Just going to the bathroom to relieve myself was interesting...it wasn't a closed room so basically anyone can come down there and hang out to see dudes peeing in a semi closed off room.  

We didn't stay here too long but I'm glad that I got to try this place at least once.
author: Ben H L.

description:
I am traveller photographer... So, I obviously have my camera with me all the time.
I was literally KICKED OUT of the bar. I got in there with a couple of friends, I decided to take one single picture inside of somebody drinking  a coffee... The bar tender, and old guy, asked me why was I taking pictures. I told him it was for my personal photography. I asked what time the bar closes... to decide if we wanted to come back later maybe. He said "we close at 1am, it's a bar, duh ???" next thing we know he was not speaking but burking: please leave... opening the door...
I was never treated that way EVER.
author: Josué I.

description:
Skimming through some of the recent reviews, I concur with the others who say the staff need an attitude adjustment. Either that, or find another place to work.

MAY 9, 2016 about 8:45am. I walk in and ask if the bar is open. The brunette, kinda plumb, kinda tall, middle-aged woman behind the counter says, "yes." So I ask for a drink. Now mind you, I ask for a drink after I ask repeatedly "really? really? really?" if the bar really is open. SF is no NYC or LA. It tends to be a city that sleeps early, works hard, and well, that's about it...So naturally, I was genuinely surprised to find something with liquor that was open before 9am.  Anyhow, after replying that the bar is open, she tells me no I can't order a drink because I look like I'm on something. I berate her a little bit. I'm very sorry I look like a hobo because I forgot my Louis Vuitton shoes back in LA but the thing is, I'm the one that can afford them and not her. My manner of speech can be rather abrupt. And the way I dress is not very well put together when I'm trotting around the streets of SF looking for a bar that claims to be as unpretentious as this one, Kerouac legacy bs and all that, etc. 

I actually like unpretentious, quirky little places with a history. All I got was pretentiousness from a woman who has no place on a pedestal of pretentious. Maybe I had a rough night. Maybe I'm already a young-ish woman who is incredibly insecure and sensitive at times, so the bitch behind the bar certainly hit a nerve when she said that I looked like I was on drugs. I have my share of problems, but drugs is not one. Even with backstory aside, there is no reason for that woman to have treated me so indignantly. 

I strongly advise the owner usher this woman to another place of employment that involves no customers. Clearly, she's burnt out on what she per her words has done "for so many years" and still has no fucking clue...
author: None Of Your Business B.

description:
First thing I look for when I walk into a bar is a good beer selection. Beer selection here was alright. I went around 9pm so that's what I had my heart set on. Had a few good ones.
All-in-all place was great. Good music playing, atmosphere was alive and friendly and the decor was funky and interesting to look at. There was upstairs seating. Never got to take a look but seemed like a popular area to sit. 
I'm probably going back today to enjoy the daytime cafe feel.
author: Anibel R.

description:
I show up here fairly often after grabbing a new book from City Lights next door to grab a drink and do some reading.

It's also a great place to get into awesome conversations with strangers or the bartenders. If you brought your own friends though, the balcony is an awesome place to sit and chat while watching the passers by outside.

The Bohemian Coffee and Kerouac drinks are both great, but I tend to just get a cheaper pint of beer.
author: Ryan H.

description:
When I first heard the name of this place, I thought it sounded like that Phil Collins song. Su-su-sudio? A friend of mine called this a good place to bring a date. I think it's a good place to meet with friends or I guess bring a date.

I suggested this spot because my friend was visiting from the South and he wanted to hit up City Lights too. Why not go to the historic bar where Jack Kerouac used to sit and write and then wander aimlessly in one of the best indie book shops in SF?

I got there a little early and sat at the bar.  Once my friends arrived, we ordered our drinks and then moved to a table. I love the interior of this place. There's so much to look at. The top level is also fun. You don't have to scream over each other to hear each other which is what makes this a good place to have a conversation with someone.

I was reading about the service - it seemed okay for us that night. Maybe because we had a small group and we kept our orders simple. I dunno. I did get the feeling though that once we were done with our drinks it was time to move which is understandable because it's a pretty well-known bar in these parts.

I would probably go back here again to catch up with friends but I wouldn't make it a regular stop if that makes sense.
author: Amy J.

description:
Come to Vesuvio if you want to drink a cocktail of history and nostalgia, with a twist of kerouac appreciation. 
i've come here on a few occasions when I do end up in north beach area and need a drink. it's fairly relaxed, and has a great upstairs. seems like its super crowded on weekends, and near empty on weekdays. 
came here on a weekday after a work dinner just to relax. only a couple people in the entire establishment, but the drinks were well mixed and the company was good. 
the fact that it's next to the legendary city lights bookstore is also a plus!
author: Xander C.

description: Vesuvio is such a great spot with tons of eclectic charm, great service, fabulous drinks and a very cool 2nd floor. We spent a few hours there on Sunday and had a great time. It is definitely worth a stop when in San Fran!
author: Julie D.

description: Moved here in 1999 and this was the first time stumbling upon Vesuvio. The bartenders had no interest in interacting with customers and were total dicks. Definitely the first and last time I'll be there. The owner need to vet the staff more closely!
author: Kevin K.

description:
I love a bar with history and character. If you're a fan of the Beat Generation or San Francisco history at all, you MUST check out this bar. Just looking at it from the outside throws you back to the 60's and 70's. All its walls are covered in frames and the entire cafe just seems cluttered, but in a good way. Even the furniture in the bathroom has an old SF vibe to it. The best part of the bar is that it has two floors, so you can grab a table upstairs and look downstairs to people watch. The crowd here will range from tourists to old ass people who have clearly been coming here for years.

The bartender that we had in particular was extremely friendly and goofing around with us because I think he could tell that we felt a little out of our element. 

Recommend taking your friends here if they're visiting from out of town. It's a great place to stop by for a San Francisco historical pub crawl (along with Li Po Cocktail Lounge in Chinatown)! It'd also be a cool place to take a date!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
This is a place that just screams San Francisco to me. It's the kind of place where I feel like a tourist in my own town, experiencing the beat era of SF. 

We walked a quite sketchy walk from Union Square after doing the winter ice skating, to have dinner here. It was a perfect place for our large group. We took over two of their giant booths. We shared a bunch of dishes including pizza and choppino. It was fun.

There is never a dull moment a Vesuvio. Every inch of wall (or really, any flat surface) was covered with unique artwork or knick knack. Service was a little lacking, but with so much going on, we were fine to wait.
author: Kari G.

description:
LOVE LOVE LOVE you, dear Vesuvio!   

If you are reading this and have never been to this amazing place, I urge you to set some time aside and take a trip.   It's not just a night out at a bar, it's a history lesson and an experience you will never forget.
author: Poppy B.

description: 7:32pm Sunday March 8th 2015 .... Here currently, the thing that stands out the most by far is the big guy bartending, WHAT. A. PRICK. !!! Completely unphased by his customers. He just stood there for a bit not even looking at us until we just have him our order which he seemed like was the most annoying thing to have to be doing. He did not deserve the courtesy tip we left him. If he's so unhappy doing this job maybe it's time for him to leave , hire someone else who's grateful for the work. Isn't that bartender 101? Be friendly?? Good atmosphere though, nice set up, girl bartender is sweet . She got the three stars I left (:
author: Alex C.

description: We happened to stumble upon this in the afternoon and I recognized it from my bookmarked yelp picks . I told my husband and stopped in before a lunch we planned. So glad we did . Not fancy but simple , honest, decent drinks. what's really great is the atmosphere , very eclectic and cozy . Loved it . Had a great time here and went on our way
author: Whitney F.

description:
This café is so awesome! Maybe because they are so chilled to serve delicious drinks and/or maybe because they let you BYOF (bring your own food) to eat there! Pizzas, cookies, burgers, you got it--just bring it! The crowds here are pretty awesome too. It's like everyone's there to catch up and have conversation...never seen anyone super drunk of eff up in here before. The staffs were very chilled too. They engage in conversation with you esp when you have food or they just simply quick to clear your empty glasses and take your order! 

Definitely a spot to stop by for a drink or two, or sit forever! Haha.
author: Mandy C.

description: Love it! It's right next to City Light Books so it's a perfect place to read and sip a beer.
author: Martha G.

description:
After dinner my friend and I decided to grab a drink. I spied the first bar and it was Vesuvio. I've never heard of it and almost wasn't sure if it was a bar from the outside. I pointed and we walked. 

Inside was quite a surprise. Really charming bar with an upstairs area for intimate conversations. Bartenders and wait staff are super friendly and nice. A lot of locals, tourists and randoms seemed to take up most of the bar. It was quite easy to strike up conversations with others. 

Quick note: Men's bathroom has a vending machine of "toys". $0.75 gets you: horny goats weed, pandora's box, genuine pecker stretcher, wuickie marriage license, over the hill condom, temptation condom and spanish fly. I've never had so much fun then I did going through those boxes.
author: Katie Anne N.

description: I'm only giving this a 3 because the cocktails are on par with what you would expect from a dive bar and I just can't conscientiously give it a 4 after shelling out almost $20 for two below average and watery atrocities. But the ambience and historic value of the bar is amazing. Go for a beer and sit upstairs, it's a beautiful building!
author: Cyris J.

description:
My first time in San Fran celebrating a girlfriend's little sisters 21st birthday was an amazing experience, until we went to Vesuvio..

As my five ladies and I arrived, we were in awe by the ambiance of this place: everything was very hip and eye catching. We grabbed a booth upstairs in the corner, so able to hear one another speak.The sign above us read "Booth for Lady Psychiatrists" which made us all smile with anticipation of the specialty drink menu (which we all ordered off of).

As soon as our server came, it was an awful experience.

No smile, no warm greeting, just a straight face asking what we wanted. Being slightly buzzed from brunch earlier, all of us were excited to be in SF being that we all were there visiting from LA for the 21st birthday. Mentioning this, we asked what the best drink would be for the birthday girl. Our server handed us the menus, and quickly walked off.

When the server arrived back, a quick glare from her stating silently that her time was money and we knew we should order ASAP. One girl after the other gave their cocktail order, and as we approached the last of our group, our server walked away before my friend could even finish her sentence of a 'Moscow Mule.' We hoped she got all of our orders?

Server then arrived with our drinks and walked off without saying anything to us. 

Drinks were good, but we were ready to get out of there as soon as we were about half way done. Finally getting our servers attention, we politely asked for the check. She then explained, "Your bill is $50.00 even including tip."

Odd that a single cocktail round between 6 girls would already include gratuity? But we didn't care to question this. As all of us reached out for our credit cards, our server exclaimed, "only one card." A bit annoyed considering none of us had cash, I offered to just pay the bill on my card and not make the situation any more awkward than it had gotten already. 

When returning with my debit, I saw that my receipt had a written tip in it from my server:

Total: $50.00
Tip: $8.00 (---this was physically written by the server)
Total: $58.00

Completely shocked, considering this is forgery and unless stated on the menu of added gratuity, tip is solely at the customers discretion. I called to the server once in sight again, and she looked me in the eyes as I calmly explained this (all 6 of us girls have and still work in the restaurant biz, so this wasn;t going unnoticed), and she said "well, my manager told me to do that. So, you can go down and talk to him about it." I said I would, and asked for the manager and her name. She gave it, and scurried off.

Still in dismay, we sat at the table and wondered if it was even worth speaking to the manager. We had a great time and didn't feel like putting anymore of a dark cloud on the day. As I was about to sign my name, the server came back and took the receipt, and as she scratched out the tip she wrote in, she said, "you know what, forget it. I don't even want the tip anymore." and stomped away.

Now, COMPLETELY over this whole scene, I signed as my tab, my friends and I got our coats on and proceeded downstairs.

As we walked by the bartender/manager, one of my friends exclaimed, "by the way, your server was extremely rude to us." He looked at her in anger, and said "well YOU tried to get free drinks for your friends birthday from her." Taken aback, my friend told him he was entirely wrong, and VERBATIM, he said back:
"Yeah? Well you're a liar and a f*cking c*nt!"

Need I say more? A disappointing representation of what SF is all about. I have never received such poor and disrespectful service in my entire life. I usually come on Yelp to write high reviews, but I could not let this one go unannounced. =/
author: Dana P.

description: First time coming here. Really great atmosphere and drinks. However, the waitress that served us was extremely rude. Maybe I thought she was having a bad day...? But it happened more than once where she gave our table an attitude and dirty looks. We were extremely turned off. There's no reason to be rude to your customers who are not even asking for much. Not sure if I'll come back here again.
author: Regina S.

description:
This might be one of my favorite bars in the world that I've only been to three times. Could it be because it's haunted by the Beats? I doubt it. And even if that were true, the Beats aren't my favorite generation of writers anyway. In fact, I blame them for scores of talentless self-indulgent navel-gazers to follow.  

But this isn't a Beat Generation review. Let's get back to the bar. I came here one night recently alone, not in the mood for a scene, but definitely in the mood for a drink after dinner in Little Italy. I hadn't been to Vesuvio in about 7 years and hoped it hadn't changed much from how I remembered it-dark, inviting and cheap. I recalled sitting upstairs and enjoying the view, as I hung out with my friends. I might have even vowed back then to come back alone so I could get lost in my dreams, as I am apt to do.

I did just that on my recent visit. It was just what I needed at the start of a busy work week, to stare out at all the people walking around Columbus Ave, making up lives for them, while pretending that  I was at one of my favorite spots in Greenwich Village (which of course was the East Coast Beat stomping ground) and so I did just that on my most recent visit, vodka soda in one hand and a notebook and pen in the other, although I didn't write down a word (OK, so the notebook part is a lie. Seven years ago, however, I would have definitely had the notebook and I might have even gazed at my navel a bit).

I'm not sure if the night had some kind of special going on, or if the friendly bartender forgot to add in one of my drinks, because when I paid my tab, I was shocked by how cheap it was. Vesuvio, I will always be a regular, even if only in spirit.
author: Joi B.

description: I love this place for its character, history, balcony, and early hours. Tony is simply the greatest!
author: Ben R.

description:
Hey Vesuvio. Asians don't all look alike.

I was just refused service at the bar. I walked in and made eye contact with a bartender to order. She turned and told me I had knocked over a waitress (who was standing next to her, and who pointed at me) and refused to serve me. Yea -- I hadn't? I literally just walked in and up to the bar.

Luckily, my friend had already gotten me a drink from another bartender. Later I was telling this story and turned out this woman HAD accidentally bumped a server as she was making her way through the super crowded bar; she didn't realize that woman had fallen against a chair, but another friend of hers saw it. Took a while to put it all together.

Anyway, Asians don't all look alike -- and I look nothing like this woman. (Unless you're one of those older, white men who sometimes tell me I look like Sandra Oh and Lucy Liu. You might think we look alike, but you would be wrong.) What gets me is that the bartenders didn't ask me about it or anything. If they had, I would've said that I'd just walked in, hadn't touched or talked to anyone, and what the hell are they talking about?! Instead they just accused me and walked away.

I love the history of this bar. I'm not a regular, I've been here a few times before, but I won't be coming back. It's 2016, and that kind of leap to judgment and treatment of a customer is ignorant and rude. Really poor service.
author: Jane Y.

description: I was in San Francisco a couple of years ago  for a wedding, and I found Vesuivo while I was walking around.  I went in for the espresso, and stayed. The bartenders were friendly and helpful, and so were the regulars i talked with.  And to my great surprise, no one was offended when I informed them I was from Los Angeles.
author: Doug H.

description:
Last week I witnessed an unfortunate encounter with the bartenders here. I tried to write the owners about it, but my emails bounced back so I'm posting about it here:

Hello,

I was at your bar last night and I saw one of the women behind the bar--short red hair, green eyeshadow--behave extremely rudely with a customer. She was confrontational and unnecessarily hostile. The costumer, a soft spoken African American woman, seemed embarrassed but when she asked the bartender why she was so rude, she didn't apologize but only raised her voice more, asking if the woman "had something to say." As if this weren't bad enough, another bartender, a woman with short blonde hair, came up behind her and loudly told the customer to "just leave."

I was uncomfortable watching this exchange and I could tell that other people at the bar were, too. Maybe the woman behind the bar was having a bad day. Maybe she dislikes her job. It could be coincidence that she lashed out at the only person of color I could see in the place. But as an outsider to the situation, it was an unsettling thing to watch. If I were running a business I'd like to know that this was going on, particularly in 2015, when things like this could easily be filmed and posted on the Internet to jeopardize your business.

I love Vesuvio. It's a great spot with a generally good vibe. But I won't be going back there on nights when these women are working behind the bar.
author: Tanya R.

description:
Quintessential North Beach, Beat Generation bar.

Good alcohol selection and the bar has a very Jack Kerouac feel to it.

Neat place to go to feel like you're in old San Francisco, and for some interesting people watching especially upstairs by the windows.
author: Eric B.

description:
Ah, one of my single favorite bars in San Francisco. Vesuvio is MAGICAL. That's not hyperbole either, this place really feels magical. 

Your friends who don't really know San Francisco - take them here. Your friends who DO know San Francisco - take them here. Everyone seems to overlook North Beach as a touristy spot with seedy topless bars. I mean, which it is, but Vesuvio is legitimately better than any bar you'd find in the lower haight or mission. Try me on that.

It feels like getting drunk at your grandparent's friend's home, where everything is antique and seems fancy in a muted sort of way and you get the feeling there's a story behind everything in there. The bi-level seating is pretty great, always sit upstairs if you can because the view allows for you to better take in the bar. There's table service too!

Love love love this bar.
author: K M.

description: Everything a unique bar should be. The bartenders were great, the libations were perfect in every way possible, and the ambiance rich in history.
author: Matthew K.

description:
This is turning into one of my favorite bars in this part of town!

A friend showed me this place last month, now I've been coming back when meeting up with some friends. I love it! If you are looking for a chill spot to grab some drinks with friends, this place is it. It has two stories of decked out walls, fully stocked bar, great bartenders, and a whole lot of quirkiness to it. Supposedly Jack London frequented this place back in the day as it was his local watering hole. Great little piece of history in this building. 

Grab a set on the second floor if there is room. You get a unique view of the bar and streets from up there. The location is great, it's easy to find, so stop on in!
author: Akvile D.

description: A slanty shanty with expensive drinks and low ceilings.  Pass next time.
author: XiXi Z.

description:
probably the best bar i've ever been to.

this place is super quirky and awesome. reasonably priced drinks and great atmosphere.  I love the 2nd level of the bar which has booths and smaller tables with a large window that you can people watch from. 

so glad this place exists!
author: April E.

description:
I'm really spoiled by the bars where the bartenders know me. (Guess that sounds bad too). Well work has brought me to a different wood and I'm not too shy to step into an unfamiliar tavern. 

Easy listening music softly playing in the background.  No rowdy bunch to push through. Happy hour from 3 to 7.  Good start.  Tables and seats are clean.  +1.

Quenching my thirst with a Sierra Nevada. $1 off. I don't remember Sierra being so bitter, and the glass could be colder.  Otherwise, it's still a beer.

Plenty of seats and the booths are pretty comfy.  I could sit here and read for 30 minutes and be very happy. I like the natural light coming in from the streets.  Unfortunately/fortunately all I have is a view of strip clubs and cars zipping by.
author: Larry L.

description: I always bring people here when I'm showing them San Francisco - it's just such a pretty little place & definitely unique to the city. I generally find the staff friendly and the drinks reasonably priced. Sitting upstairs is a treat if you can get a seat up there.
author: Fi M.

description:
What a cool spot. Like seriously this place looks nuts.

It was a good oasis of booze in a sea of rain.
author: Misha T.

description:
I was charmed by this quaint little Italian lounge-bar-hybrid on the edge of North Beach.

The interior takes antique and rustic European to a new level. It doesn't feel fake and artificially designed like the Olive Gardens of today. You can actually feel the history literally etched in the walls. From the colorful graffiti mural on the outside to the hundreds of old paintings covering the walls inside, you'll feel like you're in an old tavern in a Sicilian town.

The space is divided into a bar+lounge downstairs (which let's face it is where where the cool kids hang out) and an upper seating area where you can imbibe with a view.

The drinks were fairly priced and certainly warrant another visit to this iconic cafe.

-----

Distinguishing factor: The Soprano's reference makes this joint way cooler. And they own the domain vesuvio.com, which should automatically tell you this place is older than the internet.
author: Nick A.

description: I stopped into Vesuvio on the recommendation of my co worker. My son was visiting from Boston and I thought he would appreciate it's legacy. Indeed, it was a fun experience for us both. Our bartender, whose name I learned later was Joanna, was awesome. Knowledgeable, kind, and extremely like-able! It wasn't that she gave us a ton of attention, it was just the vibe of the comfort that she projected. While we were there, one of her regulars brought her in a sandwich, which she seemed just delighted about and it made us smile. I'm pretty sure she pegged us immediately as more touristy folks, but she didn't make us feel that way, which is always nice to not be "talked down to" by more local SF folks. My son enjoyed the experience and I was happy to share it with him. He is back in Boston and I am back in Berkeley....but I'll be back....my Palmoa drink was yummy! Thanks!
author: Cheri L.

description:
Great for the history and ambience. Kind of meh in the drinks department.

It is nicer to go in the late afternoon as it get very crowded later in the day.
author: Yael S.

description: Character. This place is awesome. Such a cool bar. There is so much stuff to look at all around the whole bar, that being said the upstairs was the best. We got there in the afternoon and went upstairs and took a seat at the very end overlooking the street. I could sit there all day just a cool vibe. Very nice staff.
author: Todd W.

description: I so badly want to give this place a decent rating because the atmosphere was great for a post July 4th drink, but I can't because one short-haired waitress was too rude. I watched her yell with frustration at a patron who was coming down the stairs, "Come down or go up!" In the waitress's defense, she had a tray of drinks, and I know working late on a holiday sucks, I've been there. Sorry, lady. But she then proceeded to shove me because of where I was standing in the bar area, near her entrance to the kitchen. In her defense, it was busy and I was likely obstructing her path to some extent. Sorry, lady. I worked in the service industry for years, I know it sucks. But your job is to be less of a jerk than most. To serve with a smile. You straight made me uncomfortable. So you should try to do that better. And don't touch people. It's weird. Thanks.
author: Nicole S.

description:
Stopped in one night to grab a couple of beers in this well known bar that still attracts an interesting clientele and serves up a cold beer.

The story of this place, according to the friendly bartender, is that it was the hangout for Beat poets and that you can still find them wandering in on some days.  My interest was the photos and the history of San Fran that was depicted in pics around the place, plus we had been wandering the city for hours and a cold one from their many taps sounded pretty good!.

Went up to the 2nd level and I loved the view from up there . . . . . . people watching to my hearts content and boy . . . . .what a collection of people!

Close to the City Lights bookstore, this piece of San Fran history is well worth a stop during your next trip to the city by the Bay!
author: Carol K.

description: Yep. The Beatniks' were right. This place is a great place to get down. Just don't flip the switch upstairs...it's connected to the Point Of Sale. I know, "Why would they have a switch...asking you to flip it?", you ask. Not sure. Just don't do it. All in all...in North Beach I fall back here. Drinks and friends. What more are you looking for?
author: Rob L.

description: Spent many years hanging out in this place.  The North Beach that I remember from a long time ago.  Best bar staff in SF (IMO)....I have zillions of fond memories of this bar.  From sitting in the front watching people walk by, to upstairs in the cramped booths that overlook the stairs, having waaay to much guinness sitting at the bar to smoking joints in the alley.  Whenever we'd go out in NB, it would always include a stop into Vesuvio for a pint or two or three, etc...  I love this place.  Small, quaint and perfect place to take a date or out with friends for the night.  It's perfect.
author: Kris B.

description:
For a bar with this much history, it is funny how many regulars drink here and that you don't really get all that many touristy type groups.

Located next to City Lights Book Store on the border of Chinatown and North Beach ... the location is great. Across the street are the world's sketchiest strip clubs. Walk a ways down and you can grab a nice meal at an outdoor table in the Italian section.

Vesuvio is a throwback to the days of Beat writing and Beat poetry. You can just imagine tons of people in black turtlenecks and striped jeans drinking whiskey and discussing politics or philosophy or reciting poetry. We went and there was an annoying group of Austrailians, a guy in a top hat on heroine who was passing out in his booth, a bunch of young hippie looking types writing in notebooks and a smattering of 20-30 something year old couples.

The best deal by far is $5 for a pint glass of beer and a shot of Wild Turkey whiskey. They also have a chalkboard up next to the bar with 'special wines' ... you can get a bottle of wine for $15 from this board. The drinks here are dirt cheap.

The place looks like it hasn't been updated (or cleaned) since Jack Kerouac and Bob Dylan used to drink here after stopping at City Lights. Kerouac was a bastard ... and an alchoholic ... thankfully most of the crowd was not as belligerant and sloppy as I am sure he used to get here.

The bar on the bottom level is nice and there are a few tables as well. The top level is my favorite part ... there are small tables that have windows which look out over the busy street and ally. And there are also two big booths which look over the bar. You can see the original gas chandaliers still lit with flames. These booths are great for discussions.

Day drinking here is alright but at night its such a divey scene, that is my favorite time to go. If you are staying in Fisherman's Wharf, there is a great cheesesteak cash only joint on the walk back open late at night. Do not under any circumstances go into the strip clubs across the street. That was an experience that would make Jack Kerouac himself blush. Yuck.

The only thing I didn't like about Vesuvio is the lack of decent music playing. I felt like they could use a jukebox ... or some better tunes.
author: E T.

description: The fucking worst Cosmo of my life. Undrinkable. Such a shame. We had high hopes for this place. This is the kind of cocktail that could give you herpes. Go across the street to the Devils acre or whatever it's called. We went there first and its wayyyyyy better. Also way better service there too
author: Fibi S.

description:
It just can't be that a bar that is featured in every SF travel guide on earth is so bad.

The fact that they have customers no matter what makes the staff at Vesuvio forget that  customer service is indeed fundamental.

-  the bartender is extremely rude:

he placed what looked like a glass of sparkling water just right next to our drinks, and when we asked if that was for us, he yelled "noooOO!" at us as if we had just talked shit about his mother.
and when asked if he could, please, put a piece of lime in my friend's drink, he practically threw one at her. He threw the thing!

- the drinks are mediocre:

an iced-tea-flavored vodka and lemonade was probably the worst drink I have ever had.
not to mention the most horrible thing I have ever seen on a drink: a thick lemon rind that seemed to have been chewed. (you can look at this work of art in the picture above)
author: Alessandra A.

description: Great historical place next to City Light Books. Dirty Martinis and Manhattans were poured quickly and often and we had a great time. Old school but fun.
author: Troy B.

description: Well I really like this joint. Bathrooms are upstairs. Tables are upstairs also. When upstairs, the waitress takes care of your needs. Great because the Bar is downstairs. Nice and loud. Upstairs is like a loft
author: Elease T.

description:
I adore Vesuvio! Its a great place to go to at the end of the night, when I'm really looking to kick back and chill before heading home. I never get trashed here, because this isn't really the venue for it. 

2 levels, and I usually manage to go upstairs. My favorite spots are the booths, where you can look down and see the bartenders making drinks and have a nice corner to talk with friends. I LOVE that despite not serving food, they don't mind if you bring in food. Just bus your own tables after. Nice, huh? I often go to Sam's across the street, grab some food, then bring it back for bar snacks while choppin' it up with friends.

The space is a little tight, which makes walking a bit of a struggle. There's one bathroom for females and one for guys (girls is upstairs, guys is like, basement level). Yeah, its a little touristy, but whatever. You're right on the border of Chinatown and Northbeach, across the street from several strip clubs. Just grab a seat by the windows and enjoy the show. =)
author: Lily W.

description:
On a recent trip to San Francisco, I popped into Vesuvio to grab a drink before meeting friends for dinner. Given the history of Vesuvio (and City Lights, its literary next-door neighbor) I was expecting this place to be a tourist trap. I was, however, pleased to find that the bar was refreshingly local while still managing to capture the spirit of the Beat generation. 

From the bartender sharing his extensive knowledge of Beatles trivia to the nice happy hour special ($1 off draft beers) Vesuvio was a friendly, affordable, and historic place to spend an idle hour in the city.
author: Colin O.

description: This is my favorite SF bar. Every time I visit San Francisco, I always make sure to stop by here. Good vibes and laid back people is always bound to be a good time. When you step inside, you will be greeted by cool photos and old school posters and the bar. But don't stop yet, I recommend walking to the back and taking the stairs up to the second floor where it's even more relaxed. Since I love people watching, this is the spot I prefer since you get a view to the outside on the second floor. Not to mention, the more intimate atmosphere upstairs is always a plus
author: Miriam Z.

description: A narrow, dark wood paneled corner bar with tiny booths and tiny chairs at tiny tables -- and, at least the last visit, a waitress with the biggest smile.  I've always had pretty good service there - whether with a small group or a large one (or even in the middle of Santarchy!).  Reasonable prices and a good atmosphere.
author: Jenn C.

description:
My favorite bar in San Francisco so far. The ambience is just what I need, and I need to see local color, and authentic weirdos drinking in the daytime in a dark and interestingly decorated bar. I need to see old men in beret's with their hand bound diaries sitting in the corner with a pen in hand maybe writing something beautiful.

They make a damned fine bloody mary here, and sometimes I pretend the absinthe they serve is real. The prices are decent, the decor is bohemian and feels authentic, and its right next door to City Lights Bookstore. I stop in every time I am in town.
author: Tracy B.

description: This place has character and it really represents San Francisco. Very cool decor, two stories, unique art covers the walls. Prices are pretty normal: $5 beer, $6 mixed drinks. Waitress was kinda rude :/ but you are in the city.
author: Sarah D.

description:
Came here one night in December to celebrate a friend's bday. Despite living in SF for nearly a year, I had yet to really explore or spend any quality time in North Beach. Nor had he, and so he figured best to expand his horizons and get out of the typical NoPa-Lower Haight-Haight scene. I came here without any preconceptions (only now after looking it up again I understand the historic aspect of it - apparently I have some learning to do). It's a dark, cozy place with bar stools, tables and an upstairs (ladies room here) with additional seating. Otherwise, you'll probably be standing if it's a busy night.

We had about a dozen folks in our group, and someone managed to arrive early enough to score a table in the back. The place was moderately crowded for a Saturday night with an eclectic mix of people milling about. I don't imagine there are many places in the city where hipsters, Asian students, the after work crowd, and old timers can really mingle so well. The drinks were poured fairly strong and were fairly priced. What I was most amazed by was the memory of our server - she was tops (I wish I remembered her name because she deserves a hand). We never waited too long for her to check up on us, nor for our drinks to be delivered.

If I was in the area, I would definitely stop by again. As it's now cold and I'm lazy, likely won't be back too soon. Still, recommended.
author: Allison B.

description:
Vesuvio is so nice we visited it twice...in one night. We stumbled upon Vesuvio the first time after wandering down Jack Kerouac Alley from Chinatown. We peaked in and dug the vibe inside. It is kitschy and colorful and wonderful and the drinks are plentiful and strong. After grabbing dinner in nearby Chinatown and making friends with the couple at the table next to ours, we brought our new friends back for another couple of drinks and they liked the Vesuvio as much as we did!

Staff was friendly and prompt despite the bar being really busy (on Christmas night, no less). I'd say if you're a fan of laid back bars with a ton of history and charm, this is the place to go.
author: Texie Y.

description:
Pop in for the setting, the history and the vibe (see other reviews).

Don't expect too much from the beer selection. Depending on which bar tender's working you might get a generously-poured radioactive manhattan.

It's a cool spot, resting on it's laurels and doing just fine with the locals and a steady flow of tourist traffic. No incentive to up their game I suspect.
author: Matt G.

description: Cool spot to hang with some friends for a drink. If you can, grab a seat upstairs by the window and watch the SF night scene go by.  And afterwards, check out Jack Kerouac alley next to it and try to contemplate the wise sayings engraved on the alleyway and try make sense of your life with your inebriated mind.  It's a cool experience.
author: Syddie P.

description: San Francisco plus Kerouac. I used to go here from time to time for a drink and earthquake slides you see on the wall while catching up with your cooler friends who moved to the  city.A San Francisco tradition how could anyone who likes to talk to people in a crowded loud vintage artist bar not love this place! :)
author: Brian D.

description:
I've never reviewed- but the horrible service and the piss poor attitude of the waitresses at Vesuvio was enough for me to sign up for an account.

ADVICE- Its a nice bar - but there are nice bars all around the city that don't have assholes tending to customers. GO SOMEWHERE ELSE.

Waitresses- (Both a brunette/Redish and a blonde.) 
First waitress we have gives us an attitude for wanting to use more than 1 card to pay for drinks and pitchers. Then told us that she had to close us out because her shift was over and wanted her tip. 

Second waitress-  does not wait on us, so I go to the bar to order.  Slams pitchers and glasses on our table and storms off without even looking at any of us. When we ask for our bill, she writes in her tip amount on my receipt that she wants us to pay. When I asked why the other waitress didn't write in her tip- Waitress response- we have the right to do that if we want for parties of 6. 

VESUVIO- MAKE A SIGN, YOU HAVE SIGNS FOR HOW LONG IT TAKES TO FLUSH A TOLIET, MIGHT BE A GOOD IDEA TO ALSO HAVE A SIGN ABOUT YOU TIP "POLICY" FROM SHITTY WAITRESSES 

I have never been to a bar where horrible waitresses demanded a tip!  I am more than happy to give a good tip for good service, but when I have one waitress acting rude to us an another writing in her tip on our bill when she is being rude and not even attending our table.
 
TIPS ARE NOT MANDATORY. 

Nice bar , horrible service.
author: Marlene L.

description:
Lucky to be able to call this bar our local spot.

Great environment and really historic feel. Stuff about Jack Kerouac, but regardless of that, its just a great old bar with and really funny environment. 

Drink prices are good too.
author: Rob F.

description: Great quirky chill spot and one I always come back to when in San Fran. At 1pm on a Thursday afternoon there are two older gentlemen playing chess in the corner. The barkeep is friendly but laid back and drink prices are reasonable for this city. The demon cat behind the bar completes the ambiance perfectly.
author: Sara W.

description:
I love the decor and ambience of this bar.  It's very renaissance-esqe and hipster.  This is a great place to meet with friends to chat as it's pretty chill inside (as opposed to crazy noisy and crowded).  There is a long bar to sit at or plenty of tables to sit at.  I really loved the upstairs balcony seating area that is exceptionally quiet.   

Vesuvio remind me more of a cafe then a bar - so i guess that makes this a cafe-bar.  Great place to read and drink.  

There's no food here, but you can bring your own food during lunchtime.  Awesome!
author: Diana L.

description:
On the outside it's a small cafe looking kinda place, on the inside it's a good vibe at a bar.  There are two stories to the place and I sat upstairs.  The upstairs over looks the lower level of the bar and the scenery on Columbus Street. The upstairs area is not too spacey and the ceiling is not too high, but it works.

Got 2 drinks for only $15.  Such a good vibe, I'd love to come here again.
author: Darylynn D.

description: Not even worth a star. Seriously the worst service, from the people outside who had a gun exchange, to the bouncer who had attitude. The racist waitress who was rude to anyone who was not white (chick with the short bangs). All around bad experience . Don't go.
author: Arpi T.

description: It was fun to have a bastardly booze shot in one of Bon Scott's old hangouts. Cool as crank.
author: Duke O.

description:
Near perfect ambience with a cool upstairs area that overlooks City Lights bookstore.  This bar seems like the quintessential North Beach spot to me.  I enjoyed watching people take camera phone pics in front of the mural on ground level from my spot on high.  Also, there were some nerdy people that appeared to be playing an urban form of laser tag in Kerouac alley between Vesuvio and City Lights.  Less appealing were the drifters that seemed to be picking out armpit lint next to the building (seriously, more than one).  In sum, grab a spot from on the second level because the people watching is top notch.

Less than top notch is their beer selection (Anchor Steam and Lagunita's IPA being the most interesting offerings).  And even worse than that was the cheesy funk that seemed to be imparted into the beer likely due to dirty lines.  Husband and I had to trade beers midway as funky IPA seemed marginally better to me than funky Anchor Steam (and the reverse was true for him, I hope).  Having had a stomach bug just two days prior, I was afraid it would be invoked again.

I didn't check out the bathrooms, but husband did.  He said they were also where the kegs were stored.  Explains a lot.

Moral of the story: sit upstairs, stick to mixed drinks!
author: Carly B.

description:
After spending the day at an 11-inning Giants game with my husband, it was time to get in some nerdy beatnik time for me!

There was a chalkboard displayed over the bar, which listed several concoctions named after writers and poets.  The drink I had (the Jack Kerouac?) was strong, but in a good way.  I took in the scenery:  a hodgepodge of photographs and art on the walls and a crazy looking cat with light-up eyes.  This is a relaxing dive bar, a dive bar without the random street signs and sports memorabilia alongisde Smirnoff ads.

Can't say much about the service.  It's not a place where people are going to kiss your ass.  If you want a drink, you're going to have to get off YOUR ass.  It wasn't too busy when we stopped in, and I felt like I was burdening them.

Yes, it is kind of a tourist trap since it's located off of Kerouac alley and next to City Lights book store, but I think this is something even locals can appreciate.  And for tourists, it's an absolute MUST.  My husband, not knowing who Kerouac was, still enjoyed himself.

And the BEST part is heading to the bookstore AFTER this.  Browsing books after a couple of cocktails?  You betcha.
author: Angela P.

description:
The idea of sexy, rebellious young men of an era long gone is romantic....
Nostalgia is alive and well at this beautiful and authentically SF bar which once served as a watering hole for the likes of Jack Keroiac and Neal Cassady . Sexy bar staff walk up and down the stairs and serve you whiskey on trays. Hipsters play scrabble using the city glare out the window as lights and a girl with a basket comes table to table selling cigarettes and chocolate condoms. If I could give this place 10 stars I would.
author: Angel W.

description: All the charm and hard work put into this bar's ambiance is killed by the arrogance of the staff. We came in happy to be in such a charming place and our waitress was so impatient and rude, we just finished our drinks and left. Not coming back!
author: Maria N.

description:
I ventured to this part of town to visit the bookstore next door but upon seeing this place from the outside, realized it would be a perfect place to read any book that I bought. After leaving the bookstore, I came over and went upstairs where there are tables next to the window that look down on the street below. 

The music selection was great - relaxing but not too relaxing. Waitress was very attentive and didn't seem to mind that I was just there to have a beer and read my book. 

I didn't eat there so can't comment on the food. But as far as a relaxing cafe atmosphere, this place can't be beat.
author: Matt O.

description: A must visit.  It's a great bar.  And if you "know time," are beat, or even have a passing interest in Kerouac, Ferlinghetti, Ginsberg, Neal Cassady, et.al., then you may want to put Vesuvio near the top of your list along with the adjacent alley and famous bookstore.
author: Robert J.

description:
My husband and I were visiting from Vegas and we went there to get a drink before hitting china town, the bartender was RUDE as hell it was packed and small in there and when asked if he could make a drink he said "i prefer not to" really thats what you say to people that come in to your establishment. Needless to say we left as we got better service at a little bar in chinatown. I dont even get that kinda rudness on the strip when I go down there in vegas. All this guy was serving was beer and wine..whooo big orders to fiill. Would give it a zero but i picked one star..

be nicer to your customers old man
author: Sheri C.

description:
Offbeat, low key, cool, divey, intimate, eccentric and even a little whimsical.

Those are probably the best ways to describe this bar, most likely my favorite after visiting San Francisco. It's well known, along with a number of other bars in this mixed city, but I heavily recommend this one.

Sure, it can be crowded at times, but this place has a very neat vibe to it. All different objects are framed on the walls - magazine covers, matchbooks, letters. I'm personally a huge fan of the varied stained glass lights hanging from the ceiling.

So I'd ignore the crowd, grab a beer or if you're feeling the mood, a glass of absinthe, and explore this historic place.
author: N. M.

description:
July 2014:
We love this place and stop in on every trip. You really need to google this place and check out it's amazing history of who's who that have been here. Friendly staff and atmosphere and a location in North Beach that can't be beat. But on July 19th Joanna really made us feel welcome, she is a great rep for Vesuvio's and we will be back on our next trip.
author: Jon U.

description:
One of my favorite bars in SF.  A must visit while in north beach.

This bar has got tons of character.  It's a real centerpiece of San Francisco culture to me.  Sure, it attracts too many tourists, but it's got so much going for it.

The decor is great.  It's.. cozy.  You can find a small corner table with friends and spend hours drinking and talking.  That's what I love about it the most I think -- it's very conducive to having a great discussion.

It's easy to get drinks, the bartenders are attentive, and they'll come around every so often to take drink orders.

Drinks are relatively cheap, and they have good specials all the time.

Again -- A must visit/try for any native or visitor(yes you, you dirty tourist)
author: Yan L.

description:
My heart skipped a beat just walking into the bar (pun intended). 
We spent so much time on the road that we didn't have too much time to soak in the history, but those walls spoke as I walked around the interior. Talk about a perfect location, this place felt like home. 

You won't find any dharma bums here, but the staff is friendly and the characters that stop by for a drink are sure to amuse you!
author: Alyvia M.

description: Great Pub, the atmosphere is great. Loved the rusty decor. I visted this pub on Halloween. Me and a group of friends crashed here after party. Our Host was gracious and all the patrons were very animated. Would definitely visit this pub next time when I visit the City.
author: Saif2521 ..

description: What a cool little spot. It has so much character and it's filled with history. The drinks were decently priced, less than $10 for a drink. Will not disappoint.
author: Joanna F.

description:
There's so much history here. As a writer and lover or literature, this place is always a place I love going to. I admire it so much for everything it was, but not so much for what it is. Other than how iconic it is, the longer you're there the more unspectacular is seems. There is so much they can improve on without sacrificing the integrity of the bar's history. At least do something different with the drinks or figure out how to make the most of how small the space is. 

Actually the service is pretty good as far as the staff who tends the table. The bartenders don't stand out to me in any way. But overall its a fun time. I still love coming here.
author: Dexter H.

description: After city lights it's always a good idea to take your new book to this bar and drink like the beats. Go ahead and wax poetic, just be sure to keep it off the bathroom wall & in your moleskin. The second floor has a nice view to people watch and it's a perfect stop for friends from out of town as well as locals.
author: Rebecca C.

description: Maybe I'm biased.. Maybe the culture and the life of this bar brings out this english literature nerd in me. Biased or not, I think this is probably the best hole in the wall bar in the city. It's quirky and charming and doesn't take itself too seriously. How could it? It's nestled next door to City Lights book shop and offers and upstairs seating area with windows that look out over the street. After ordering an anchor steam I get lost walking around and looking at all the newspaper articles and signs on the wall. Truly I could spend a whole day there drinking and absorbing the infectious spirit that is Vesuvio. I've even seen men bring a computer and hide away in a booth to get some work done over a pint of beer. It's never been obnoxious or full of drunk college kids. It's a bar to hang out at and meet people. Everyone has a story and Vesuvio is the coolest watering hole to meet people and engage in conversation. It's a transient bar you may never meet the same people twice, but rest assured each time you enter Vesuvio you will meet someone worth remembering.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Automatic 20% tip for parties 6 or more even if your server is horrible and rude. 

The balls on the female, short haired, unfriendly, server to tell us to our face after ignoring us and making rude comments that she is adding in an automatic gratuity. 

Bar is fine but will never return because of such horrible service.
author: J A.

description:
Mandatory 20% tip for party of 6+ when the tab is drinks only?  That is absolutely INSANE.  Rude waitress to boot.  

I'll go buy drinks at one of the nearby bars, and I'll tip 20% gladly, just don't try and force me to do it when you provide terrible service. 

It is not nice to be not nice.
author: Mike I.

description:
The draft Widmer is my absolute favorite, best I've had among the bars in SF. Creamy on the top, bursting with the live yeast flavor which fools me I am drinking a potion to health and happiness.  

A nice place to just sit and watch characters of people, enjoy solitude, melt-in to the 40s and 50s music and forget I have work to do the next day.
author: Minna S.

description: This place is awful! I understand it's a historic SF relic, but the staff here are so rude. Do not go unless you enjoy people being terrible to you and charging you too much for drinks.
author: Andrea C.

description:
Honestly, the main reason I go to a bar is the atmosphere. I could drink a Stella Artois at home, but I'd never pass up the opportunity to pass up said drink if I could do so in a bar like Vesuvio.

With prohibition specials like "Bud and Bourbon" and the ever-popular absinthe on the menu, Vesuvio is a bar that is full of character. The second floor is even cooler, giving you a view of not only the varied patrons, but also some of the most random of memorabilia. Where else can you find a Powell and Hyde cable car sign?
author: Casey S.

description:
Walking down Colombia ave and did a double take " is that a 2 story bar ". On vacation we become people watchers by default and this was the prime location. 

Strong mix of locals and tourist ( I try to blend in with my California bear hoodie and socks). 

Hint of advice, know what you want. Have an idea at least. This isn't one of those signature cocktail places.
author: Samuel C.

description:
We were having a great time here until a shift change or something and were unattended to for over 30 minutes while trying to flag a waitress down and eventually asking the friendly bouncer if he could get somebody to help us.

Eventually this lady came over (short brown hair) and was extremely rude and asked us what we wanted and to hurry since she was busy and upset that we asked for assistance. She also automatically included 20% gratuity even though she was rude and obnoxious. I tried to diffuse the situation as we all understand that they might have been understaffed etc but there is never an excuse for being rude to friendly and paying customers. Especially when there are many other options in the area. 

We were having a great time up until then but I will not return to this establishment.
author: Ryan S.

description:
Apparently one of the oldest bars in SF. The decor makes it feel very old timey. Back when SF was home to artists and weirdos. In fact, look across the street and you'll see most of them.

While the drinks are just alright, this Kerouac-loving bar has a nice layout. Especially upstairs where you can chill. They do serve Absinthe so if you're up for it, you can get it.

Also if you want to feel like a giant, just hit up the bathroom.
author: Victor C.

description: This place is awesome! Ice cold beers, quick and friendly service. I have now been a handful of times and each visit was excellent. Today I was even greeted at the doorstep by a friendly staff member. Unfortunately, before I had one foot in the door I was told I was not allowed to be served. Obviously I have been cut off before at an establishment, but not for reasons the woman stated. I attempted to leave my dog curbside to duck in and have a quick pint before tackling another couple of hills on our afternoon stroll. It's not like I didn't have a bone for my furry best friend. I love the guy and even would've offered him a thirst quenching beverage if I was allowed one myself. I will return for future visits to quench my thirst, but next time I will have the audacity to leave my trusty steed, cooped up and alone in my air conditioned hotel room. Animal rights are important and I'm enthusiastic about positive hospitality experiences.
author: Kyle H.

description: Huge bar. Serves the usual beers for the usual price. We got waitress service and she was great, even when the bar started to get packed. Place is good for groups. Only complaint I have is that the women's restroom is only one stall.
author: Lisa T.

description: I went during Santacon. Like another person said, it's a good oasis of booze in a sea of rain. The doorman had had e fucking nough at Santacon and was over it. Like Halloween & St. Patrick's Day had a baby, he said. I don't blame him. People were rowdy. But fortunately, once inside, the racousness dissipated and it was nothing but chill drinking and shmoozing. We met some nice people from Brazil and the drink I spilled landed only on myself. :)
author: Em L.

description:
There's not a bar in North Beach without as much charm and bohemian style as this one. Yes, the poets, yes, "Howl," all that...

But I like stopping here because in addition to the charm, you can grab a table upstairs, stare at the weirdness happening down that charming alley (which was once a street) and keep drinking without going downstairs because they wave waiter service. Phenomenal.

Tip: if you sit at a booth with someone you like, you can have more "privacy." The odds of you getting a booth are next to zero.
author: Alexia R.

description:
How can a place be in business that has the most horrific serving/bartending staff I have ever encountered IN MY LIFE!!!  I have been working in the serving industry for 12 years and I would never dream of treating a patron the way my friends and I were treated here.  

You're suppose to wait until we leave and talk shit behind our backs like normal bar staff!  

Completely disrespected by our server who argued repeatedly, rolled her eyes, tapped her foot, looked around and generally acted like we were a complete nuisance to her.  We were then told the manager was aware of our complaint and as we left the so-called manager yelled derogatory comments at us.

We were not rowdy, overly intoxicated nor was the bar over crowded to the extent that we were holding up the waitress.  (all upstairs seating area if that makes a difference).  All of us are in the service industry and in our late 20's and know proper dining out etiquette.  

There are so many amazing places to eat and drink in San Francisco, BYPASS VESUVIO unless you feel like a BDSM evening, but I say, save that for the bedroom.
author: Chandra S.

description:
This place makes me want to don a black turtleneck with dark glasses and a beret, Jack Kerouac book in hand! I can hear the sound of the bongos already...

Fittingly, Vesuvio is right next to Jack Kerouac Alley and City Lights Books, so I had a blast checking out the paintings and browsing some titles before heading in. There's a large selection of beers, plus coffee and speciality drinks, such as the Jack Kerouac (rum, tequila, & OJ!)

The decor is awesome, so even if you aren't feeling like a drink, I think it's worth it to just go inside and read up on the Beatnik generation and check out the cool old photos! :)
I absolutely LOVE the fact that there's a second level too! Best seat is right by the window! You get natural sunlight, plus watching all the tourists come by with their maps and cameras is pretty fun too!

Oh yeah, another plus is that you can bring your own lunch in! Really, it can't get much better than that! Drinks are waaay cheaper than if you had to buy a full-on meal too!

Definitely stop by! Feel the presence of the old Beat poets!
author: Kei H.

description:
You had me at hello.

So Vesuvio is tiny and narrow, and from the outside looks too swanky for your own good, but hands down one of the best places I've ended up in a long time. The cocktails are delicious, the music is pretty good, and if you're sitting upstairs on the balcony, people watching instantly becomes a favorite pastime. Also, they have waiter service and it seems like thats the preference if you're sitting upstairs, so go and squeeze yourself into a table or a booth if you can. Bathrooms are decently clean and honestly, its a pretty good place to start the night.

Cocktails are on average around the $7, jtlyk.
author: Jessica H.

description: Bartender overheard that I had a sweet tooth and immediately gave me a cup filled with starbursts and jelly beans. 1 star docked because there were no pink or red starbursts.
author: Claire S.

description:
I've avoided Vesuvio Cafe for the 2 years that I've lived up the street because, well, it's a tourist trap (or so I thought)!

When Victoria C. (& friends) texted to tell me to meet them there for post-Santacon drinks I was skeptical. 

I arrived to find a semi-crowded bar still filled with Santas (including myself) and a fun atmosphere. I searched everywhere for my friends before realizing there is an upstairs. This is where the bathrooms are too. 

Gin and Tonics were decently poured. The waitress was even nice enough to bring me 2! She noticed the first one she brought wasn't carbonated enough.

Not really my scene but I'll be back if friends want to go.
author: Sara P.

description:
I came back to this bar because it just defines San Francisco to me. 
To my surprise, I had to stop at the ladies' room and two people were going at it in the parlor. I tried to keep mum about it but when I asked for the men's bathroom, the owner made a big fuss. 
I was the talk of the afternoon. Definitely an experience I'll never forget. Afterward it prompted great conversation from many interesting people. This is definitely a Cheers-type bar if there ever was one.
author: Yvette C.

description:
A legendary watering hole on the border between Chinatown and North Beach. I lived in SF in the 80's and used to hang out here regularly. On my recent visit as a tourist, this was on my must-do list and it did not disappoint.

The energy of all those artsy beatniks still permeates the place and I always leave feeling cooler by association. So much to look at on the walls and in the faces of Vesuvio's chill clientel. Good drinks and an awesome atmosphere will always bring me back.
author: Sherry M.

description:
This bar has character. I also hear it's a frequent watering hole for all the ad agencies in the area. 

I don't know much about the arts, but apparently some famous writers and poets used to visit the place and become inspired. Next door is also some famous book store. A lot of people like to sit on the second floor for some cooler vibes. It looks like a coffee shop, but it's actually a bar.

I wish more places in SF had this type of atmosphere.
author: Paul B.

description:
This was where my beloved had arranged for us to reunite for the first part of our evening. I'd arrived early, a bit nervous (since the rest of the evening was a 'surprise') and upon not seeing my precious other-half, I grabbed a seat at the bar. 

I'm blaming my nervousness and hormones for my temper because when the bartender asked how I was doing, I unloaded. He, the sweet gentleman that he was, heard me out as I complained about how my date could leave me waiting like this. 

"What time was he supposed to meet you?"
"Seven"
"It's five-till. Are you usually late?"
"Yes" (how did he know?!)
"Well, there you go."

I didn't quite understand what he meant, but as he set my drink down he calmly explained, " He hasn't done anything wrong. It's not seven."

I paid, seethed a bit, and then realized that yes, I was being a bit unreasonable. The beer helped too, and by the time seven rolled around, my beloved arrived and ordered us a fresh round. I felt better and I shared a little smile with the nice but painfully honest bartender.

If you like wonderfully honest bar-people, wood, and cute little upstairs bathrooms- this makes for a nice spot to catch a drink and wait for your date.
author: Loli L.

description: Vesuvio is one of those places that just should never change. Full of history, art, funk, and true SF characters, this tiny place overflows with good vibes. Second floor is great for a view of Columbus but don't drink too much otherwise you won't make it down the spiral stairs. I wouldn't change a thing, not even the bathroom.
author: Matt A.

description:
2012 Drunkcathlon: San Fran Edition. Review #7

Drink requirement: Order 2 Jack Kerouacs

Just a cool spot that feels like a landmark. Friendly staff, great location surrounded by history.
author: Kaity J.

description:
Dark 'N' Stormy since 1948.

Last of three stops on a vintage North Beach bar crawl.

Immediately head to the second floor. Cross your fingers the table farthest to the back is free. Grab it and share the same space as Jack Kerouac.

Perhaps he also shared a love for rum and ginger beer. How could you not here. Expertly crafted and delivered right to your historic seat.

One. Make that two. Or was it three drinks later we were On The Road.

Foresee plenty more roads leading this way.

- - - - - - - - - -

Stop one: http://www.yelp.com/biz/tosca-cafe-san-francisco#hrid:PYSOiaiSg9sT9dqMOYzYNA

Stop two: http://www.yelp.com/biz/specs-twelve-adler-museum-cafe-san-francisco-2#hrid:Jj1moJ8MsbOT4OjqD2MYag
author: Jason B.

description:
North Beach First Friday ends, and the need for drinking still exists. So, to Vesuvio we go!

As I had previously only come here with ladyfriends, I had no idea of the mysteries and wonders that could be found in the men's bathroom. My manfriends returned to me with nothing other than a QUICKIE NOOKIE packet. It is for sale from a vending machine in the men's bathroom, at a cost of 25 cents each. It contains an "instant marriage license" and has a very high class lady on the cover. They also brought back another 25 cent gem, which is a book of sex positions. And let me tell you, it is a scintillating read indeed!

In case there aren't already reasons enough to love Vesuvio, there's another for you.
author: Vivienne P.

description: My very favorite bar in SF. I always take visitors here either right before or right after a stop at City Lights -- depending on whether I want to drunk-shop or drunk-read. Sitting upstairs overlooking Columbus Ave. is one of The City's sublime experiences. I wrote half a novella here once, over a week or two at a sunny upstairs table with a day drink. The hosts and hostesses never care how long I sit there and I appreciate that very much. Love this place.
author: T K.

description: I feel Beat! Love this place and come every time I'm in town. Great beer selection, service and happy hour till 7! Sit upstairs by the windows with a book from City Lights Bookstore and enjoy. There is history here.
author: Jim U.

description: A tour guide I had recommend this place. He said if you are into the 1950s and 60s there are pictures on the walls you will appreciate. There sure were pictures and I didn't know any of the people so perhaps that is true. The bar is cool though - especially upstairs! The low ceilings of the upstairs provides a cool atmosphere. Grab a window seat and enjoy looking down to the street and alley below. When we went the noise level was energetic and the place was busy, but turning over frequently enough so you could come in and find a seat right away. You could just sit down and one of the bartenders was going around taking orders and brining drinks.
author: Ben S.

description: I was in San Francisco a few weeks ago for to see the Giants/As play on the same weekend.  Great North Beach bar!! I love the decor and atmosphere of Vesuvio.  I also like the "old school projector" showing photos above the bar.  Awesome Vibe!!
author: Tony N.

description:
It's a bar. They had good jazz playing and the bar tender who looked like he was some sort of jock made an okay sazerac.
They have no parking lot.
author: Andy H.

description:
While walking the Barbary Coast trail in SF, we were led right up to the doorstep of Vesuvio.  Looked like a perfect time for a drink!

I'd been here years before, and really enjoyed the hip vibe.  It's a place steeped in history, and you can just feel it once you walk in.  The stained glass, the old wood...it's just a cool looking place!

We grabbed a couple of pints and just chilled, letting our feet take a rest.  Couldn't have asked for more!
author: Greg S.

description: Another local legend, and we know how I feel about those.  It's got a lot going for it in terms of history, but it's also been around long enough to become a sort of anti-tourist tourist trap.  The bands can be pretty dismal, and the crowds are often an alienating mix of noisy tourists and too-cool-for-school lookit-me locals.  On the other hand, you can spend hours just looking at all the art, ephemera, and relics of the various eras of SF's history.  The drinks menu isn't the most exciting, but everything is well made; it's not prominently advertised (you have to look over the menu at the end of the bar over the coffee brewer), but don't sleep on their wide and tasty collection of coffee cocktails, which goes way beyond your basic Irish.  The quintessential 'fun place to visit but you wouldn't want to live there' bar.
author: Leonard P.

description: My favorite place to hang out while visiting San Francisco. So much atmosphere and the staff is the best. Can't wait to wear my T-shirt I bought as a momentous.
author: Sandra S.

description:
Normally I only write about places I enjoy. However, the service at this place was so appalling I felt I needed to share.

I used to be a waitress and I understand that at table service bars you generally order from your server. However, on busy days, ordering at the bar is fine. For this reason I was left rather confused when our waitress became visibly upset with us for doing so. I'm not sure if this was because she  received a commission or something, but her treatment of my friends and I was despicable. She all but called us cheap, despite the fact we had a rather sizable bill. 

Take my advice, if you want good drinks and good service take your business elsewhere.
author: Elena B.

description: Good escape with tasty Guinness. Cocktails were fine for a reasonable price. Retro-hip atmosphere to grab a drink.
author: Drew B.

description: Heard great things about this place so we decided to stop by and have a drink. Unfortunately the bartender David (who has a big beard) was extremely rude. We are from Los Angeles and now have an awful perception of San Francisco thanks to him. We have never been treated so awful.
author: Yvette Marlene P.

description:
Up here at my second floor perch at Vesuvio, the table is too small and sticky for spreading out papers. The raucous conversation of the party of nine at the table beside me has crescendoed to hollering. And there's no wifi. In fact, my phone won't work at all.

But I am still writing. It feels like every word I write might have a breath of genius in it, like a beat poet's ghost might take me by the hand and help me along. I scribble madly. I drink cheap wine. I smirk at a bus load of tourists snapping pictures in the muraled alley below.

Vesuvio isn't just a good place to write. It is the place to write in San Francisco. Shake off that fear of artistic cliche, grab a pen and a tattered notebook, and show up for happy hour at 3pm on weekdays. I'll see you there.
author: Kristy L.

description: This place is generally packed to the brim with hipsters, and their drink list is fairly small and expensive. With Mr. Bing's, Buddha Lounge, and Li Po just around the corner, there are better places to go for an ordinary beer. Now, if they had their own brews, I'd be impressed, but just being somewhere that Kerouac and his buds kicked it doesn't do anything for me.
author: Danny C.

description: Great little hole in the wall bar in San Francisco! I wish I would have discovered it sooner, as it's such a unique place. We sat upstairs and had a few drinks with friends. It's not loud, which is so nice for a bar. It didn't seem to be overcrowded either, so that's always a bonus.
author: Shauna S.

description: Great service. Great drinks and food. Good deals on pitchers. Perfect place to start a night on the town or catch up with friends.
author: Phil D.

description:
Many a beat author, bohemian, wild child and booze hound has graced Vesuvio with their presence. But really, this is the kind of bar that can appeal to anyone with a personality. The large painted mural outside speaks to this point.

Upon entering, you'll find that style, charm and intrigue converge to make out a drinking den that is seemingly from another dimension. Open up your mind and figure out your life. Strike up a convo with a down-and-out hustler or a pretty lass who's new in town. It's one of the best places in the city to do this.

Highly recommended if you enjoy the mystique of beat literature, or just need a drink after walking all over Chinatown and North Beach. Definitely check out City Lights Bookstore next door as well.
author: Jeff O.

description: If I can give no stars I will. The waitress accused us of not paying our bills and then the bouncer accused us of smoking cigarettes. We all paid our bills and non of us smoke. These queries were asked of my friends and I but not of the rest of the people in the bar. What made us distinguishable? We were all Asian and African American.  I find the aforementioned a little suspect. What an unpleasant experience. An account of race or not the treatment that I received here was not only unnecessary but what we did got was uncalled to blame us for the smoke but not any other people in the club. Signed, an officer for the US government
author: Rafael A.

description: My experience there was super negative and far cry from the Best Bar In America TV show.  Don't believe what you see on TV...esp. anything positive about this bar that is a negative energy vortex.
author: Michael S.

description:
Stopped in on an early Thursday evening - not crowded...yet (something we discovered when we tried to return for a nightcap and could not wedge ourselves past the first few densely packed groups standing three deep).
Sitting at the bar ordered two drinks - one a No 209 gin and tonic an the other a martini.  The martini was meh with an old olive but the gin and tonic was fantastic.  Our bartender (sorry no name but awesome pink hair) was great - attentive and friendly.  Would stop by again but make sure to do so early to avoid the crowds.
author: Jo G.

description:
I love Vesuvio! The red tinted interior with upstairs seating overlooking the strip clubs. It has a lot of history, yes, but it also has fantastic drinks and interesting staff.

I always bring visitors to this part of town for the flavor.
author: Casey S.

description: A very cute and funky spot. I loved just looking around sipping on of their beers on tab.
author: Giacomo C.

description: I used to frequent Vesuvio's in the late 70s when I lived nearby on Broadway. It was the best. I came back decades later and there was a tv at the bar, blasting sports. What a sad change.
author: Nancy D.

description:
Any bar that Jack Kerouac frequented is a bar that is a favorite of mine. 

This isn't a hipster bar. It isn't a Marina bar. Don't really know how to describe it. It  falls into the nether regions of categorization. 

If you want a quirky bar to have a conversation with someone, definitely go upstairs. It's slightly claustrophobic but unline any bar I have been to in SF. 

It's mostly a beer bar it seems, but the irish coffee was popular at our table. 

The bar is on the small side so I don't know that I'd go in here with more than 8 people if you want to sit together. 

One of SF's gems. I'm a fan.
author: Carlos A.

description: Go in, take a photo and leave. Trust me you do not wanna deal with the clumsy and rude bartenders and waitresses. It's a wonderful spot just horribly managed.
author: Pedro P.

description:
If you're looking to drown your sorrows (but those resilient bastards know how to swim) go to Vesuvio and let some good feelins sink in.

Beat poet credibility, speakeasy aesthetic, 1920's porn, and 2 floors filled to the brim with drink and merriment.  A SF treat if I ever saw one.  

I even got a friendly history lesson there the other night after the jovial doorman overheard my outrage about the mosiac quote above the entrance, which says something like, "itching to get as far from Portland as possible."  I was all like, "How dare they speak of my beautiful hometown in that rude manner!  I feel most unwelcome!"  But, apparently during Lewis & Clark's expedition in the early 1800's (of what is now Washington and Oregon) they faced a series of unrelenting trials and obstacles, including rampant fleas.  So there you have it:  a proper PDX historical burn!  Fair enough!
author: Lauryn P.

description:
looking for absinthe? Looking for a place to grab a drink with friends while still carry on a conversation? Are you in the North Beach area? If you answered "yes!" to any of the above, then this is the spot for you!  

On a sidenote: the fact that Jack Kerouac spent time here is all you need to know and is a big reason why you should go!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Super kitschy decor, a smashing together of tables, decent bars on tap. All in all, a solid  bar. That said, not one of the best I've been to. 

Bathrooms are interesting upstairs, the bar tenders are on the hipster and I-only-work-here-so-I-can-get-my-spoken-word-workshop-going side of things. All in all, just fine.
author: Amanda B.

description:
No visit to San Francisco is complete without a trip to the legendary and still wonderful Vesuvio in North Beach. 

I'm not sure how much the place has changed since Kerouac and the boys were hangin' out here, but I have a feeling they'd still be right at home if they were to stumble in from the great beyond today. 

This place radiates authenticity, history, and character. The kind that can only be achieved over decades of good, simple service.
