There's bric-a-brac galore on the walls and shelves, but it's the furthest thing from the carefully planned randomness you'd find cluttering an Applebee's. What they have at Vesuvio seems like it's there because, well, shit just accumulates over the decades as a favorite gathering place of the people. 

The service is friendly and efficient, the prices more than reasonable, and the clientele diverse and interesting. 

As an added bonus, it's got one of the more unique men's rooms you'll find...down a low slung stairwell and into a doorless storage room with urinals seemingly interspersed with the empty kegs and boxes. Character is revealed in many ways. 

One of my favorite simple pleasures is ordering a stiff drink, then letting my eyes and imagination wander as I gaze around and listen to the place from a seat at the bar or the balcony. 

That gentle buzz comes over you and you just sort of blend into the glorious past of the venerable Vesuvio.
author: Alfredo M.

description: We all know its history, and it's a cool place to have a couple of drinks (especially on the second floor overlooking North Beach), but the drinks are atrocious. It's also pretty dirty, even by dive bar standards.
author: Bobby N.

description:
This place had such a great atmosphere. I felt like I was stepping into a different time. I came in here for a couple of drinks with friends and it was beautiful and everyone was really friendly (a rarity on weekends)

The staff was on point as well. They were fun and funky and above all, fast.
author: rebecca p.

description:
Kinda of a dive in North Beach with on Columbus.  Lots of stuff hanging from the walls for a super cluttered look.  Gives it character.  Like it's been here for many decades.  Decent service.  

Close to Portsmouth Square parking.

Not sure why they call it a "cafe".  No food here.
author: Doctor G.

description:
RECESSION SPECIAL! 4$ for a shot and a 10oz beer is my kind of deal. My friends and I experienced a pretty sloppy night because of it. Vesuvio has that neighborhood bar feel with nice folks and decently priced drinks. They also have absinthe which I have yet to try. 

Last night there was even a pop n lock dance battle right outside involving a bum and a man in a little league baseball uniform. Just another San Francisco night.
author: Calvin L.

description:
I had a really great time at Vesuvio's.  The atmosphere is great, the energy is great, the bartender is a kick, and the balcony, where you can look out at the people on the street or down into the bar, is really awesome.

The Wizard says; check it out.
author: Joe K.

description:
I love Vesuvio! 

I've always been curious about Vesuvio - passing by it, you see the peculiar looking second floor and think, "hmm... what an interesting looking place." A few months ago, my girlfriends and I were bar crawling the North Beach area for a birthday. One of our stops was Vesuvio since one of the girls had been before. My first experience was okay since it was really crowded and we didn't stay longer than the time to have one drink. 

However, this past Saturday I returned and around 12:45AM, we were lucky and the back of the upstairs balcony area had open tables. One of my best girlfriends and I (and her sister) took a window table and chatted over a couple drinks till they closed. If you can get a good seat and have a few drinks here, Vesuvio is amazing. Very laidback and unique place - it's got a vibrant environment, yet you can still carry on a conversation perfectly without having to hunch over and yell. 

If you don't mind the occasional smell that this place has, you're in for great & cheap (YES!) drinks, friendly service, and a unique environment to sip and enjoy the night away.
author: Tiffany K.

description: Down the cutest little alley with poems and phrases imprinted in the cement from the people who made The Vesuvio, on the corner across from the bookstore,  is this great bar. Beyond the history of the place, it was cozy, welcoming and had great drinks. You're sure to get that local feel that SF is about.
author: Laura B.

description:
What a great place to hang out at night!! The look is of an old pub that hasn't changed over the years. Totally love the old time décor & chill vibe of the place. Came  late on a Saturday night and we lucked out with the last few seats at the bar. Great selection of beers & they could make about any drink we thought of...they have absinthe which is pretty cool for those of my buddies who like it. They do not skimp out on the alcohol & the beer selection is good enough. I had two and was definitely feeling it afterwards!! The bartender was awesome - fast to acknowledge us and get our drinks. Oh, and the drinks are not overpriced...score!!

The crowd was loud & having a good time but wasn't so loud that I had to yell to be heard - plus point for sure. There is an upstairs area where you can sit/lounge in wicker chairs and such and people watch below - a favorite pastime when in North Beach. Definitely will come back to this watering hole my next visit...
author: Jessica S.

description:
Great atmosphere, super cheap drinks and a WIDE variety of people to interest you here. You can taste, smell and see a part of the literary and cultural history of the beatnik generation poets here as you enjoy your tasty beverages. I imagined myself sitting where Ginsberg had sat many moons before me and certainly howled like Kerouac as the night progressed. 
 
The place was absolutely wall to wall people on a Saturday night so this probably isn't the place if you are impatient about sitting down and looking for a quiet place although we eventually got an awesome spot upstairs looking over the entire bar, where we could hear each other just fine.

Been to the city more times than I can count on mine and yours and the person sitting next to you's fingers and toes but never went here, I feel like all my trips were sort of missing something. I plan to start a new count involving this place as I think it would somehow fill the void. The past meets the present in this bar and I plan to enjoy it well in the future.
author: Robert H.

description:
My favorite bar in San Francisco. I work in the FiDi, so I'm close enough that I can come here several times a week; sometimes for lunch, sometimes after work. They always have good music going, no matter what the genre. Seating is plentiful, I've been there at many different hours of the day and I've never not gotten a seat. They don't serve food, but you're more than welcome to bring your lunch/dinner along with you.

There's always good people-watching here, you're practically on the corner of Broadway/Columbus, which is the heart of North Beach. You get a healthy balance of locals, tourists, super nice people, suits and complete whack jobs. Vesuvio is mentioned in a lot of tourist guides, so this is definitely a destination spot for people who are visiting San Francisco.

Lastly, they have one of the best deals I've seen in any bar, anywhere: the Recession Special. The Recession Special is a shot of whiskey (Old Crow) and a glass of beer (Bud) for $4. I know, I know, I've heard the arguments and seen the faces; Old Crow and Bud? Gross! And yes, those aren't usually my first choices...but, for $4, I'm not gonna complain very much, if at all. Seriously, you guys, the Recession Special; ask for it by name.
author: J N.

description: I love this place, I always bring visitors by when I take them on a "tour" of the city. It's full of history, be sure to take some time to check out the amazing memorabilia hanging on the walls. Then grab your drink/beer and head upstairs for a nice plerch to people watch.
author: Andrea J.

description:
This tiny little bar is cute.  I don't know much about the famous author that frequented here but I suppose it's good to know it was there then and it is here now.  I went here during the day.  The tables are tiny but you can fit a group of 9 here at this time, perhaps at night...not so much.

The server was nice but she wasn't as attentive as most bars.  

Cool place to hang out.  On the border of Little Italy and Chinatown.  Cute decor inside.  Very eclectic.
author: Lauren T.

description: Visiting out of town from Miami looked up bars in the area and this one stood out. Man I'm glad I found this place. Strong drinks cheap prices. Johnny Yelp knows how to make an amazing Absinthe. Next time you go ask for Johnny Yelp on a Sunday. He will take care of you. I look forward to coming back to the city just to have a drink at Visuzio once again. Thank you for the great time.
author: Patrick C.

description: It's sensory overload and I love it! I just had a beer after visiting the bookstore next door. The waitress was friendly and it's a great place to get a drink, people watch from the windows upstairs. It was cheap, low key and awesome.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Walked in to a very eclectic collection of memorabilia on the walls of pretty much everything! Posters to trinkets to mini statues to signs. There was so much going on, but somehow it all worked :)

Cool, cool bar to hang out at and watch games going on with no pressure to chug chug chug and rush out. It was very laid back and they didnt have just bar seating, but also tables with semi-comfy couches and and upstairs area with more seating that over looks the bar area! They also had a "waitress" come around to see if we needed more drinks. Nice.
author: Ling H.

description:
This used to be one of my favorite bars in North Beach when I lived in SF. Every time I visited, I would go here. My hubs and I were visiting last week and decided to go for a beer on a rainy afternoon. Still love the space - kind of divey and good people watching both in the bar and on the street. The bartender was super friendly. 

I had always remembered this place as having a good selection of beer on tap (i'm a beer snob) but this was not the case (at least for me). For Hefeweizenr, they had Widmer (blah!) Why not a Franziskaner or Hoegarten? Or even a Great White? They also offer a small selection  of special "microbrews". So maybe you would think to see something from Deschutes Brewery or some crazy good beer like Hitachimo Nest. But that is not the case - the selection included Fat Tire and Blue Moon. Are these really considered MIcrobrews? Blue Moon isn't a horrible beer but I wouldn't consider this a special mircrobrew either - it's brewed by Coors! 

Anyway, I figured I would stick with a classic Stella that was on tap and the hubs ordered a Guinness.  My Stella was so horribly flat, I couldn't even drink it and my hubs Guinness wasn't very fresh. The bartender didn't charge us for the Stella, which was nice but she could see I didn't drink it. 

While we were sitting at Vesuvio, we yelped other bars in the area and thankfully found a much better place to enjoy some real beer (the Columbus Cafe). Vesuvio does had a nice vibe to it, but it's not a very good beer bar.
author: Betsy R.

description:
Came here for the first time on our last trip to San Francisco. The sign outside is interesting enough to check it out. 
Walking in I loved the look of it, lots of interesting things. We weren't there for that long but in that time two guys tried to pick up on my Hubby, pretty funny, I saw sex toy machines in the bathroom, and saw the cool view from the upstairs. It's in a neighborhood we frequent so I'm sure we'll be back.
author: Roxanne R.

description: Beautiful, quirky place with a great atmosphere to get a drink. This aside from the fact that there's so much history. A must try, for sure!
author: Paloma D.

description: Vesuvio's is a classic must visit bar in San Fran. Whenever I visit the City, I always meet my friends there to start our adventures. This trip I had the Moscow Mule. Although the copper cup was missing, the flavor wasn't. The ginger beer was more mild that I'm used to, but the cocktail was well put together and enjoyable.
author: Roger T.

description:
Yeah, another of those establishments that is a San Francisco monument.

I'd been to this bar a few times before I lived in SF which led me to believe the entire city was paved with seedy strip clubs and awesome bars (well one out of two ain't bad).  I'm not sure what it is but this bar has incredible ambiance.  Drinking upstairs is probably one of my favorite things to do here as it feels like you have your own private corner but are still in a bar.  If you're not engaging in conversation then it's still fun to go upstairs, pack your friends in a booth and people watch from above.

The beer selection is pretty average but there's typically at least one or two things that are decent and you can always get a Bohemian Coffee or something else you might not try.  

Great place to stop if you're in the hood.  Bring a friend.
author: Steven R.

description:
Vesuvio is a place to go for some drinks and conversation and a must if you're in North Beach. It's got character and good drinks (I suggest trying the dark and stormy!). 
It's not a place known for the most amazing service but when you have good friends and good drinks then it's bound to be a great time!
author: Marlyn F.

description: This was one of our stops on our own self-guided So I Married An Axe Murderer tour. LOVED this place. We got a great seat for two upstairs right in the cozy little nook by the window. Spent a couple hours here, just savoring the scene, making a memory. The waitress had us pay upon serving our first drinks, which I thought was a little unusual, but they probably want people to have a drink and then make room for other customers. We stayed a long time, though and had another couple drinks. REALLY cool place and I would definitely go back. Seemed like it had a lot of history and had seen a lot of cool happenings.
author: Amy M.

description:
I went here to see Jack Kerouac's old haunt, because it was next to the City Light bookstore, because it was used as a front for So I Married an Axe Murderer, and because I was thirsty.

The bartender was friendly and helpful, the patrons were varied and relaxed, the bar was beautiful and homey.  

Enjoy this bar!
author: Holly S.

description: I wish I could pack up this cafe and bring it back to NYC with me. My friend and I thought it was so cute! Atmosphere was super laid back. We drank there two different nights. First at the bar and second upstairs. Love this place! Friendly staff!
author: Lindsey G.

description:
Kimono shopping can be stressful. Haggling with shop owners and elbowing your way through an aggressive Chinatown crowd in search of the perfect dragon printed lounge wear calls for a stiff drink at the end of an adventure that left my jacket smelling of dried fish and pork buns. (on a side note, why the hell is that Golden Gate bakery that has those awesome egg tarts never open?!!? Those people vacation like ten months a year) 

When me and my lovely date neared the end of the Grant strip we were parched and in need of unwinding. Just down the alley and across the border that separates Italy from China we wandered into Vesuvio for said libations. I have been hammered here a few times and whilst this visit was merely a pit stop I can enjoy the ambiance just the same. 

My bronzed and smooth skinned date seldom drinks so I was pleasantly surprised that she was happy to down a few Tipsy Arnold Palmers with me. The drinks came in handy to lighten the mood since our server was apparently too busy gossiping with the bartender to remember she was at work. Numerous folks walked in and sat down only to be ignored for ten minutes before exiting. I think more people left than actually got served that day. We joked when a group went upstairs to the balcony seating since we knew that they were going to be waiting a while but they did have great bleacher seats to watch others drinking below. It was like they came in just to cheer us on while we got served....when we eventually did. Thanks to my beautiful company and her soothing nature, I was able to look at the service failure with a humorous twist. Then again, when does a gorgeous woman not put a man at ease? 

Love the decor and this spot is typically a good crowd but I will be sure to order from the bar next time I see our part time waitress on shift.
author: Dru P.

description: Great eclectic bar. Felt like we were walking into a time warp. Easy no frills drink.
author: Judy V.

description:
The 5th hole for my friend's birthday bar crawl, home to an eclectic decor and clutterness that managed to still feel homely and comfortable, but chalk full of local history...  According to the drunk college guy that sat in my seat 30 seconds after I vacated it, to go to the bar and order a round of drinks for the birthday girl, apparently he told them all about the local history of Jack Kerouac, history of San Francisco and asked for a few numbers while he was at it.  I returned with one of their signature drinks, the appropriately named Jack Kerouac, not to sure what was in it but damn good.  Fun atmosphere here, nice service from our hostess and plenty of seating as well, I didn't even notice the upper level until we were moving on to the next bar.  Ill be back...

Here's a way to track where we've been and we're were going...
http://www.yelp.com/list/lillians-birthday-crawl-san-francisco
author: Chris T.

description: I love this place.  Sitting upstairs with the windows open people watching on a nice day can't be beat.  The crowd is usually eclectic and usually well-spoken, but not too hipster.  The bar is great, service is usually very good and the prices are average for the area.
author: Daniel W.

description: Love Vesuvio always check it out when I am in town. Great throw back classic vib. Just makes me think of what the city was like back in the day. Great place to chill and have a few beers while soaking in the eclectic set up. Plenty of room to sit for a while in a great neighborhood.
author: Rob D.

description:
I came here while on vacation. I was told we were going to a bar in North Beach on the Fourth of July. So I'm picturing an open air bar by the beach with a view of the water and fireworks. Where's the beach in North Beach? You San Franciscan's are cruel jokesters. Sort of like when I asked where the historic mission is in the Mission District.

Despite ending up in a windowless dive bar instead a lounge with a beach front view, this is a cool place where I enjoyed a whiskey sour and could see and hear the walls telling stories. It was a good crowd except for one loud group of pontificating 20some's who voiced plenty of information to the entire bar - giving credence that our school system and expensive college degrees aren't fully working. I guess they haven't learned that if you're going to be loud in a good dive bar, you must be interesting, eclectic, and upbeat. If that's not you, then shut it and enjoy the ambiance.
author: Brian U.

description:
Great bar with all your favourite drinks. comfortable nooks and seating. two levels with a balcony overlooking the bar.  a really down to earth bar that is a great stop before you go to the Saloon for some great live music.

 definately take visitors here as it next to City Lights Books and if they have read or are interested in the beat generation then they already have heard of this bar.
author: Brett R.

description: I like Vesuvio's. The ambience, the décor, the alcohol. It's simple and not, all rolled into one. If you are in SF and want to get a drink then come to Vesuvio. They have all kinds of beer and drinks. My fave is the Pimm's cup. I am a sucker for Pimm's since you can't get it everywhere and Vesuvio makes a good Pimm's drink. The service is typical SF service - here's your menu, what do you want, here you go, here's your bill, bye. But ehhh whatever that's SF and that's why you love it....some days. Also, sit upstairs. It's just funner (I know that's not a word, but it fits this review) that way.
author: Carina R.

description:
Great Spot, Love the decor.  Super Chill.
Get the Pitchers - $11, $14 and $17.
author: Oriana C.

description: I'd give it a 5 stars but the bar tender was kind of being rude for no reason. Maybe it was a bad night but either way it affected me. Cool vibe otherwise, it looks very old. The decorations are pretty awesome. It's probable this place has been around for a century.
author: Daniel F.

description:
To me - Vesuvio represents San Francisco.  It was one of the first places I discovered when moving to SF.  Yet despite so many places to go, I still grab a drink there everytime I'm in Northbeach.  

Vesuvio has a nostalgic - classic feel to it without being a grandpa bar.  It captures the history of an ageless San Francisco bar in a way no bar does.  The yellow colors always warm you up and the artwork makes you think of what it was like.
With all of the bars today trying to look 'classic', this bar actually has it.

If you're in the area, stop by.
author: Shawn M.

description: Great atmosphere and great array of drinks! Have to grab a seat on the second floor and admire the decor.
author: Chrissie W.

description:
Only thing I will complain about this place is the temperature.

With that said, this place is super cool! Super divey but old school divey with old pictures and vintage stuff. Plus they have Absinthe, can't complain! Although this absinthe isn't the best I've had that's for sure. I like bringing my friends here and getting drinks. 

Love it! But careful of tourists!!
author: Ezequiel R.

description: This place is awesome. Such a great vibe, and looks like the place has a lot of history. Bartender was nice and met some good people there
author: Kalani M.

description:
Came in on a Sunday afternoon - the place was pretty empty.  We were hanging out in the city and it looked like a neat place to grab a drink.  I was driving (eventually) so I just had a small beer and my partner had a martini.

EEK - there was a hair in the martini (on the olives).  

So yeah - a neat looking place filled with newspaper clippings about itself on the wall.  Sure the people watching is good: hipster kids coming in to sit in Kerouac's chair, strange (drunk?) people yelling to themselves...  The drink prices aren't bad, but the cleanliness fail is a dealbreaker for me.
author: Nicole A.

description: This is going to be a barebones review. My cousins and I stopped by here after the Cigar Bar. They wanted to take me here because it's one of only a handful of places (according to them) that serve Absinthe. We took our shots and continued on with our night.
author: Paolo D.

description:
Stopped here on a bar crawl with some friends and thoroughly enjoyed it. Vesuvio has a great vibe, very cozy and welcoming. We sat upstairs and had some beers and Irish coffee while watching the tourists come and go taking photos of the murals on the walls outside, certainly a good place for people watching. Our waitress was friendly and brought our drinks very quickly.
Possibly the best part were the sex toy machines in the ladies room, for 75¢ you too could keel over in semi-drunken laughter at the tiny cardboard packages filled with mystery items, ours included a cock ring and a rubber finger teaser that looked like a single rubber glove finger with some nubbins on the tip, a bit like a roosters comb. Awesome. Post our sex toy photo shoot we were on our way. I will definitely be returning next time I am in the area though.
author: Allie H.

description:
Next door to City Lights but away from the North Beach chaos, perfect place to chill with friends. Stake a table on the second floor and enjoy the people watching along the streets. A gamut of interesting characters stroll by, from the typical tourist to the trendy Euro to the antedivuian goth...
Great drinks, great service and lives up to the historic eclectic Beat ambiance and of course good old Jack Kerouac's hang out. Good place for locals and off the beaten path visitors.
author: Naomi K.

description:
Don't miss Vesuvio! Had a wonderful, blessed time in the city today, partly because of my experience this morning after coffee in North Beach! 

It was early and my autistic son had to go to the bathroom. You know how it is: he had to go immediately! Apparently liberals in S.F. don't use the bathroom? (hee hee, just kidding!) We had a heck of a time finding somewhere to go. We walked into the closest establishment with a bathroom thinking they wouldn't let my son in, since it was a bar, but the charming woman stopped her talk (or tour?) with another couple to show us the way upstairs. My husband said that while we were in there, she was explaining what all the hoopla about this bar was about. I can't say I was familiar with it at all. When we came out, she offered to show us around and suggested we take a few pictures. I'm so glad I did! She was so interesting and polite to give us a guided tour of this local landmark. 

I will post my photos on my family activity site as a must-see place for tourists!!! 

Afterward she offered to let us get a beer since it was so warm out. Phew! Best beer ever! She even gave my son a bowl of maraschino cherries. Lots of smiles leaving this place! Fourth of July crowd, check this out as a stop if you're around North Beach, and don't forget to take some photos of the memorabilia inside!
author: Amy S.

description: This place is great! Great vibe! A place to really have a great time with a group of friends and have some tasty beverages. North Beach is my favorite part of SF and this is one of its gems, best one I've been to yet.
author: Mark C.

description: really liked this place! went here as part of a bar crawl, so don't let the name fool you into thinking it's a typical cafe ;). it was fun sitting at the top if you want a slightly quieter atmosphere for talking with your friends, but you can still see the activity going on downstairs. cute little place with friendly service and good drinks. the decor is probably something i'd call pub-y, but it was a bit bizarre too (in a good way!)
author: Bianca C.

description:
Now I've never heard of this place before going but I've been to places like it all over. The kind of place intellectuals from history spent their days readings and drinking. Where the atmosphere defined a generation. This place fits that mold to the tooth and is an inspiration to boot. Came through on a Tuesday night so not crowded by any means. From the outside the stain glass windows backlit with the name are pretty ole timey but appropriate and draw you right inside. There are little seating nooks and old art and books and posters and ancient chandeliers everywhere. This place is well known for being a haunt of jack Kerouac and the like and it's obvious why. The bar still has a drink named after him that's rum tequila orange juice and cranberry juice. Not a bad drink, but not too strong either. Don't expect to be getting drunk on their cocktails here. They're more for the habit not to mess you up. There's always someone there drinking an IPA and reading philosophy in the corner and with just the right noir lighting overhead. There's an upstairs which looks over the whole interior that is pretty awesome and has windows so u can watch over the city all the strip clubs and bar surrounding the area. 

The drinks in this place aren't moderate in terms of price. Most cocktails being 7$ and beers around 5$. The cocktails aren't strong. But you can't go wrong with a 5$ beer. They even have a "recession" special that's a shot and a beer for 6$. The bartender was prob a nice guy but I didn't talk to him. The woman sorta serving was really friendly though and brought our drinks to the table and everything. Pretty chill. 

The only downside to this place is the location. Not like proximity to other stuff just being over in north beach. It's like so far from where I normally spend time in sf that it's a serious trek to get over there and parking isn't too fun either. There's a lot of cool places around that I want to check out as well when I have more money and better drinking habits.

Anyways highly recommend this place. It's not touristy and it has the vibe that the same type of people are still coming here since back in the day.
author: Harrison M.

description: love this two floor seating bar with all the italian food places nearby. Love the gritty feeling that writers practically lived there for centuries before moving on to another bar. A must for anyone in the neighborhood.
author: Carolina S.

description:
I like Vesuvio... we came for a bachelor party this time

drinks are good, ambiance is good... nice place to hang out
author: Aarash Z.

description:
Definitely my favorite place in North Beach to hangout and talk with tourists visiting San Francisco.  Vesuvio is a SF landmark, as it should be.  It was a haunt by Jack Kerouac and was used as the background for a certain Mike Myers movie I care not to disclose.

The bar is cool.  It host an eclectic crowd:  your locals, the tourists, couples, groups, singles, really cool people, pompous know-it-alls, and your occasional clubber gone astray.  Diversity is what makes San Francisco tick, and it's what makes Vesuvio tick.

As you enter the bar, in a corner entrance, you can see that Vesuvio doesn't offer much to please the eyes, but it offers history and an aura not easily found in other establishments.  The barkeeps are usually cool and fast.  I usually like to order my drink from them and head off upstairs if the downstairs area is too packed.  There's someone that can take your order upstairs, but it's preference over convenience for me...I just don't like anyone spilling a drop of my precious nectar through the narrow staircase.

Vesuvio is definitely a must go for anyone visiting San Francisco for the first time.  I'll see you tourists around...
author: Jules S.

description:
Isn't this name hot? Doesn't this name turn you on? Well, the place itself is nothing like the name sounds, at least to me. That's not to say it isn't hot or that I didn't get very turned on in here. Hello - two big hells to the yeah on that! 

This place feels like what it is, an old saloon that has barely been updated enough to keep up with code. It also feels like you need to carry a couple of pistols in your holster and kick someone's ass all the way across the bar before you order a drink.  Lots of variety in drink and really cool wait-staff/bartenders are to be found in here. The crowd is nicely mixed in both age and in other notable and entertaining areas.  It was pretty much standing room only when we were doin' our thang (not good for the 1 armed 1 toilet-ed upstairs in-the-attic bathroom though). 

Soooo, do yer thang in here - you even have large windows to see out in the alley to watch the group of occasional bongers. You can also admire the homeless guy with his yoga mat while you talk shit and realize there's a severely twisted sexual odyssey of a mural disguised to look like a farm on the building across said alley. 

If this were in Austin, this would be Keepin' Austin Weird.
author: Snuggly G.

description:
Next door to City Books.  A classic bar that is also steeped in history.  It has amazing character and characters!  We sat on the balcony.  They had an OK beer selection and the waitress was pretty timely.  But, it's wasn't so clean (no table wipe-downs or napkins or coasters) and could have used an open window or two for an airing out.  

That said, the mood of the Vesuvio is one-of-a-kind.  A definite Beatnik experience. Wished I could have given a 3.5 star rating for the lack of cleaing.  But, given their place in history, they get a 4 star.
author: Tony S.

description:
Guitar playing duo out front singing in the alley....thank you to you. Classic place for Beat worshipers to gravitate to but also a really frickin cool bar. My BF who could give a hoot less about the literary significance of this place declared it "pretty fu*&ing cool. If I lived here, I'd drink here". I consider that pretty high praise from a man who hails from Bandera, Texas, the Cowboy Capitol of the World. I'm just sayin....

The barkeeps make a tasty drink and the service is top notch. I'm glad they don't do kitschy Kerouc inspired drinks. Maintaining the divey awesome-ness is what it's all about yo. 

I feel like I should write a haiku but I'm not that talented or douchey. Or maybe I am since I considered it.
author: Theresa H.

description: Historic, cool and crowded bar. Getting a booth is difficult. The bartenders are attentive and friendly.Drinks are relatively strong
author: Astha S.

description: Great spot for unique cocktails after a trip to City Lights. I had the Bohemian Coffee. Yum :)
author: Kaili K.

description:
I really liked the whole look of this place! Everybody seemed to be having fun and I liked how the upstairs area was nice a cozy. There were some booths there if you have a small group of friends. Cool bar.

Also, upstairs is perfect for people watching out onto the street or even downstairs in the bar.
author: Sandra N.

description:
Cats, I was "On the Road" with one thing in mind: Visit the infamous bar frequented by beat poet Jack Kerouac. Diggin' it?  

Beat poets and followers have paid many visits to Vesuvio for decades. This queen was in the city alone and decided to pay tribute to a destination that an influential generation of writers visited.

Once inside and comfortable with a beer,surrounded by friendly patrons/bartenders, I noticed the following: A good number of beer on tap, red stools, scattered tables, a tv, artsy-ness, and an upstairs area. I came in for a beer but drank 2 frothy Guinness' --all served by an extremely cool (very beat) bartender. Bread and visa/mc is accepted, though there is a $10 minimum.

The men and women who were sitting with me at the bar were outgoing, but I have a feeling that it had to do with the stiff drinks they were telling me about. Within an hour and a half, we had a hard spiel on LA, San Francisco, music, traveling, careers, food, life, and ended it with a debate on The Beatles and Pearl Jam. One of the drunker men mentioned that Pearl Jam has much more of an influence on music than The Beatles ever did. Again, he was drunk, so I discredited everything he said, but not before I picked his brain. At the end of the day, it was all for kicks. 

This joint delivers on all levels of hip, which is obvious why beat poets drank here in the 50's and 60's. I finaled back to the east bay content with beers and knowing that I drank under the roof that Jack Kerouac and Dean Moriarty did 50+ years ago. Vesuvio is definitely a groovy bar that left me feeling fresh and copacetic.
author: J J.

description:
This place definitely lives up to the hype. After having it on my list for quite some time, I finally got around to checking it out last night. A girl pal of mine and I took a walk to North Beach, did some browsing at City Lights Books, and then strolled in for a drink or two. 

I have to say from the minute I walked in, I completely loved the place. It had plenty of seating, a good vibe, and the decor was pretty artsy fartsy cool. We decided to head upstairs and chose a seat overlooking the bar, on the side across from a huge, colorful mural. I'm not sure there is a bad seat here, but we liked ours. 

We were pleasantly surprised to locate drink menus and also to find we were greeted by a waitress. At that point we weren't sure if there would be service upstairs. She was patient and super sweet in explaining the specials and showing us the beer selection listed on the wall behind us. 

We decided on 21st Amendment Watermelon Wheat Beer -- delish! I'm so glad my friend recommended it since I've been homesick for my Abita Purple Haze and Strawberry Harvest (New Orleans beers that were much more accessible in Houston than in the Bay Area for obvious reasons). At only $5 a beer, I was happy with that. 

We stayed and chill for a couple while light jazz music played in the background. Good times were had by all. 

The Verdict: I will be a regular here, oh yes. I will be a regular.
author: Cara S.

description: This place is like groovy man ya know what I mean? It's the coolest. Step into to Vesuvio's and take a trip back to the 50s it hasn't changed much since then. Except for the addition of a color tv. They are still playing some of the same music on the radio here. If you drink enough maybe you can hallucinate up a few beat-niks to make your experience complete. Good drinks and a great place to people watch. As I left I spilled some liquor on the floor....And the liquor was spilt on the barroom floor and the bar was closed for the night. when out from the corner came a little white mouse, to bask in the pale moonlight. And he lapped up the liquor on the barroom floor ,and back on his haunches he sat. And for the rest of the night you could hear him roar...Bring on the G...D... Cat.
author: Ron W.

description: best gin mules ever. now if only I can go drinking with someone who can keep up with me... they need to serve food here for the lightweights. just one thing, done really well. would be so appreciated. I'm thinking....Belgian fries...no...dutch babies?
author: Viv R.

description:
Once upon a time, I loved this place.  

Sadly, my love affair ended Saturday.  Seemed everyone that works there was in a bad mood.  The waitress ignored us, the bartender seemed put out when asked for a cocktail. 

Oh Vesuvio - breaking up is hard to do ....
author: brandie y.

description:
Everything a great bar should have: good beer, great wall art and an amazing space within local history. Cozy without being schleppy, kitschy without being cliche. 

Best of all bar worlds.
author: Jeska D.

description: Really cute little bar, one of the oldest in the city. A lot of charm in there. Bar tenders are very nice and friendly. I like this place !
author: Marion P.

description:
Bummer. I really hate dropping the one star bomb. I really do. But, I don't really have a choice after the inexplicably rude and offensive service we received for no apparent reason. 

Was having a great time watching the 4th of July fireworks on a rooftop in the FiDi, and decided to pop into one of the neighborhood bars for a couple beers to celebrate. 

Walking up Columbus, we decided to poke our heads into Vesuvio, which somehow as a native San Franciscan I had never gone to before. 

A tall, dirty,bearded bouncer in a hooded sweatshirt abruptly stops our entrance and demands to see IDs. Fair enough. My buddy pulls out his, and the bouncer grabs it and coughs all over it. Nervously, my friend starts laughing, to which the bouncer threateningly responds "what are you laughing at"? My friend takes back his ID and walks in. Then it's my turn. Guy grabs my ID, looks at it, and throws it to the floor, staring back at me. I bend over and grab it and walk in, at first thinking this was just part of the hipster "schtick" until I realized this guy was just being a prck for no reason whatsoever. 

I bring up our experience to our waitress, who agrees that that is inexcusable behavior, but no one in the bar offers us an apology or any sort of explanation of why we were treated so disrespectfully.

Bottom line: avoid this place like the plague. There are wayyyyyy better bars in North Beach that care about their customers and their business. Also, I just hope someone who is less friendly and tolerant than me doesn't run into that bouncer and kick his teeth in next time. Good riddance.
author: Patrick G.

description:
The last time I came here, there was no yelp. Yes, it's been that long. I think it was back in 2004. Well, the place hasn't changed a bit from what I can remember. I wonder how much it has changed since Jack Kerouac's time? 

So, I brought my girlfriend here the other night after hanging out in North Beach all day. She had never been. It was fun. A nice bar to hang in. I like to sit upstairs and watch all the people in the bar down below, and watch all the crazy local bums and prostitutes outside on the streets. This place is great for people-watching!! 

If you are in North Beach, stopping by Vesuvio for a drink is a must.
author: Knud P.

description: Great Northbeach dive bar. Larger on the inside than it looks from the outside. Decent happy hour. Very much a neighborhood hangout. There is an upstairs area to sit with friends. Lots of memorabilia to look at around the bar. Pretty dead during the day but packs in quickly across the night.
author: Silicon W.

description:
For what it's worth, the look of the place is really cool.  One major problem, the place reeked of sweat and urine!  It completely ruined the experience.  I felt like I spent more time trying not to vomit than I did enjoying the drinks and the rest of the space.

Need I say more??  No urge to go here again until they give it a quality spring cleaning.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Most obnoxious bar man I have ever met ( the guy who looks like a LMFAO reject) can't believe he's allowed work there.
Ill never set foot into that bar again.
author: Garrett D.

description:
Despite at times being packed with picture taking tourists, this is still one of my favorite bars in North Beach.

Come in the afternoon and find a seat at the bar next to some of the regulars. Have a conversation with the bartenders who can tell you about SF history and the history of Vesuvio which has been pouring drinks since the 1940's. Artists and writers are tucked away in the nooks, paintings are on the walls, jazz is playing from the speakers, and the drink prices are still reasonable. Great place to sit back, relax, and meet some eccentric characters.
author: T.C. J.

description: Bartender slightly impatient and rude. Love the layout, with tables on top overlooking the bar area/streets. I wouldn't call this a lounge by any means, though.
author: Amanda V.

description: Stopped by here one night for a happy hour with some coworkers. I ended up getting asked to leave, kind of a long story, the bar tender was kind of a jerk and didn't like that I hated LeBron James. Anyway, the drinks are good and reasonably priced and the bouncer was very nice.
author: Stephanie T.

description:
This place is steeped in history and style. Essentially, it's a historical place that has not lost its charm, so 5 stars. 

It gets crowded on the weekends, so if you can find a table, grab it. This is one of those places I invariably seem to end up at when I have people visiting town.
author: Ken L.

description: We came in around 9 or 10 o clock and the place was pretty crowded, but we found a table upstairs with a great view of the street. They had a great special that included a shot of bourbon and a glass of bud for $5. The staff was attentive, the drinks were made right, and the atmosphere  of the bar was just about unbeatable.
author: Kevin B.

description: I had a really good time there, the place has a lot of character. Good beers, good music!
author: Cecile M.

description:
Stopping here has become a tradition for my wife and I every time we visit SF. We go upstairs to the balcony, I always get a bloody mary, we look out the windows and get nostalgic for when we lived in the city. I look around and seep up the history, watch the bustling in N. Beach. This is a real SF treasure and it never changes, which is a good thing.

Oh, i just noticed my profile pic happens to be of this very experience.
author: Roger a.

description:
One star for nostalgia's sake. 

Vesuvio's one of the many spots I drank while underage with my British colleagues (The Guardian UK rated Vesuvio the third best bar in the world) back when Pets.com and Webvan were flush with venture funding. I remember being so tired one night here that I actually rested my head on my arm at the bar. And they STILL didn't card me!

FAST FORWARD TO 2007:
Came to Vesuvio for a nightcap after a work dinner recently (Bailey's on the rocks, for me,  if you must know) and was reminded what a charming old place it really is.
author: Miriam W.

description:
If you get a server named Katie or Katy or however you spell her name, run out. She has a short haircut and a combover, probably 5'9" or so. She is a mean girl. Not nice at all. And when confronted about her poor service, she said, "You're at Vesuvio." Oh man, someone who works in the service industry is validating her poor service. This is supposed to be the bar where beat was invented. It's hard to believe that Beatniks shouldn't care about good service I guess... ??? No thanks. She needs to step off your pedestal and smile a little.  

Katy, who was the face of the bar -- her personality was rancid. Ergo, this bar is rancid. I will not be going here again. Thanks, Katy/Katie/Kati for a most welcoming experience.

Katie, my lady. You were no lady this Saturday night. May I suggest the following: http://www.elegantwoman.org/how-to-be-a-lady.html

Read here for similar experiences: 
1/ http://www.yelp.com/biz/vesuvio-cafe-san-francisco#hrid:CInu4mHNOCaP5KiO1cr5gA
2/ http://www.yelp.com/biz/vesuvio-cafe-san-francisco#hrid:UnSD5dOjRmtJBodzUrjqlw
3 http://www.yelp.com/biz/vesuvio-cafe-san-francisco#hrid:oMBn2BR0kOf72W3MWC0kLA
author: Edmarc H.

description:
So, our plan was to go to Bubble Lounge and Kells right down the street but that didn't happen so we stumbled upon this place. It was very low key but it was a Monday night so I wasn't expecting anything else. 
It's a narrow bar with a bunch of little tables with a second floor. 
It's a cute place to go to hang out and chit chat with some friends.
I have no idea how busy it is on a friday but its a very unique bar and very north beach.
The drinks were really yummy and the bartenders seemed really cool and laid back. 
If you just want to get a drink and hang out on a week day, it's a great place to go.
author: Lana K.

description: stumbled into this bar hopping around with some friends from europe, and ended up staying here.  they loved it.  reasonable drink prices.  my first time too.  people, bartenders were friendly.  great atmosphere and eclectic design.  old jack kerouac frequented the place and adds to the charm.  on top of this, i dropped my id on the floor.  a patron found me to give it back.  amazing.  good vibes here.
author: I Be E.

description:
Sure I'm attached, I love the history, the atmosphere, (maybe not the bathroom) but definitely the poetry on the walls on the top floor by the window.  Just don't read it after your seventh jack+coke or you'll go into flights of paranoid delusions.

On a more personal note, I owe my life to Vesuvio's Cafe, it pulled me out of a burning....no nothing that exciting, but it's where my parents went on their first date.

Thank you Vesuvio's.
author: Mike V.

description: Very cute. Reasonable prices. Could have more beers on tap. Friendly waitress. Love the decor!
author: Jeff L.

description:
I have been and out of Vesuvio many times, first because it was a drinking site of Jack Kerouac and is right across the alley from Ferlinghetti's City Light Books.  I returned because it feels like a good local bar.  Yes, there are tourists, I guess I would officially be considered one, but the bartenders are competent and not overly pushy.  After the first couple times, the bartenders were remembering my drink choices.  

Overall it is a nice, laid back place to drink.
author: Orin B.

description: Class Place, good location, good ambiance, good drinks. The Waitstaff is professional and attentive.
author: Dean J.

description:
I really liked this place.

Being the photo freak that I am, I really loved the projections of old photos on the wall.  I liked the upstairs very much, it was quiet and all of us got to talk.  I love the vintage feel of this place.  The bartender seemed a bit crotchety, but he was a good one.  He knew his stuff.

The cocktail waitress was SUPER fast.  She took our order upstairs and went down and came back probably in about 3 minutes.  We were all like, "What!? You just left!"

It was great.  Lots of history in this place.  It's got a good vibe.  I prefer quieter intimate chill bars, we went on a Tuesday or Wednesday last week...I don't remember, but it was nice and quiet, not too many rowdy folks out.

Wouldn't say this one is a recession buster, we got 3 drinks and it was 17 bucks (a beer and 2 gin and tonics).
author: Jillian K.

description: Betty and I came here for an after dinner night cap.  I got the Absinthe which was ok, I'm not a big anise/black licorice fan, but it was good.  The atmosphere was lively and I loved the memorabilia on all the walls.  It had that nice divey feel.  Elizabeth doesn't like whiskey or coffee, but she got an Irish Coffee as she became a big fan of them while on our trip.  Service was good enough for the type of bar it is.  We would definitely come back.
author: Bob B.

description:
Don't bother sitting upstairs.

That's my spot.

Vesuvio has seen me since I was 17  when they conveniently used to not card us waaaay back then.  They're way strict now on "kids these days trying to sneak into bars." Geez, imagine that. I've been here only a couple handfuls of time over the years.  Why? Well, because I'm not alcoholic and while I like this chill spot, I don't like to be a "regular" anywhere, I suppose I have commitment issues!  haha. 
Serious note: There's lots of options in this neighborhood and Vesuvio really is in my top chill 5 for the simple fact that it's a Native San Franciscan girl's paradise: good place to catch up with a girlfriend that not packed with FiDi suits trying to get laid, the bartenders don't seem to have a whole lot of tude, and best of all, it's not $17 for a martini.
author: Athena S.

description:
This place ripped! I wish there was something near to it in Chicago. 

The staff is friendly, the atmosphere is laid back yet you feel like you're sitting in a piece of SF history. Great beer and cocktail selection and plenty of space to sit. We came here twice in 4 days.
author: Tommy D.

description:
The first time I ever came here, I wanted to live here.  These days I practically do.

David, Jim, Joanna and the rest are the best drinkslingers in the west.  I'm glad Marina types only come in to "slum it" on the weekends.  If you think this a "dive bar," you must be used to albacore-tuna-pomegranate-açai Margaritas at Applebee's or something.  

Vesuvio is a jewel and a mountain of San Francisco history--the one you Marina/South Bay types are trying so damn hard to erase.  So stay home.
author: Charles B.

description: Romantic and fun - LOVED it! We nestled into a little booth and watched artists drawing at a table- a very alive and dynamic place - full of joie de vivre!
author: Robyn B.

description: Surrounded by stained glass, this bar feels like a really chill hang out spot. Go here when you're just looking for a kickback and not for partying. The bartender's hair also matches the eccentricity of the place. If you compliment her, you might get a drink or two like I did.
author: Minks M.

description:
Its hard to find bars as good as Vesuvio in San Francisco. There are so many bars that are uncomfortable and over crowded in this city.
You can always get a seat in here... the best ones being upstairs where you can keep an eye on Columbus and Broadway. You never feel lonely in a place like this.....
there are so many people with so many situations to watch..... you can just sit back with a drink and forget about your life for an hour...
Or you can pretend you are in a movie or that you are a famous poet or reporter.. all which are extremely amusing in my opinion.
A good way to spend time really.
author: Kate H.

description:
Jack Kerouac Alley keeps Vesuvio's from humping City Lights Bookstore --- and there's SO much SF history in this sentence alone. 

A tourist trap of sorts --- the pub is located on the Columbus crush wedged between North Beach and Chinatown.  Vesuvio's is one of my favorite landmark DIVE bars in ALL of San Francisco.  It's really the BEST place to head upstairs to order STRONG stiff drinks and people watch.
author: BrasilPo P.

description: We loved this place so much we went twice in the three days we were in town. Beautiful quaint little spot, great decor and ambience, great crowd and good prices. A great spot for a few drinks before or after dinner, highly recommended.
author: Jo-e M.

description:
A friend brought me here last year on my bachelors party before my wedding. Place has great atmosphere and history. It just feels good to drink beer at Vesuvios. Enjoyed some Anchorsteam on draft and afterwards we checked out the local gentlemen clubs.

If your in San Fran and looking for a place with a lot of character and friendly people to hang out at check this place out. Would definitely come back in for a drink next time I'm in S.F.

Cheers Vesuvio
author: Josh M.

description:
Why can't all tourist traps be like this? We were the only two tourists there!

This is the best bar I've ever been to. Even though I'm not a big fan of beatnik literature, I appreciated the photographs and art that overfilled the place. Great jazz music accompanying strong drinks, people watching from upstairs and heated discussions about Catholic guilt and repentance. 

Best way to spend a Wednesday afternoon.
author: Tif W.

description:
Instantly fell in love with this place when my friend took me to North Beach to go bar hopping after a nerve wracking interview (much needed, might I add). The antique decor is cute to boot, and the drinks are supa cheap. Two Glenlivets, one Jameson (all on the rocks), and a Jameson + ginger for $30? Sold.

Upstairs, you'll find more seating areas for both small and larger parties. You can also people watch over some drinks if you sit by the window. Music is not bad either.

A great bar to start a night of debauchery.
author: Aeramis F.

description:
Right now I'm drunk and happy. Thanx Vesuvio!! Thank you Jack!
Vesuvio, where the locals can be yocals.
author: Carla P.

description: Rather than rambling as a ram shackled rum runner wanna be, let's just say this: the fact that there's wicker, history, tourists, pictures popped & stunningly simple & strong drinks, it's *the* perfect welcoming wagon for anyone who would like to understand what we do in San Francisco when someone says they're in town: we drink, and we drink at drink dens like Vesuvio.
author: Jon A.

description: Guys I'm just a sucker for gas lamps.  & pitchers of Lagunitas.  Probably too touristy to go to regularly...but I WAS a tourist!  Also did I mention I'm a sucker for gas lamps?  When I sell my novel & become a bajillionaire or whatever, I want to live in a brownstone with a gas lamp out front.
author: Mordicai C.

description: 5 star for the ambience, drinks are good but nothing out of the ordinary.  Just a really solid North Beach / Beat generation bar.  I come here regularly
author: Alex B.

description:
Darn - this place makes a good alcoholic Arnold Palmer! Glad I read the other reviews before heading there on a Wedn night...not only did I order it but my friend had it recommended to her too! They are spot on with that concoction. Not overly sweet, served w/ a slice of lemon if you want more of a "lemonade" mouth-feel. Goes down smoothly & way too easily! Stopped myself at 2 but definitely going back to try their sake mixed drinks. 

We sat at a table downstairs by the bar. History is cool, bar is cool, pictures are cool. Our waitress was good - nothing to report about. $10 min on credit cards, so bring cash or be prepared to get a few. But at $6/cocktail at happy hour, that minimum is easily hit. 

My only complaint is the bathroom - only 1 for all the women. Can make having to go to the bathroom a true emergency by the time you actually get to use the darn toilet! I recommend passing the time looking at pictures, taking your elsewhere.
author: Marissa H.

description:
This place was pretty damn cool I must admit and no, not just because Kerouac drank here.  I loved the whole look and feel of the place and not to mention the drink prices weren't out of range.  The steep twisty stairs would have killed me back in my stiletto heeled drinking days but I suppose that could be one of those adorable eccentricities that attract me.  The atmosphere was extremely warm and cozy and there was plenty of interesting things to look at!

The customers were friendly and most of the bar staff, Melissa however, was a b*tch.
author: Linda Z.

description:
Essential bay area stop. Really charming!

I went here with a friend on a night of pub crawling. I will definately make this a hangout spot when and if I ever move to SF. Quaint and comfortable atmosphere with a close-knit neighborhood vibe.
author: Lynn C.

description:
This is a pretty cool divish bar in North Beach.

The drinks are reasonably priced (about $5/beer), and it's usually not over crowded where you can't get a seat or completely empty where you're the only group there.

Lots of decorations all over the place which makes this place feel very nostalgic.

I heard Dave Chappelle has been know to hang out here, though I've never bumped into him.
author: Ayall S.

description:
Funky, fun, laidback and awesome!

The atmosphere in there is very chill. We went on a lazy weekend afternoon. Which from reading other reviews I recommend. There were only about 5 other people in there. Definitely recommend happy hour beer pitchers. $11 or $14!! And they're good sized.

Lots of great stuff to look at, friendly bartenders (the waitress creeped me out a bit, her pants were grossly tight) and interesting character customers.
author: Anne H.

description:
I'm so predictable when I visit San Francisco. I walk over to City Lights books, grab something to read (this time a collection of letters by Charles Bukowski) and head next door to Vesuvio.

This place is such a down to earth joint, jazz playing, beer flowing, lots of lively conversation and incredible history.

I don't need much more and Vesuvio always delivers.
author: David S.

description:
Anyone that supports Litquake, I'm a fan of.  It should with the amount of writers and bohemians that have passed through these doors.  I went in support of a few writers I have never heard of and greatly admired 3 out of the 4 I listened to.  There were 6 but parking was so bad I circled for 30 minutes.  I really wish that was an exaggeration.

I sat there with my author friend in the back of the bar where we had a clear view because the writers were at a podium on the second floor.  It was wonderful to listen to everyone laugh and enjoy themselves.

After I brought out my notebook and started writing, a guy writing in his own journal caught my eye and kept checking me out.  I not used to this and in my embarrassment kept looking down, an illness I caught at birth.  He was in his 40's I presume with his graying hair and nicely put together wardrobe.  I do not know what he was in late 20's frazzled all the time me.
author: Ashley I.

description: This was a great little place in a not so fancy part of SF.  I was visiting from out-of-town and a friend suggested this place.  While she told me it wasn't a dive, it certainly met the criteria from an LA standard but I still loved the place.  It is cozy but I love the upstairs seating area and the fact that the drinks are uber cheap and they have a great selection of spirits!
author: Vonnie S.

description:
I love this place. I come here every time I'm in SF and it is always the same. Chill, unpretentious, mixed crowd, balcony seating, friendly cocktail waitress, view of the mural across the alley, etc, etc...
There's just something really refreshing about this bar. I don't know if it's any one thing or the sum of it's parts.
author: Elijah C.

description: Cool looking place but the bar tender was very rude. More likely to expect service with a middle finger rather than a smile if you happen to buy a bear from that guy. Hopefully he just works days or maybe I just caught him on a bad one, but still... Wow.
author: Greg B.

description:
I was carded - that's right and for that, FIVE stars!  Anytime I need to feel "young again" and I shall return...it'll likely be often :)

Seriously, a great neighborhood pub with so much charm!  We especially enjoy the upstairs - from up above, you look out to the alley or onto Columbus, watching the hustle and bustle of busy North Beach - the tourists, the young ones dressing up for a night out, guys horsing around.  From the inside looking out is almost magical...

I tried the Jack Kerouac because it looked refreshing and pretty - plus, what's not to like with rum, tequila, orange/cranberry juice and lime?  If you grab a table upstairs, you can either grab your own drink from downstairs or you can wait for the waitress to come take your order.

Cheers and enjoy!
author: Gloria H.

description: great bar, full of character and charm.  Middle of Tourist hell but still has the local neighborhood dive bar feel
author: Robert F.

description: This is one of my favorite chill bars in North Beach.  The bar is on the ground floor, but you can walk upstairs for more seating/tables.  Usually it's pretty crowded, but not crowded to the point where you'll never get seating eventually.  The decor is great... reminds me of a bar-version of Applebees or whatnot.  I've always had a great time I've been here, and the bartenders are all nice and the drink prices are great.  Haven't tried the food here yet, but it looks great!
author: Liz W.

description:
This is a great bar to people watch. Especially if you are sitting upstairs hiding behind the sun yelling remarks at tourists through an open window. It is even more fun when said tourists have a sense of humor and when they catch you taking pictures of them, they turn around and take pictures of you. 

I decided on a hefe, not to be confused with jefe. Crisp and refreshing as always. Watched some sports, shouted obscenities as passersby (ok not really obscenities, it's not like I was telling 'yo mama' jokes), watched some sports and heard the bartender standing up for himself and his bar..maybe someone told him a yo mama joke? 

Should you choose to have a beer here, take the stairs to the nearest open window and have a good time. And remember, the bartender don't take no shit!
author: Whitney B.

description:
Hands down one of the coolest places to grab a drink in San Francisco. Love the vibe, drinks, and rich history.  Their Seagrams sweet tea vodka and lemonade is my favorite drink to order.

If you've got some out-of-towners you're looking to impress, you must take them here! It makes all other bars/lounges look like child's play.

And if you're feeling frisky, swing by the Lusty Lady afterwards ;)
author: Katie S.

description:
I would give zero stars if that was possible,and my review is based entirely on the nasty, unpleasant server.  I was with 3 friends yesterday and suggested that we pop in and have a drink at the "historic" Vesuvio bar.  The downstairs was dark, and there was only one table, so, at the suggestion of one friend who scoped out the upstairs area, we decided to head for a window seat.  As we started upstairs, we saw a female server, and we said, "We are going to sit upstairs," to which she sighed painfully and loudly and said, "Would you order BEFORE you go upstairs?"  Like obedient children, we all ordered our drinks and climbed to the second floor.

When we were upstairs, we noted only 2-tops next to the windows, and, after taking our seats, we thought of moving chairs a bit so that we could all sit together.  The "sighing server" showed up with our drinks as we rearranged the chairs and looked at us as if we have committed a homicide, saying, "Uh, I don't THNK so.  You are NOT moving anything around up here."  We told her that we were just trying to set up a spot where we could be together, and she said, "Nothing gets moved."

One of my friends is a tourist who has never visited San Franciso, and he was horrified.  We all sat and rather cringed, but, even worse, when she returned to her station downstairs, my tourist friend said, "She is talking about us with a frown and a sour face."  

I always took my East Coast friends to Vesuvio, but I will not sit for a repeat performance.  It is such a shame that such a historice spot would employ such a nasty witch.  I will not be back, and I will recommend to all I know to avoid the nasties of the Vesuvio bar.  It was a nice place in a kinder, gentler time.  What ever happened to "service with a smile"?!
author: Carmilla B.

description:
I really like Vesuvio. The funky decor, artwork and people make it a fun and interesting place. It's kind of a hidden treasure amongst the touristy hustle and bustle of North Beach.

The first time I went my friends and I just kind of stumbled upon it on our way to another bar. I remember thinking that it was such an interesting place and how much I enjoyed myself and anticipated going back...and I have been. I like sitting upstairs, its cozy and intimate and I suggest you do the same.
author: Denise S.

description:
Long time frequent visitor, first-time (long time comin...) review... This is seriously my favorite bar in this lifetime. Everything about this place is awesome. From the peep show pics they play on the projector at night, to the weird tall feeling you get from the roof in the men's bathroom... 

Drinks are reasonably priced, but they're all well-made. I usually come in and have the old fashioned, or a gin and tonic. While my girlfriend usually goes for the specials or her go-to drink, the sweet tea vodka lemonade... I've spent many hours enjoying good drinks over good conversations many times, here. Nothin' but good times and chill waves.

My suggestion: come here with two or three friends, grab a table upstairs, chat it up, and tip your bartender good. An awesome night WILL BE ahead of you.
author: Ray H.

description:
Kinda touristy but a solid stop for a stiff afternoon drink. Older crowd.
The bartender was a good gent who was very welcoming and took very good care of me. I also thank him for chasing me down a whole city block to inform me that I had forgotten my credit card.

I will be back in order to further explore this place.
author: Mo A.

description:
The first time I went to Vesuvio was on New Year's Eve and the place was insanely crowded. Yet, my friends and I found a table upstairs and were served our beers promptly. 

I don't know about the men's bathroom but there are some sweet novelty toy dispensers in the women's restroom (bring quarters!).

The only thing that could improve the place (in my opinion) is a pool table... but the space is relatively small and could in no way fit one. If they had a pool table I'd add another star.

I love Vesuvio!
author: Alex W.

description:
Jack Kerouac, City Lights, if you want beat this is it. The place is funky and old. Tourists can be annoying. Fun to just sit and absorb it all. intimate areas up stairs are funky and good for a date.
Good stop on a pub crawl with specs and the saloon
author: James B.

description: This place is so cozy and awesome. It's right next to City Lights (which is great), and has a really cool upstairs balcony with a lot of cozy tables for two and booths. The drinks are relatively cheap, and they walk around to your table to get your order which is really great when you're trying to just relax and enjoy your company. I've been here twice now, and I definitely plan on returning.
author: Lauren D.

description: My first and favorite bar in the City! The drinks are excellent and the vibe is chill. It is definitely a "hipster" bar, without douche-ness. I would suggest getting the dark and stormy, but it must be drank on the second floor.
author: Kristyn W.

description:
This place has more character in one inch of floor space than most bars accumulate total over their entire lifetimes.  It looks super touristy from the outside, but it's North Beach, and many of the best places are popular for a reason.  Don't be fooled. 

I love the tables at the far end of the top floor where you can look out the window at Columbus.  It's quiet enough to talk but noisy enough that it feels like you're out and the wait staff actually comes back and checks on you in a timely manner.  It's cheap and without gimmicks (as much as I like bartenders with hilariously-gelled mustaches and a dress code from the 1930s).  I usually end up with a glass of wine here because it somehow feels more atmospherically necessary, but they have a decent selection of everything.  The people are jovial and friendly, and if you want to start up a conversation with the kids at the next table, they are usually up for it.  Plenty of old timers, but mostly younguns looking for a cozy place to hang out that feels like it could become home if you just sat there for long enough.
author: Sydney H.

description:
Any bar that is equipped with good beer and a bartender who is thoroughly knowledgeable with hockey talk, and defends the honor of his bar is five star worthy in my book.

Also, I noticed the interior of the place was really nice as I happily sipped on a frosty Amstel Light.
author: Katie B.

description: Perfectly good grog and a friendly crew but lets be honest, this place is really about the experience and ambiance . Vesuvio is classic San Francisco in more ways than one. As such places are being steadily gobbled up one after the other by the Manhattanization of the city places like Vesuvio - and City LIghts Bookstore - become all the more precious. Lets support them eh? Bartender, another!
author: Clay W.

description:
Short and sweet.


My favorite bar in San Francisco.


It's good enough for Jack Kerouac, it's good enough for me.

At the bar, there is a sign that reads, "San Francisco: 49 square miles surrounded entirely by reality."
author: Rex N.

description:
Oh hey! Were you looking for a really good Bloody Mary? One of the better in the city, perhaps one of the top 10 in a city that offers quite a range of them? I'm willing to bet you've been let down by more than a few "special" BMs in SF, be it ones with bleu cheese, bacon, expensive infused vodkas, diamond-encrusted dodo eggs, or FDR's eyeball, all of them just fail at the relatively simple approach to a good Bloody Mary.

Well, Vesuvio nails it with nary more than the traditional ingredients simply by asking the question, "what do each of these ingredients contribute to the overall taste of the perfect Bloody Mary?" The answer is a spicy, diverse flavor base of horseradish, pickle juice, tabasco, tomato juice, and worcestershire. I'm convinced that 90% of a perfect Bloody Mary comes from adding each of these by hand. After that, it only gets better. After the vodka, the only thing left is a wide array of toothpick-skewered pickled veggies--Vesuvio offers green beans, pearl onions, and olives to top off their happy-making concoction.

And oh yeah, the Beats drank here too. That's why this place will (hopefully) never get torn down.
author: Alee K.

description: Was trepidatious about visiting this place -- I was expecting a theme park vibe, jacked up prices, etc., given its landmark status and historical significance. Was pleasantly surprised to find that it's still a friendly neighborhood bar. The bar staff was friendly and good natured and made time to chat. Good beer selection.
author: Chad S.

description:
Great location if you are on your way to North Beach from the downtown/financial district.  Located right next to City Lights Books, so you can soak in all that Beat Generation history.  Very touristy, but worth the extra price for a drink or two.

Word to the wise....get your drinks from the bar and pay as you go.  DO NOT open a tab.  The waitresses will add drinks to your tab if you are not careful.  Also, they will try to run whatever card you use to open the tab even if you are paying cash.  

It's a fun place for groups.....especially the balcony upstairs, but it loses stars for trying to rip-off it's clientele.
author: Alex S.

description:
Honestly, and this is going to sound super lame, I just felt so cool drinking at this bar, knowing that this is where Kerouac, Dylan and Ginsberg spent their days getting piss drunk and being super-geniuses.

Also, a shot and a beer for $4. Can't beat that.

PS - Vintage projection system they have rigged up is worth a fortune to collectors. I wonder if they know this?
author: James H.

description: I love the vibe of this bar and have only recently started venturing into North Beach even though i've lived here most of my life! The decor is fascinating and eclectic. We were fixed upon the provocative changing photos from the 1920's flashing on the wall. It's great because it didn't clash with the modern day basketball game playing on the flatscreen nearby. Vesuvio's is just cool like that. There weren't any crazy people and it just felt like a chill bar to have a drink with friends. Their are various tables scattered around and it's cozy.
author: Samantha L.

description:
Of course, being a beat fan, I have always wanted to drink here. But I hate going to North Beach, due to its dode concentration and horrible parking/transit. Luckily, due to our free night at a downtown hotel, we could walk here and meet some friends after our dinner at WashBAG.

I had a great time. Great vibe here and good beer. Plus I left with a buzz. :)
author: Emily M.

description:
Cozy. Comfortable. Colorful. Gezellig. 

The Bohemian atmosphere feels thick with creativity. Every nook and cranny has character. It's an awesome bar with fair prices.

I like sitting upstairs and watching the charades below (both in the bar and outside). 

Outside there's often some form of quality "street theatre" starring the various vandals, vagrants and other random people who hang out by the big mural in the alley next door.

Vesuvio's is by far my favorite bar in San Francisco.
author: Cam M.

description: I live this place. The lattes are fantastic and the atmosphere is just right... Not too hipster, not too touristy .. It's in north each and is a staple for the locals. Get your coffee in a house cup and stay a while in this historic San Fran spot.
author: Jed T.

description:
Quirky definitely describes it best. A couple buddies and I were looking for a quick drink before we headed off to our next adventure when we stumbled upon this place. 

We really weren't there that long to enjoy the atmosphere but we did get some quality face time with the bartender. She was very friendly and actually seemed interested in what we had to say instead of faking it. They had sweet tea vodka on special that day so we got a couple of dirty Palmers (sweet tea vodka and lemonade). I think I am going to start calling those Tigers Woods now after his recent scandal. 

I did notice that the prices for mix drinks were $1-2 higher than they should have been. If I am in the area I will be back.
author: Jeff P.

description:
Vesuvio is probably my favorite bar in North Beach. I might be a sucker for the rich "beat" history of this place (I think Jack Kerouac and friends used to frequent this place and the book store next door) but there's something about this place that makes me feel comfortable. Beers are reasonably priced, and you can actually get a server to bring you drinks if you snag a table (quite a nice change from most bars I go to). They'll even bring you about bottle of tabasco sauce if you're playing a stupid game with your friends that involves it.

It might not become your favorite bar in North Beach, but it's worth checking out. And it might become your favorite bar in North Beach.
author: Adam D.

description: Stopped by here to grab a couple of drinks during a bar hopping adventure around North Beach on a weekday night. Got our drinks and proceeded upstairs, great for people watching but at night there weren't that many to observe. My friend really liked the baileys coffee. Drinks are pretty cheap. When we were closing our tab we decided to have another round of shots with our waitress. She ended up making them on the house to celebrate our June birthdays! How nice :)
author: Rose Y.

description: Super cute hippie/ hipster joint.  It is two stories and plenty of seating and really great for larger groups.  Super loud and was really packed on a early Saturday night.  I must say you better watch your bartender not to over charge you!!  I heard an Urban legend that it happens a lot.
author: Emilee C.

description:
As an angsty fifteen year old, I wanted to get the hell out of my small town, move to NYC, take a lot of drugs in Central Park, type stream of conscious style prose, drive across the country to SF, writing my journeys back and forth. Essentially, I wanted to be a romanticized beatnik. And during that phase in my life (before I started cutting my own hair, making my own clothes and dating guys in punk bands) I read up everything there was to know about Allen Ginsberg, Jack Kerouac, Lawrence Ferlinghetti, etc...

This is how I learned about Vesuvio's and for as long as I could I would try to sneak into this place just to sit in the same seats as my heroes, theoretically.  Vesuvio's is everything I thought it would be like...Lots of drunks, dimly lit, perfect for business, friends, family and everything in between. There's a lot of beautiful history here, and it's been preserved well. That alone can make up for the price of drinks, but it's the memories that make this place so special.

If these walls could talk, I'm sure Vesuvio's would have a series of novels, prose, and everything in between.
author: Lauren S.

description: Came here on a Sunday afternoon,  sat down at an empty table and no one came to serve me.  The bartender looked at me more than once and was not overly busy.  Racist?  Sexist?  Not interested in business?  So after more than 15 minute of waiting, I left.  Yikes!
author: Debbie W.

description: Tiny, cozy, warm little pub.
author: James S.

description: People here, as in most bars in San Francisco, tend to behave as though strangers must be strange and should be kept that way.  Since this bar caters to people who have heard of Jack Kerouac, I expected it to be an exception to that anti-tourist pompousness, but it reeks of it.  And both barmaids working while I was there told me they'd never read anything Kerouac wrote, but one seemed to me to enjoy my rambling about his writing and mine and other things, reaffiming my notion that bartenders make bars anywhere.
author: Billy Lee H.

description:
I love this place. Here is why.

1) Full bar. My roommates love the Recession Special (Bud + Old Crow) for $4... and this place also makes pretty tasty White Russians. If you're into that.

2) There's table service, which can sometimes be a bit slow, but its cool. Everyone's nice and happy, and the warm lighting makes you both sleepy and mildly desirous of everyone around you.

3) Lots of seating... a clean ladies room... and a great wealth of Beatnik paraphernalia plastered on every surface. For those of you who'd like to spend a night sitting where Jack Kerouac may have placed his iconoclastic bottom, you'll be thrilled to be here. The crowd is usually a bit mixed... casual businessmen, tourists, some hipsters, and the normal bar-going population (whomever fits into this category, I assume you'll self-define).

4) It's a good bar in North Beach (and those are hard to find). So if you're in the area and under 35 (or feel under 35)... check it out.
author: Ashley M.

description: Good drinks, friendly staff and most importantly, history! :)
author: Jeff K.

description: I cannot begin to tell you what a delight Rose was last night.  We stumbled in for gin and she dealt with three drunk, crazy people like a champ. Thanks for the good time Rose.  You are the best.
