author: John S.

description: I've only been once, (North Beach feels like such a trek somehow?) but I love this place. They don't serve food, so I was free to bring my pup in, which is always a plus. The atmosphere of this place is just sooo nice and welcoming. The interior is just so original, it kind of gives off the feel of prohibition days or something. Although I've only been once I do plan to go again in the near future, as this just might be my favorite bar in SF.
author: Amy S.

description: I'm a big fan of this joint; not because it's a bar-I'm far from a drinker. I'm good for one dark & stormy and it's always amazing here. I'm a big fan because no matter what time of day, month or year I ALWAYS have an incredible time here.The staff provides friendly service and a warm, inviting atmosphere. There are always patrons that have a story, something weird to say or even make you smell their shirtsleeve and ask you if it smells like stripper-crotch. Oh boy!
author: Sherie R.

description:
Vesuvio is a place my works buds & I frequent on Fridays. Super chill, unpretentious atmosphere. NIce service, good drinks, feasible, and no loud music. We've brought board games + food before -- space can be a little cramped for large tables, but nothing out of the ordinary for SF. 

Minus one star for NO FOOD!
author: Tejal D.

description: it just dominates so much coolness on so many levels. the drink slingers have a charm. the beverages deliver that has it magic. and the rest is there as you have need. a great place for travelers and friends.
author: Milan M.

description:
WOO HOO! Totally love this place! David (he looks like a lumberjack) and Bridget (wonderful classily dressed young lady) are some of the nicest bartenders and very hospitable. 

If you like stained glass and neoclassic italian art, come to this place! it's a little squishy on the bottom floor but there's always a table or two on the top floor. the bathrooms are a little awkward because the mens is on the lower lower floor and the womens is on the second floor. a little cumbersome, but it's okay.

it's definitely a place where i feel comfortable with the staff and most importantly, the crowd. nice people hang out here and i love it.

Oh! Prices. I bought: two white russians, two boozy arnold palmer things, and one bloody mary = $30. not too bad , right? but then again, i looked at the bill when i was drunk so i figured that was cheap. lol.
author: Kiana L.

description:
I'm not really sure why I love this place, but I do. It seems to be the place I take out of town visitors for a low key post-dinner beer or three. There's just something cozy about this place...like my other favorite bar, Comstock, Vesuvio makes me forget the hubbub of Columbus Ave the minute I walk in. 

It hasn't been too packed (I've wandered in on random Friday nights) and I've always been able to grab a seat either at the bar or in a random corner. It's not too loud, so I think it's a great place to catch up with friends and enjoy a tasty beer!
author: Karena Q.

description:
When you think of a bar in North Beach, you think of Vesuvio. With its quirky decorations, location next to City Lights and Jack Keourac Alley, and rather casual atmosphere, you would think the place would get overrun with tourists and the bridge and tunnel crowd. 

This place screams San Francisco, with it's small second floor (DUCK!), colorful lamps and casual atmosphere. Ironically, the place is loaded with history (Jack Kerouac drinking grounds, and you can state he started killing himself here), yet I think it scares off some people.

The place is a great place to chill out in the neighborhood, either at the start of the evening or the last bar to finish off (I recommend a Tequila and a Stella).
author: Patrick N.

description: Quirky bar that should be on the welcoming tour for anyone that you're showing around SF. If there's room, grab one of the small tables upstairs so you're a bit removed but can still partake in the good people watching. The drinks are pretty good - and strong.
author: Gina C.

description: The perfect place sip a Jack on the rocks and take in the room full of photos, Tiffany lamps and colorful patrons. This was one of the first bars I ever went to in SF, and it's still one of my faves.
author: John I.

description: Try the bloody mary and sit upstairs on a nice day, with the window open and people watch. No better way to spend a Sunday.
author: Es F.

description:
Hung out here for several evenings during a trip up to San Fran in December.

The atmosphere is practically perfect.  I know of the history, the beat poet movement, Jack Kerouac etc... but I just loved the layed back atmosphere of the bar.  Music is not too loud, drinks are good and keep coming, the service was great (though one evening the waitress seemed to be in a bad mood and was pretty blegh), and it just has that great chill atmosphere.

If you're in the area, and want to check out a historic bar where you can actually talk to the people next to you without having to yell over music, then this place is a must.
author: Shawn M.

description:
This tiny little bar had a lot of neat stuff on the walls and was interesting to sit and look around.  

I tucked into a corner table downstairs and sipped a whiskey and coke while I watched people hang out at the bar, saw a couple on their first date, and listened to some lively banter of the bartenders.  The tables are close together downstairs (I didn't go up), but the close proximity allowed me to talk easily with the lovely couple at the table next to mine.

Prices were pretty average, it wasn't super-cheap, but I didn't leave feeling taken advantage of, either.
author: Miss L.

description: LOVE the layout inside! So cute and whimsical.
author: Cind Y.

description:
I really ended up liking this place in several different ways. You can kinda push it anyway you want it. First, if you wanna do the cheapskate route, they've got the "recession special" last time I was there...which was a shot of well whiskey and a bud for like $6 or something. Nice!

However, where this place really shines is as a classic cocktail joint. The first night I was there, the bartender was a true cocktail artist. Made some solid manhattans, and then hit up a concoction all of his own which was sort of a blend between an old fashioned and a sazerac (I know...and I bet you thought those 2 drinks couldn't have a middle ground!)

Even when its full, the bartenders still have time for ya, and will be totally cool with you pointing at that sparkly spandex that just walked by (yes, this happens).

The crowd can get a little into their pink shirts and popped collars every so often, but in general, they stay off on their own and don't invade your cool bubble too badly. The place will also get packed because its small, but I've had a lot of good luck here near the end of nights or on weekdays. Give it a check one of these days!
author: Sean C.

description: Historic bar considering Jack Kerouac used to hang out here. I like the upstairs area. It's pretty chill and interesting. You can sit here alone if you want to (and not feel weird or stared at).
author: Olivia P.

description: An update: It seems the servers that all work here now are awesome! Not that I am a bar fly, but I do love my occasional beer here.
author: Tim N.

description:
This is a beatnik-era bar with a LOT of character. The upper level seating, posters, art,  unique furniture and antiques make it worth a look on their own. But I recommend you stay for a bit.

If you come with friends it's quiet enough to talk and it has a cool vibe while you drink up and get ready for your next location. If you come by yourself it's a relaxing place to get an irish coffee / cocktail and sketch or read a book. Plus, table service upstairs.
author: Micah S.

description: A cool and quirky Bar with tons of Memorabilia on the walls it has a cool and cramped second floor. I order the economic special which is a shot of Bourbon and a glass of Bud . Not bad for $4. My fried had a Captain and Coke ,he was trying to get his Pirate on LOL. Lots of Attractive city girls were in this place tonight. WOW.
author: Eugene L.

description: Super love this little place in the heart of San Francisco's North Beach. This is the best place to chill with friends while see the world outside pass you by. Music is good, atmosphere is fantastic. They don't accept debit/credit cards so bring lots of cash if you want to get wasted coz they don't really have the strongest drink and it is a little pricey, but who cares?! you're in San Francisco so enjoy and drink the night away!!
author: Donci B.

description:
I like to describe places in terms that everyone can understand. As I was sitting at a table here, overlooking the street below... I turned to the man sitting next to me and said, "You know, this seems like the kind of place that, if we were living in a TV show, would be our hang out spot. 'Friends' had Central Perk, 'How I Met Your Mother' has MacLaren's, and our show would have Vesuvio." Which, you know, would be awesome. I wish I lived nearer to this place instead of 6 hours away from it. I might not drink all the time, but it would definitely be an interesting place to meet up with friends. It was pretty in a victorian sort of way, and very San Franciscan. 

The five of us in our group stayed for quite a while, waiting to meet up with my boyfriend who had been out on business all day. I had two drinks over the course of, what, 3 hours?... and still managed to get drunk. To be fair, I think my vodka cranberry was actually just vodka with a little bit of pink food coloring. It was the first drink I've ever had that I had to sit there and nurse, and I don't even particularly enjoy the taste of alcohol. I might have been gone after that, but I still went in for a long island. Also, it was here that I found out what a long island actually is. Turns  out, they're not actually made with tea. They're made with ALL the alcohol, and a little bit of soda or something. This was also the first one I've had that wasn't dark brown. The last thing I remember is ordering a gin and tonic to have waiting for Dan when he got there, because he hadn't had the greatest of days. Oh, wait... I also remember chanting "fus roh Dan" as he came to join us. Did I mention we're all nerds? Then again, if you understood the reference, you're kind of a nerd, too.

Anyhow, after that it all kind of goes dark, and stays dark until a little while later when I was sucking down vegetable spaghetti at some restaurant across town. This place doesn't kid around with their drinks, and also, it was only 8 dollars for a long island. 8 dollars for blackout-in-a-cup. I've been to an LA bar that charged 16 dollars for a drink with the same name, but that couldn't possibly have been the same drink. I'm slowly starting to think I live in the wrong place. 

I really enjoyed Vesuvio. If I had to spend 3 hours waiting for someone, I'm glad it was here.
author: Terin C.

description:
One of my favorite bars in the world! Vesuvio is everything a bar should be. Laid back vibe, good prices, friendly, (but not too friendly ) bartenders and a diverse crowd. You can have a conversation here or sit in the corner with a book. Everyone is welcome. It's featured in pretty much every tour guide to San Francisco so it does get a fair amount of tourists, but plenty of regulars too. 
It's said Kerouac stop here prior to a meeting and liked it so much that he skipped the meeting and stayed here all day. I can see why. If I lived in SF, I'd be a regular here as well.
author: Scott H.

description: I'd give this place 3.5 stars if I could. I don't think it's a 4 though. I went on NYE night so I feel like it's not fair to judge bars and restaurants on huge nights like that. We actually did get very quick service on drinks. The glass of champagne I got there was pretty awful though, and the cocktails were just ok but I wasn't blown away by them. Prices were good. We did ask for a couple of simple drinks/recipies that they couldn't do. Not sure why, maybe they don't have that deep of inventory? Usually if I ask bartenders for something specific like that they have no problem accomedating. I thought it seemed strange for such a popular bar. I got the impression this was a good place to stick with the basic drinks but to not try to get too fancy when ordering.
author: R R.

description:
One of my friend's favorite cities is San Fran, when I went to visit she gave us a list of spots we should hit and this was on it. It's located right next to the famous City Lights bookstore.

This place is really cool and has quite a history (just check out their website). There are posters, artwork and old newspaper clippings all over the walls. There is a cute second floor which lines the walls of the bar so you still have a view of the floor below. We got one of the little corner booths on the second floor so we were able to check the place out pretty well. We went at an off time so the place wasn't really crowded, but the people in there were nice and diverse. With the bar's history it's somewhat of a tourist trap by default, but it never feels that way (there isn't a gimmicky, cheesy or overpriced thing about it).

Stop in and have a beer, you won't be disappointed.
author: Mary T.

description:
I made my way over to Vesuvio on a Saturday night to meet up with some friends.  They had gotten a table on the second level, which is great for people watching.  Too bad the people below weren't doing anything worth watching.

I liked the vibe and the ambiance - it's a prefect bar to bring visitors to give them the SF "feel".   OK beer selection, just a lot of mainstream beers. Full bar.  I got the feeling this is more of a "meet old friends" bar than "meet new friends". Probably a good way to start the night.
author: Nathan M.

description: Second floor balcony is best: try the local brews, they have a great bottle selection.
author: dean d.

description:
Yes, it's a San Francisco institution, but it's always worth it to drink here because of the constant stream of San Franciscans that stop in here a lot. I visit about four or five times a year and there is always some kind of notorious local (last night it was a newspaperman) drinking here. The bric-a-brac is great for the OCD-ridden. The staff is helpful and friendly. It's cozy and somehow more awesome because you know that Kerouac probably puked in the alley. And now it is named for him. 

Incidentally, my favorite bit of SF trivia - the alley here used to be nicknamed Murder Alley because there was about a murder a day in it at one time.
author: Darren M.

description:
(From early September 2010 visit)
Sit upstairs by the big windows, have a cocktail or two, flip through your purchases from City Lights next door. Don't drink so much that you can't make it back down the stairs.
author: Corinne L.

description: If I could give Vesuvio negative ten stars as a review I would.  In all my years of going to bars I have never experienced the crass, nasty and horrific service I received today.  AVOID this place if the bartender with the pink hair and the waitress with the blond braids are working.  DON'T sit at a table as they will try and add a huge tip without your knowledge or consent.   This bar has great history and location however service makes a huge impact and this bar should be avoided.
author: Jeanne B.

description:
Great place to visit. We got a great table. Great dirty martinis.
Nice crowd, locals & tourists. It's a friendly place not too loud either. Perfect balance.
author: Geordie E.

description: Definitely my go-to local watering hole in North Beach. It's close enough to the glitz and sleaze of the Broadway strip club strip to feel a little edgy, but once you come inside, the atmosphere is quiet and relaxed. Vesuvios is my oasis from the rowdy Broadway crowd and the tourists on Columbus. I like to take my beer upstairs to the second level and look out onto the street or down at the patrons below, especially if I'm lucky enough to snag one of the booths tucked away in the corners. The prices can be a little steep, but they have a couple of good specials, the like "recession buster," a beer and a shot of bourbon for $4. And they make the best damn Irish coffee I've ever had - made with cold cream floated on top!
author: Johnny W.

description: Been going here for years. The atmosphere is the best part. I have many pictures in there with friends current and from the past. It's awesome.
author: Miguel N.

description: Awful Awful Awful customer service. I actually overheard one of the women that worked there talking s**t about the customers! There are plenty of wonderful places in SF. Spend your money in a place that deserves your business.
author: Sue L.

description:
If these walls could talk
they would curse and laugh and sing...
two feet in the past.
author: Nathan K.

description: Great place to stop in for a drink, especially if you don't make it to North Beach very often. It has a lot of character and history and tends to be fairly full, but never packed. Make sure you stop by City Light Books first!
author: Kristen C.

description:
Fantastic history to this place.  Used to have one of the greatest juke boxes.  I miss it.  A must stop every time I'm in San Francisco.
If there were a heaven, Vesuvio would be it.  But since I'm an atheist, I'll just say: 
When I die, I hope in my mind, that I walk thru the doors of Vesuvio to be greeted by my family and friends and a good drink.  And the music's playing, we're all laughing and having a great time.  And that's it for eternity.  My favorite bar in my favorite city.  And I'd be happy forever in my "Brazil" ending.
author: D A P.

description: Terrific piece of North Beach history. And they've got Anchor Steam on tap. The best seats are on the second floor. Great place for people watching on Columbus.
author: Bruce T.

description:
Came here worried that the place might be overrun with Kerouac seekers - of which I am one. Hypocritical, I know - but pleased to find out it's very much a local establishment full of friendly, very helpful regulars and staff. Even got an excellent recommendation from one of the waitresses/bartenders for a dinner location my second night in town. (Sodinis Trattoria. Review forthcoming.)

My only gripe? The Sunday night crew was most definitely the "B" team. A very poor attitude behind the bar, and why, on this night only, was I told I couldn't open at tab at the bar (as I'd done other nights previously) but that, if I moved 3.5 feet to my rear and sat at a table, I could? Nonsensical. Finished my one beer and left.

Otherwise, a nice, friendly vibe, and if I lived in San Francisco, I could see becoming a Vesuvio's regular myself. (And for the four nights I spent in town, I guess I was.)
author: Hugh R.

description:
Bit of a joint, dark and full of character. Would be a dive (and probably was once upon a time) but now full of tourists and folks reading their books purchased across the alley at City Lights.

Definitely a beer place - saw a few Bloody Mary's going down too so maybe they're ok. We had come from lunch at Cafe Claude and were in a bit of a wine mood. Mistake. One of the worst glasses of red I've ever had. Should have known better. Stick with a pint and bring a book. Fun spot.
author: Tony S.

description: its not quite a dive, its not high class, its just right for a couple of homies, some beers, and rad conversation. it gets pretty loud on the weekends but i don't mind screaming at my friends, just bring a mint. the bartender dude who looks like zach galifianakis delivers on personality. now, the whole jack kerouac thing is cool, but go there and make your own masterpiece. write a stranger a poem on a dirty napkin. compose your 1st symphony if that is your thing. i don't know about you but just being around the buzz of ascending voices and delectable spirits keep the creative juices flowing. if you want to get hyphy go to ruby sky. if you want to chill with the cool kids, well......
author: Qui K.

description: this place is pretty darn hip and cool. maybe we lucked out b/c we got seats at the bar and had a super cool and fun bartender. Yea, I'd go back......
author: Mrs. A.

description: Vesuvio has a quirky, old-fashioned vibe to it. I doubt much has changed since it was built in the late 40s, and I mean that as a great compliment. The walls are adorned with old images and stories, providing intrigue and adding to the cozy feel already provided by the small space and ample use of wood. Try to get there early enough to get a table!
author: Brett B.

description: Fun bar scene downtown. Friendly and efficient service, decent prices for the City.
author: Stephen M.

description: Vesuvio is one of those historic bars, usually ripe with tourists, kitsch dripping from the walls, where you can imagine Jack Keruoac tossing back whiskey and shooting the breeze with Allen Ginsberg. It is next door to the original beatnik haunt, and the USA's first ever paperback bookstore, City Lights Books. According to local lore, the owner of Vesuvio lived in the small apartment upstairs inside City Lights, which is now the Poetry room.  If you are a beatnik literature buff like me, I highly recommend taking some time to look at the postcards of black and white shots from the 50's in the poetry room and maybe read some beat poems to get in the mood. Just make sure you are quiet about it or you might get some dirty looks. Then go to Vesuvio for a cocktail. Don't order anything too complicated at the bar though. This place is divey, not one of those fancy joints where they fresh squeeze all the juices. Stick to highballs or beer here.
author: Audra S.

description:
This place is so cute!  I've never been to Europe, but I felt a little European when I stepped in.  They have an upper level that overlooks the bottom floor and has street view on the other side.  The low ceilings give it a homey feel too.  

My friends got the Sweet Tea Vodka, and it was definitely a kicker, and delicious too!

I'd love to come here again.  I can very well see myself enjoying a crossword or reading a book while sippin on sweet tea.
author: Kimba V.

description:
What I enjoyed most about Vesuvio was that it was NOT one of those pretentious, I-want-to-hook-up, materialistic lounge bars.  Like another reviewer said, THIS is a bar that you can just hang out at without all the loud music that blows out your ear drums and the ridiculous people trying to make out or hook up with each other.  While other bars take the initiative and lure you in with the machismo of sex and the raw aggression of alcoholism, Vesuvio is quite different, you can actually hang out there and TALK to your friends and just have a nice time.

I personally don't care about shots, or cocktails or all that junk.  Beer will always be my personal preference when I go out to drink, Vesuvio provides just that, a good place where I can get a pitcher of beer instead of a fruity martini or shot of Patron.  In my opinion, why pay almost 10 dollars for a small shot and get drunk within the first 5 minutes when you can talk to friends, have some fun, drink some BEER.  Good times.

The interior design is freakin' awesome, two story decor made to look similarly to an Irish pub.  Though in some ways it's also very bohemian and has it's own little charismatic elegance to it and at the same time a very friendly atmosphere.

I'd give an extra star if I could for the cute Asian bartender/waitress who works there.  Such a pretty girl, if you're reading this, you deserve a star.

/edit: Yuck, that last sentence was cringe-worthy reading it in 2018. I'm sorry for saying that about the bartender.
author: Simon L.

description:
Just moved to North Beach from Chicago and this place is officially the best bar I've ever had the privilege of calling my local. The staff are friendly and great about remembering your drink and the cast of characters that call this place home make it worth its weight in gold. 

Great location, great history, great bar.
author: Angela M.

description: The atmosphere is uniquely San Franciscan, and I would recommend it for any locals and tourists passing through to get that experience. There's usually a good chance to get a table upstairs to enjoy the view, and the noise level usually isn't too loud in order to enjoy a conversation. It's a great place to relax and have a drink with friends!
author: Matt J.

description: I'll try to keep this short.  I really hate leaving bad reviews about a business but this one is really deserving.  I have been here once before and had a great time and the following experience saddens me.  Tonight, I attended a birthday party for a server who works with my partner.  We were a group of 10, all servers and bartenders.  We had come from the stinking rose, where we had an amazing dining experience.  As we received drinks, the cocktail waitress mentioned that her shift was ending and that she would need to be paid now because she "didn't want to miss out on a 15 dollar tip" and that the tip would be included in the price.  We were all fine with that, of course, but I felt really uncomfortable when she talked like that to us, almost embarassed.  We were there for a birthday party, and everyone was in a good mood and just wanted to have a good time.  We are all in the industry and would have left this woman a great tip if she had explained that she were about to be off work and that she'd like to transfer us to another server, but that is not what went down.  When we tried to add drinks to the tab, she looked really irritated and talked with us about tips 2 other times.  Even saying the word tip to a customer is APPALLING to me, and the cherry on top was the security guard who came upstairs and asked us to be quiet.  We were going around in a circle telling the birthday girl things we each liked about her, and then cheersing when each one of us was done talking.  I was with 2 guys and 7 girls, of course it's going to get a little loud.  At my bar i worry about people being intoxicated, falling asleep, etc, not groups of servers/bartenders who put up with peoples crap all the time, and only want to celebrate a birthday and buy lots of alcohol from your establishment.  I went outside to smoke a cigarette (by this time my friends were chugging the wine because we just wanted to leave) and apologized to the door guy for being loud, and explained to him we were all in the industry and were celebrating a birthday blah blah, and then he replied "we try to keep it low key, i know it looks like a dump but......." and i said 'actually it doesn't', I was being honest, the bar doesn't look like a dump at all, but the cocktail server I had tonight does make it look like a dump, as does the security guard who was on his iphone while doing the door.  Totally unacceptable and unprofessional.  I give one star for the guy in the green cap who was free pouring drinks with amazing accuracy, I was watching him to keep myself calm throughout the onslaught of tips badgering I got from that awful cocktail waitress.  I will not return to this business, there are so many other bars with awesome elite cocktail servers that I'd rather give my money to when my group of industry professionals wants to go out.  Kudos to that bartender though.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
Your best bet for a North Beach bar if you're trying to capture that Kerouac, beat experience. Kudos to any bar with windows so you can, you know, see the outside world (and at the corner of Broadway and Columbus they really should be charging admission for the live show that occurs outside)

Ladies, I have no clue why every guy in SF thinks this is the best place for a first date... but, we do.
author: Robert M.

description: Solid place where you're treated well if you deserve it and no non-sense bar with a solid selection and reasonable prices.  Classic beatnik ambiance where you can sip a drink and bring your own foods.  Upstairs is my favorite spot to sip a drink in SF
author: Matthew M.

description:
Vesuvio. This is the kind of place you come in, early evening, to catch drinks before dinner. The setting sun catches the windows just right...it's perfect.

The drinks were reasonably priced, as well. I got iced tea vodka with lemonade - it was only $6 and delicious! Mmmm. My husband got a beer, which he enjoyed. We drank our drinks and were pretty much only one of two groups in the bar. I really enjoyed the ambiance and will go back next time we are in San Francisco.
author: Xenu M.

description: Best little bar in North End. Art work is fun and definitely conversation starters. Drinks are good and come quick.
author: Elizabeth S.

description: This is a historically relevant spot in North Beach with great drinks & friendly staff. Definitely worth stopping in :) .
author: Becca M.

description:
Shuffled by here on my own, on a dark, rainy January night in San Francisco.  I went to Vesuvio's accidentally on purpose because I was meeting a friend for drinks at a different establishment and had a little bit of time to kill....

It's a fine place.  Tiny and kind of cozy on the inside, great bartenders and good conversation with interesting people from all over the world.  I probably would have given it 3 stars if it hadn't been for the Jack K connection, and I honestly don't know if I will frequent the joint.  But I highly recommend it for tourists and for those trudging along Columbus--if only because the alcohol was decently priced.
author: Sarita T.

description:
Surly.......yep! Old decor..............yep! Great music..........yep! Full of history............yep! Stiff drinks.............yep! Why is it not 5-stars? Well I usually so blasted when I leave I cannot remember if they serve food!

I am a traditionalist at heart so this place is one of 2 musts when I visit town.

Love it!
author: K M.

description:
Kitchy dive bar with connections to a dude named Jack Kerouac. Ever heard of him? If yes, it's worth going here; if not, meh...

The old guy bartender is Johnny On the Spot with strong drinks, but beware his gentle feelings - an innocent sarcastic remark will ruin his evening.
author: Anton A.

description: Funky vibe focusing on the beatnik thing.  Nothing special but cheap drinks and an interesting, unpretentious atmosphere.
author: Josh F.

description: Cool spot to get literal but the balcony section smells like farts. I'm looking at you Ginsberg.
author: Jordan P.

description: We spotted this from the street and had to stop in for a drink.  Great beers on tap with decent prices.  I would stop by if your in the area but wouldn't make a trip out of it.  I could people watch in here all day long... We hung out upstairs.  Its totally a laid back kind of place with friendly staff.  I've posted a shot upstairs.  Cool atmosphere.
author: Julie R.

description:
I went to Vesuvio's on both Friday and Saturday nights.  Why?  I really can't put my finger on it.   Yes, the bar has a very interesting and ecletic décor but it's usually very crowded with both tourists and locals alike.  The bar does draw a well diverse crowd though which makes for great people watching.  The bartenders were a bit blah and really didn't exhibit the best personalities.  The drinks are decent, nothing to really rant or rave about.  They had this cool absinthe dispenser which attracted the tourists like flies to shit.  Prices were decent as well, which is perk given this bar's immense popularity.

The best part of this bar was the food situation.  There is none here!  Now, normally, I would shun a place for that.  But they'll let you bring food from outside the bar and eat it right there in front of them.  They even have condiments for ya if you need them.  Gotta love that.
author: Jim D.

description:
One of my favorite spots.

Maybe its the romantic allure of North Beach, or that I just remember that special night with a certain someone that was so special because it possibly wan't so special to anyone else. Vesuvio's is just a classy place with great history; and being on Kerouac's alley doesn't hurt either.

Go in, enjoy a few drinks (get something classy please), and reap the rewards of sitting in such a historic spot.
author: Patrick K.

description:
There's something about Vesuvio's charm that I can't quite put my finger on. Its ambiance is not trendy enough to cater to the young crowd, but it's vibe doesn't speak entirely to the older generations either. But it's a bar that brings together hordes of people that just want to kick back and enjoy themselves. 

My friends and I hit up Vesuvio after a long day of running around SF and the bar did what we wanted it to. It gave us a place to relax and get our drink on. Our waitress Adelle, knew what was up and hooked us up with pretty good service. We all got a round of drinks and the prices were reasonable. 

Although Vesuvio is a fully stocked bar, it sits more like a small cafe. The balcony seating upstairs was a bit cramped and the stairs a bit narrow. Still there is something cozy and inviting about this place. If you're ever in the North Beach and are looking for a place to enjoy yourself, you won't go wrong with Vesuvio.
author: Matt H.

description: Full of character, not too crowded, not blaring loud music, and the staff are friendly.  It has everything I look for in a bar and it's a great place to people-watch.  I go here every time I'm looking for a drink in North Beach.
author: Amanda R.

description:
Stopped in for a drink Saturday night for the first time in quite awhile...which reminded me of some of the phenomenal times I've had at this place.

It will always have a place in my heart due to being the origin of  the best words I've ever heard uttered in a bar in my life:

Longish story, but here goes:

My two best wingmen and I managed to meet up with 2 girls and bring them here for a cocktail or two.  We go upstairs and are having a great time.  Girls are loving us...well loving Chadd and me anyway.  Paul is feeling a little left out.  But there are these two other fairly attractive women up there sneaking cigarettes out the open window.

Paul had always been very, very sensitive to cigarette smoke and politely asks them to extinguish their cigarettes.  They basically tell him to f*ck off.

Paul does not like this.  not. one. bit.  So he starts musing aloud on how horrible a habit smoking is.  It makes your clothes, breath and hair stink, it causes cancer, etc.  Then he gets to the killer line:

"Look at those two over there, they can't be more than 28 or 29 but they look 40, their skin looks like leather...they're just wretched!"

At which point one of the girls walks over and slowly and deliberately pours an entire pint of beer over Paul's head.

Without batting an eye Paul slicks his Hefeweizen drenched hair back looks her in the eye and says:

"That's okay Baby!  Because I'm still pretty and you're still wretched!"

By the time Chadd and I managed to drag our doubled up asses off the floor, the two who had been with us were halfway to the marina and the beer dumping girls were leading the bouncer up the stairs to have us forcibly removed from the premises.

Quite the evening.

Somewhat ironically, not long after that Paul moved to New York and started smoking.

Even more ironically, Paul was graced with a beautiful baby girl last friday...karma's a bitch.
author: Jay W.

description:
This is probably one of my favorite bars in the city.  It attracts a very diverse clientele such as artists, students, business people, psychics, tourists, yups and crazy people from all walks of life.  It was once the hangout of Kerouac and other Beat poets - enough said. 

The best seating is upstairs by the windows - people watching to the extreme.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Awesome bar! Quirky, yet somewhat classy. Straight in the heart of downtown San Francisco, but has a warm feeling. Zany pictures and murals filled up the walls making the whole bar into a neat collage. Service was great as were our drinks. The upstairs area is fun as you can stare at all the weird people passing by outside. Definitely one of my favorite bars in San Francisco.
author: David D.

description:
I felt like a cool cat being in here. It was roomy (on a Thursday, anyways) and... well, I can't think of any other word besides cool. There was also a Recession Special while we were there, something I greatly appreciate from any establishment.

I wonder if Bob Dylan ever sat where I sat?! Or Diane DiPrima!?
author: Rachel S.

description: I have been to this bar several times over the past few years, and have always enjoyed each visit.  I like the decor inside the bar, and the upstairs area is a great place to enjoy a few beers.  However, it might be slightly scary to come down the winding staircase after a few too many beers.
author: Jenn W.

description: Other visits have been fun.  I mean, how many other places can you see a man that looks like Slash and talks with a voicebox get trashed?  The place is really interesting in a neatly eccentric way, and the drinks are good.  But all that isn't enough to keep me coming back if the service gets rude.  The female bartender on this particular visit was dismissive and condescending, and it almost seemed like the other guy was trying to pick a fight with another customer.  The hell is going on here?!
author: Megan K.

description:
I go there to get away from the day, gray looming overhead.  Thoughts of a girl in Marin.  Over and down in a sleepy town... 

....
....

We meet at Vesuvio's.  She's married and I'm broke.  I'm great to be around she says.  A football game is on the TV over the bar and we both stare at it intensely.  (I couldn't tell you the teams that were playing but I could tell you about the striped shirt she was wearing and how cute her arms were folded over the table, excited eyes ablaze in a cold beer buzz.)  Her laugh a comfort to my soul like no one else's - The only way I know how to connect with her in my nervousness is making her laugh, drinking Lagunita's IPA. Her husband is trying to reach her.  He wants to drink a beer, too. With her.   

Something very comfortable about the time spent inside this bar.  Mellow lamps and Kerouac on the wall.  Beat poets are here, before happy hour, writing it down with tightly crossed legs, wrenching out the woes and whatnot.  I fall into the warmth of Vesuvio's, wishing there was no ending to this day.  Tonight is coming too fast and I can only hope ordering two more beers will do the trick.  She makes her empty beer bottle kiss my empty beer bottle.  Before the waitress comes by again, the bottles are in a frenzy - banging against each other.  The bottle caps on the table spill to the floor like socks on a dark bedroom floor - Uncontrolled laughs spring from our sideways heads.  We order two more and tell the waitress, "Please don't take away the empties.  It's proof we've been here awhile."  

I find my eyes on the TV once more as some kind of tension returns to our table.  The girl's eyes scan my face.  I look at her, weakening.  Our smiles fading for the moment.  I know the truth, but I don't need it right now.  She wants to be honest.  She wants to know what's on my mind. She's been on my mind but I don't want to lay something that heavy on her.  

....

Enough about the girl.  I didn't get the girl.  I got the bar.  All to myself.  Legs tightly crossed, scribbling loosely on a postcard.  The rain coming down in sheets, now.  She and I once ran through the rain, smiling - Not caring about anything or anyone.  She and I connected forever in a single moment - Wishing to stop time - Knowing that we had to quit it all after awhile.  We ran into this bar and found a table where I found love in her smile.  She said that she hadn't seen that hungry look in a man's eyes in a long time.  She told me she would never forget this night.  (Yes, night had arrived.  The Transamerica Beacon was blinking to remind some of us it was time to go home.)

....
....


I will never forget that night.  I found love for a girl.  For a city.  I am writing these kind of things on the postcard and become concerned with typicalities - Those lovely cliches that ungracefully grace postcards of this sentiment - Like it matters at this point.  I send it off to her anyway.  I still owe you twenty bucks and a couple beers, I tell her.  

But she's in that Marin town - Betting on the sure thing - Loving life and the way the sun shines and the way you can see Mt. Tamalpais all the time.  

I'm still here.  In Vesuvio's.  I came in from the rain.
author: Kenny R.

description:
Take a loved one here.  

Talk business over chardonnay.  Drink as much as you can at $7 a glass.  

By the end of the evening, if you can remember it, you could change your life.  Or maybe you'll just get really, really drunk, and not remember what you said at all.
author: David D.

description:
Another tourist trap bar in a cruddy part of town. If you must come here, fight through the mess of invading hordes, grab a well poured Guinness, then find a place to sit down and people watch. Here were the highlights of my night:-

1) Dumb tourist #1 trying to sit in the uncomfortable & totally impractical 1970s wicker chair while having a conversation with dumb tourist #2 to their left about the state of the economy.

2) Beer Promo Girls in skimpy clothes getting visually raped by eastern european teenage drug lords.

http://farm2.static.flickr.com/1116/566128708_69ca52323d.jpg?v=0

3) Jamie Hyneman, the moustached beret wearing chap from Myth Busters busting the myth... "how much attention can a homeless guy get by playing the lute badly".

http://i115.photobucket.com/albums/n305/honda_san86/72deb2d8.jpg
author: Michael H.

description:
Who in the world thought it would be a good idea to take an area of town where most women wear heels, serve us alcohol, add a narrow and curved staircase and throw the womens restroom at the top of it? Is this some sort of sick joke? Are they testing us? Are they trying to separate the women from the girls? 

I am happy to report that I have never failed the test and tumbled down the stairs into a bar full of patrons just waiting for this to happen.  I have, however, seen this happen a few times. 

That might be the only thing I don't like about this place, besides the weekend crowd, but I just don't go to North Beach on the weekends....problem solved. Now that I have gotten the bathroom/weekend rant out of the way I can pay homage to this great little bar.
 
Oh, Vesuvio, how I love thee. I love that the round tables upstairs were all designed by a local artist. I love that that artist hangs out in this bar and I have had the pleasure of speaking with him. I love that a cute old lady wanders in sometimes taking overpriced Polaroids of you, and I love that she actually relinquished her camera to be in one with us. I love that I have met so many awesome interesting people here. I love that City Lights books is right next door. I love that I can watch the people walking by below. I love the cozy decor and the nice bartenders. 

This is a great bar, but go on a weekday and either monitor your alcohol intake or wear flats....trust me on this one!
author: Drue C.

description: A good place to finish the night right.
author: Victoria F.

description: Drinks are delicious and cheap. Crowd is diverse and fun. Bartenders are friendly. I'm a fan.
author: Jason K.

description:
This is probably my favorite San Fran bar. Not too classy, not too divey. Always a diverse, non pretentious crowd.  No matter when I stop by it never seems too crowded or too dead.
A laid back place with a cool ambiance to chill with friends and have a few drinks. And of course, cool paraphernalia on the walls too keep things interesting.
Never too loud, so you can actually have a conversation that isn't a screaming match.  The service always seems good, no matter how busy it gets.  The wait staff works hard to make sure I can get a cool buzz.  Good times.
author: B J.

description:
I was standing in front of this bar having a cigarette, when a homeless man walks up to me and starts telling me a joke.  I can't remember the joke, only that it involved Michael Jackson.  I laughed, but didn't have a dollar, so I gave him a cigarette.  
And that's about it.  
That was the highlight of my night.  I wish I could tell you the joke.

That being said, it is a charming little historical bar in the heart of North Beach and I should have liked it.  I really wanted it to be good.  But unfortunately, it strikes me as boring.  Kind of like this review.   My bad.
author: Starla D.

description: If I could give negative stars I would--I have never been treated so poorly by waitresses...um if I want to order a drink at the bar IM GOING TO ORDER A DRINK AT THE BAR! Both waitresses were snooty and said we needed to order from them to sit down (after we had been sitting for 5 minutes!!), NEWS to me since I've been here a ton! Well I'm currently going to finish my drink and leave, you just lost 7 customers!
author: Colette V.

description: This place has history, it's next to City Lights, and it's got enough space to be able to sit and have a conversation. +1 for watching the bardender shut down some aspiring young barsexual girls who wanted free drinks if they'd make out with each other.
author: Mike O.

description:
A group of six of us had the most miserable experience at Vesuvio's on a Sunday afternoon.  We were a very normal group of six locals without any attitude or bad behavior and got very abused by the staff for reasons unknown.

The waitress was the rudest I have ever come across in some 20 years of going to bars in San Francisco and the bartender was another piece of work with a bad attitude.  A simple request to salt the rim of a glass (as originally ordered) on a second round of $52 in drinks (this brought our total to $104 with them) was met with a sneer by the waitress who said, "It IS salted" and left us but not before spilling some of one drink onto a friend's coat without so much as an apology or a clean up.  The coat now has to be dry cleaned and the spill was clearly intentional on her part.  

The person in our party who made the request for the salted glass went to the bartender to get it corrected and he was rude as well.  The waitress then glared at us everytime from then on. She never asked if we wanted anything else and obviously didn't want us there from the time we walked in.  When we left, another in our party told the bartender how we felt and he was just as rude.  The bartender denies what his unbelievably obnoxious reply was, but he is the only one taking that position.

I used to go to Vesuvio's but never will again and I have never had problems like this before anyplace else in the city.  I always try to be accommodating to busy staff and even to servers with bad attitudes.  These two were above and beyond the worst I've ever dealt with and are a perfect example of what is wrong with service in San Francisco.
author: MJ M.

description:
So for the record this is my #1 favorite place to start a night in the city! 
I love their lemon drop martinis! They are the best in the city if you ask me! 

The setting is great, it is an older bar so the interior is a little vintage.. and there is cool stuff all over the walls... The bartenders are amazing, also there is an upstairs with a bunch of tables and this place is right in the middle of North Beach.. so what else does a person really need!?!?!? 

Stop in check it out and have a beer!
author: Samantha R.

description:
Can the service here be any slower rude and just all around unpleasant?
I was with a large party and a group of my friends that just arrived ordered a round of drinks. 
The waitress : WOuld you like  to pay separate or all together. One of my friend: We would like to pay separate please.
The waitress: ugh! Great! like separate checks is going to make my job any easier! 
I mean she could have handeled it so many ways. A note: If  you are in the service industry and are this bitter, maybe it is time you leave the service industry. 
My friend who made the suggestion that we meet at Vesuvio's regreted her choice by the end of the night. 
I will never return to this North Beach establishment. My suggestion: Go to Tosca!
author: Jennifer S.

description:
Good God, I  miss this place.

Back in Oh-Two, when I lived in the City, I spent every Tuesday afternoon here.  Was in the neighborhood today, so I dropped in for an hour or so.  Chartreuse on the rocks, times three.  Twas Fantastic.
author: Mark S.

description:
One of my all time favorite bars.  It just represents San Francisco and it's right next to City Lights Bookstore.  It's great when you can sit upstairs and look out the window and observe.  I usually get Merlot ot Bailey's.  The Merlot is great and gives me just the right buzz and it's only $5!  
Everyone has to try this place at least once.  I guarantee you will come back.  I just love looking at all the signs and pictured all over the bar too.  
A great experience!
author: Christene M.

description:
It's a table of four...Jack Kerouac, Allen Ginsburg, Neal Cassady and myself. We're tucked away in a corner upstairs, looking down on the bar with a view of Columbus Avenue through the windows. Kerouac and Cassady are at again, and Ginsburg creepily staring downstairs in lust of young men.

This place, if for nothing else, is amazing because of its history. Next door to City Lights Books, it's cramped & stuffy with locals and tourists alike. The walls hold old photographs, drawings, and paintings from the beat era, and the chairs are worn.

Service at the bar was fairly poor, but there are cute cocktail waitresses who stop by and take drink orders every few minutes. Mixed drinks are strong! 

Was I sitting in the same chair as Kerouac once did? Before he and Neal Cassady drunkenly screeched down Columbus Avenue in 'On the Road', were they throwing back drinks here? I would like to think so.

5 stars for being part of literary and/or 'drunk cracka' history!
author: matt m.

description:
Vesuvio is a great bar.  It is well-decorated with nice photos and memorabilia from years past.  Like Katie C. said, it's a great spot for people watching and enjoying a beer or two.

They have great bartenders and cocktail waitresses, and great music when they play jazz on the in-house sound system.

The Vesuvio staff have always treated me with courtesy and respect, and I've always appreciated that.

For those of you who want to know how to act in bars, Jack can sell you a copy of his book, the "Dim Light Bar Guide".  Alternatively, you can pick up a copy from City Lights next door.

I'm also happy to know that management put up a framed photograph of bartender Jack and yours truly standing next to Vesuvio in Kerouac alley.

Apparently, the photographer from the San Francisco Chronicle was able to successful lobby for his feature, a series of photographs of notable locals, and we got into the Style section in May 2007.

My 15 minutes of fame might be gone.

Vesuvio, however, remains a timeless North Beach institution.
author: Justin C.

description: Strangley, this place always has people in it- never dead, never overcrowded. Seems like a tourist bar, but still always has a good atmosphere for beer chugging.
author: Jim B.

description: I came to this bar at the recommendation of a friend, and I think I can now say that I have come across the WORST SERVER I have ever encountered in my life. This girl obviously didn't want to serve us, so we had to flag her down or stop her on her way to somewhere else to get our drinks for us. It probably took less than 10 seconds to order our drinks overall, but during the ordering process, she gave us this b***** attitude and told us that there is a 10$ minimum for credit card and when my friend and I asked each other what else to order to fill up the minimum, she interrupted and said "ok, this is really heavy"(referring to the drinks she had in her hand for another table). It took literally less than 10 seconds to say, "we would like this", "there is a 10 dollar minimum", (we look at each other), "ok, this is really heavy", "we'll add one more beer". she comes back with the receipt, says absolutely nothing, slides it over by the edge of the table, then throws the pen on the table with the dirtiest attitude I have ever seen from a server. I was pretty pissed. I came home and got on Yelp to see if others had similar experiences. Sure enough there are several complaints on here about the same server chick. Seems like others went as far as to complain to the bartender and the manager, only to have gotten another slap on the face. I guess I'm glad I kept my cool and didn't bother complaining to the manager cause I would have definitely thrown a crap show. Obviously, this place is popular so she must not be rude to everyone that goes there. As a matter of fact, she was very friendly to the table next to us. I don't know what made this psycho want to be rude to us, but if I were you, I would not take the chance to see if she likes you or not. stay away from this place.
author: James C.

description: One of my many old hang-outs in San Francisco.  Great atmosphere and great locations.  Wait staff was always nice and the drimks were awesome as well.
author: Daniel C.

description:
I love me some booze.  I get really claustrophobic with places though...this is one of them.  For some reason though it's been the default place for my friends to meet up. 

Wanna use a credit card?  Psych!!!!  Fuck no you won't!!!  Yeah...so what that there's a credit card machine at the bar....the OG bartender will NOT take it....he has better shit to do with his time...like make me MY drink!!!  Better sit your ass down and have the waitress do it for you.  

Oh yeah....want anything with soda water?  Psych AGAIN bitches!!!  That shit is flat....and the reason?  "That's how our soda water comes out."  Deal beyotches...this place gots HISTORY!!! Jack Kerouac drank here fools! You can't step to that shit!
author: Jay H.

description: Vesuvio rocks! This place has awesome drinks, way cool no attitude and quick to service bartenders, plenty of seating but still manages to get super packed and I can see why. Tons of character..there are pictures of old SF plastered all over the place, artwork by local artists. The upstairs is less packed, a little darker and better if you want to go a bit more incognito. My only gripe is that they need more bathrooms! A great time to take some out of towners..you'll find plenty of those there as well as locals. A definite go-back!
author: Grace C.

description:
Step back in time when you enter this hip and rustic bar that once was host to some of the west coast most famous and influential poets and writers. It's seems as though very little has changed in this bar since it's beginnings except for the bartenders.

It's always a friendly and laid-back atmosphere every time I go there and the folks who are there drinking tend to be very approachable and cool. Although I've never ordered a mixed drink while I'm there, I can tell you that their beer is always fresh and very cold. They have a great happy hour and plenty of space to find a table for you and a date or a group of friends.

I like stopping in here after going to Washington Square Park or that general vicinity for a couple pints. A must-see for any tourist!
author: Gabriel R.

description:
May 11, 2007 @ 8:45pm: Birthday pub crawl continues.  I got in, went upstairs, straight for the bathroom, I really needed to go.  The wall in the women's bathroom was covered with fernet labels, I was happy and ready for my 5th shot of fernet.  I walked towards my friends at the table upstairs and demanded fernet.  

Not only did I have my fifth fernet shot at Vesuvio the night of my quarter century birthday, I also had number six, seven, eight and nine.  Yes, I was wasted, sloshed, soused, plastered, hammered, boozed up, seeing double, tanked, and very liquored up.  I did however still managed to go down the stairs without any help and do a bit of hula hooping.  Before leaving the bar, I drank water, tons of water from a pitcher... it was awesome!  

It's a pretty chill bar -- nicely decorated and the upstairs is a great place for people watching.  The bartenders/servers seem to be in good moods and even kept a smile on their face when they had to clean up 2 broken glasses.  No, it wasn't me that broke it, I can't remember who, but I know for sure it wasn't me.   

Fernet Count at Vesuvio: 5 
- 5th shot from Trevor
- 6th shot from Ronnie
- 7th shot from Stanley
- 8th shot from Stanley
- 9th shot from Lisa

"It was Vesuvio that drove me into drinking beers -- my friends and I enjoyed pitchers and pitchers of Amstel Light here on May 7, 2004.  Ever since then, I've become a beer addict.  This bar will always hold a special place in my heart.  I love this place because of the memories.  Thanks Vesuvio :-)!

Ended my birthday with a total of 10 shot of Fernet at North Star and I know that because of the initials of people who bought me those shots written on my arm with a black Sharpie pen -- it's my new tattoo (JJLKTRSSLS)!
author: Celeste M.

description: dont like the service there, though the second floor does have nice decor!
author: Shuting Z.

description:
Ok, so I was only here once. And it was at 8 a.m. But I still have to give it 4 stars because it opens so early and because of the following story:

My friend said that for his 30th birthday he wanted to drink from dawn to dusk and of course we obliged. Vesuvio opens at 7. I had friends visiting so didn't get there until 8, but when I walked in another friend (who isn't a big drinker) came up to me and said "I just threw up".

Any bar that has patrons who puke at 8 a.m. deserves 4 stars.
author: Suge K.

description:
Fantasical museum of the "Beats." There's supposedly some Beat museum that charges actually money to enter. Forget that. The only dollars that are flying out of your pocket at Vesuvio are going towards the great beers on tap. Meanwhile, trip out on the neverending photos and "vintage" SF history about Kerouac, the Beats, the Merry Pranksters, and all the cool mo fos that helped shape SF into the liberal radical town that we are. 

Cheers mates!
author: Braden B.

description: My all time favorite bar.  The history (The Beats) is still relevant today with them just accross the alley from City Lights Bookstore.  Great place for an afternoon of Happy Hour drinks.  No food but plenty of good talk and vibes.  Mike the bartender is an awesome host making everyone feel welcomed.  If you are in SF don't miss the opportunity to visit.  It does get crowded inthe evening but they do have upstairs seating as well.
author: Kevin P.

description: Definitely not my favorite place, particularly in terms of crowd/patrons or service, but it's a San Francisco institution, and if you haven't been, you must.   Gets extremely crowded on weeknight nights, but week days, particularly earlier in the evening are pretty easy going.  When it's crowded, I prefer to stake out a table upstairs, which have servers/table service.  It will certainly take a lot longer to get your drinks, but at least you don't have to deal with the bartenders, who range from hostile to just.. inattentive.   Upstairs is not bad for groups, particularly in early evening or week nights.  Great views of the street from the back tables up top!
author: Heidi M.

description:
Vesuvio is one the the great bars in The City...hell, one of the great bars, period.  Atmospheric, great cheap drinks, bartenders that know their craft (kudos to big Mike!) Vesuvio is people-watching central. I love taking a seat upstairs overlooking Columbus, and Kerouac Alley, and Tosca, and Specs, chilling with a highball and watching the world pass by.  And still open at 6 AM?!  LOVE THIS PLACE!

I just posted a video about this classic joint.  Take a look at http://bit.ly/9k4S0h
author: Dennis C.

description: This Old Prospector-looking guy sitting at the bar--a local--quipped,  "Thank you for sitting next to me.  You're the first non-Italian person to sit on this bar today."  Granted, the atmosphere was filled with joy and celebration after Italy won the 2006 World Cup, this really cute 2-story establishment is filled with both tourists and locals.    The bartender makes sure he squeezes a full lime for my mojito... which was actually very good.  There was a local Latino Arts event happening in the alley nextdoor, and I was even able to take my mojito outside.  Great location, only a walking distance to the local strip clubs, and other North Beach establishments, this place is closed only 4 hours of the day.... check this place out to see some private dancers, including myself, destressing after a hard day at work. ;)
author: Grace M.

description:
Yet another of North Beach's great, historic watering holes! 

First off, Vesuvio is not someplace you want to schedule your next party bus of 30 guests to stop at. There is simply not enough room. And it's not that kind of place. So please don't do it.

This is a spot where you can have a few drinks with friends and feel like you're surrounded by and being a part of history yourself.

There is something special about a place that's been around as long as it has been. 

This is a place where ideas are born.
author: John Eric S.

description: Lots of tradition, but it's a bit touristy these days.  Stop in for a pint and check it out.
author: Dave C.

description:
I can't stand Jack Kerouac or any of that crowd for that matter. They were misoginist jerks who couldn't have done anything if they didn't have women taking care of there babies and supporting them after they spent all there money on drugs and alcohol.

That said. I love this bar! It may be a tourist attraction, but as you can see from the above comment I came here DISPITE the fact that Kerouac used to hang out here not because of it. It's just a great old school bar with good lighting, great crowd, friendly bartenders and stiff drinks. If this was in Santa Cruz I would be a regular. For sure.
author: Tracey W.

description:
Back, almost a decade back, this was my first bar in San Francisco.
And back, a few years ago, when I was planning on leaving SF, this
was the last bar I went to, before catching the plane.


I've been coming here for years, not as a regular, but every now and
again, every few months, or weeks, depending on the ebbs and flows
of life. 


The bar tenders may not be the friendliest. The area may not be
the best. And I have nothing good, or bad, to say about their drinks
as I tend to order basic things. Beer. Scotch. A whiskey sour/soda 
every now and again.


There is something about this place that keeps me returning to
it year after year, getting a drink, going to the 2nd floor and watching
the people around, and on the street. A fine place to kill a few hours.


For me? 5 stars. For you? I do not know.
author: Max R.

description:
I went here a lot in grad school.....That's probably why I don't go there very often now, it reminds me of post exam drinking/bitching fests.  

FYI - The stairs can be treacherous in heels.
author: Nikki c.

description: Small spot in North Beach, right next to Cookhouse, it seemed pretty packed for a Friday Afternoon. They have tons of beer on tap, but i just came in here for one drink because they were still setting up at Cookhouse. Anyways, hence the 3 stars, i will have to come back to try it out again.
author: Benjamin L.

description:
I honestly don't know what the big deal is about this place.  It was OK at best.  It was packed, HOT, and kinda smelly.  I've been there a few times (not really by choice) and have had OK experiences.  The wait staff wasn't very friendly - well at least the chick that waited on us.

I can think of 10 other places around the corner that I'd rather visit.
author: Noneya B.

description:
San Francisco is a drinking town in its own right. We have great wine just over the bridge, great craft ales and beers brewed within the city limits, many choices of other speciality alcohol (gin, vodka, etc) and a cold damp fog that persists for most of the year, which in my mind further necessitates the need for a spirit to lift your mood and warm your face and belly. Lately, I've been in my own mental funky fog. I've been brooding over stuff like Lent and work and tattoos and meaning and other assorted crap. I need to go and straighten the swarm out in a place I will refer to as a "Think and Drink". Vesuvio's in North Beach fits this description nicely. 

A San Francisco landmark that a legend in its own time. It sparks on the instant nostalgia simliar to that of cable cars, Golden Gate park via the Haight, the Golden Gate bridge without assuming a level of pretentiousness you'd almost expect this bar to have. It's both a solo day drinkers bar and a tourist destination for those seeking out what once was a hub of the beat movement (or a place to take out of towners where drinking is a main attraction!)

Just so you know (in case you didn't get the point from other reviews) this is SO not a place to pick up on people. It's too kick back to try. You can't help but chill and get absorbed by a comfy atmosphere to your own inner happy Zen drinking space (as opposed to the party my ass off drinking space). If you've never done this at a bar, this is a good place to practice. The views from the second floor are perfect for absently gazing while your thoughts and the alcohol take over. I think I'm overdue for a visit and just one more reason to love San Francisco.
author: Veronica G.

description:
Great bar, cozy atmosphere, and I love the upstairs space with big windows that let's you look out into the neighborhood of Jack Kerouac. The stringed lights and quirky knickknacks along the walls and the bar definitely gives the place some authentic character - nothing cookie-cutter about it. 

On a not-so-crowded weeknight, this is a fantastic hangout spot if you want to catch up with some old friends (which was what I was there for) or have the perfect end of the evening drinks for a first date (which was what the couple sitting next us were there for. Not that I was eavesdropping...)

Anywho... 

My D.O.C. - Sweet Tea Vodka. A perfect combination - the sweetness of iced tea with the dizziness of vodka, all at a very reasonable $6. That's pretty darn cheap! I've been here twice and so far this is the only drink I've ordered thus far, just because I'm pretty much in love with it. 

If I live in SF, this spot would definitely be a regular of mine. For all you SF visitors, be sure to enjoy this great local scene after you're done with all the touristy stuff. It's probably time anyway you take a break from looking through postcards and endless Golden Gate Bridge refrigerator magnets.
author: Andy L.

description:
Sometimes when I find myself in North Beach on a beautiful spring or summer afternoon, I'll think to myself, "Golly gee, Thomas.  It's such a pretty day today.  How's about soaking up some of San Francisco's finest literary history and doing some writing of your own?"

To which I'll say, much to the confusion of those around me, "Vesuvio it is, then."  And then I'll walk through that front door (next to Jack Kerouac Alley, no less!), belly up to that beautiful bar and order a Guinness.

This isn't just a bar, per se.  It's a bona fide (that means Bono likes it) INSTITUTION.  The vibe is infectious, and if you listen really, really close, you can hear the spirits of this city's great legacy of poetry speaking to you.  Or, you can hear the spirits being poured.  Whichever, this is a wonderful place to bring your buddies, sit upstairs, and have lovely conversations surrounded by the world that comfortably envelops you in its warm embrace.

It's a bar that makes you feel good, and at one with yourself and whomever you happen to be with.

Yes!  My 25th review!
author: Thomas B.

description:
5 stars for the atmosphere.  

It doesn't get any better than walking up the stairs to the 2nd floor, snagging a table by the window, and drinking/talking all afternoon.  I introduced Mario to this place one day, & I think he fell a little more in love with me.  No, really.  No, really.
author: Holly F.

description:
This place is damn cool.  It gets a bonus star because of its history, but the first time I came here, I didn't know about its history, and I still thought it was damn cool.

The bartenders are friendly, and that's pretty impressive considering the annoying tourist crap they probably have to deal with.  It's very relaxing sitting in here in broad daylight, which is something I can't say for many bars.
author: John S.

description: Cool bar, super packed but still really cool. They had some good beers on tap and the service was great. The decor was a little eclectic... like a hipster version of TGI Friridays, or Applebees. Would I go back? Definitely - tons of fun and the patrons are as nice as the staff!
author: Rich P.

description:
I popped my cherry at Vesuvio's in 2001.  I had just turned legal (to drink) and it was the first bar I visited in the city.   Oh the good ol' times... when I could get tipsy of a couple drinks.  

Any who, this historic saloon is known to attract people from all walks of life inculding artists, cab drivers, seamen, college students, the business crowd, visitors and exotic dancers who are off the clock.   Good crowd and even better atmosphere.  I'd recommend Vesuvio's for a drink or 2 if you feel like soaking up some local culture.
author: Shiho F.

description:
I think I spent a hundred bucks on drinks here. But I was buying for three. I sat in a booth next to a photo of Lawrence Ferlinghetti, while my friend, esteemed poet of nature, Joe Massey, sat beneath Kerouac.

We drank Anchor Steams, whiskey and sodas, and had a pleasant time. Good, chill atmosphere. No loud music.  Really cool bathrooms.
author: Anthony R.

description:
If I can rate this joint by half a star I would. I had a chance to walk down Columbus and see that "famous" Vesuvio bar that was pretty laid-back busy bar for Sunday morning. Lady, if I can call her that, greeted me with "You can't take the pictures of the people at the bar!", seeing that I just finished taking some cool pics of the architecture and modern paintings outside. I happened to shut off my camera before I even entered the bar, but she still took the freedom, without even asking, to remove my camera and act tough like my
plan was, instead of ordering vodka-cranberry to actually take photos of the people at the bar!!!!!....Where did she get that idea I don't know.
I just know that I was kicked out for no particular reason by this overweight bartender that obviously was lacking some attention that she wanted to gain by throwing me out and making a drama
over something that she imagined in her little bitter brain. I was more than polite, but she insisted on numerous name callings in front of her costumers that were rolling their eyes, listening to her gipsy-style monologue.
I expected much much more from Vesuvio, will do my best to contact the owners of this joint and introduce them with "impeccable attitude" their bartender represented on Sunday morning (October, 3rd around 11:30)
Would highly recommend this place if you feel like being misstreated and name called. This person is disgrace to costumer service and horrible representative of SF bar scene. 
She didn't waste her time continuing to call me different names infront of her 7-8 people audience, even as I was leaving.
Something needs to be done, this person removed from behind the bar as she obviously cannot handle people and service. There is soooo many good looking, younger women, with friendly and superlative personalities that would gladly work and make people welcomed at Vesuvio.
I am dusguisted with her dirty, possible drunk, mouth.
author: Milan V.

description:
How I ended up at this bar twice in the span of 12 hours is beyond me... But it was pretty damn fun both times.

This is the perfect place to get to know that attractive someone you met at a nearby (but way too loud) bar on a Saturday night.  It is also a really good place to meet friends on Sunday afternoon, sip some damn good mexican coffee (even better than the balboa), and watch the hours go by.

Minus two stars because the door guy wouldn't let me in at 1:45am...plus one star because the door guy eventually let me in after my friend inside offered to flash him....plus one more star for said flash =)
author: D S.

description:
My friend is one of those literary Beat generation wanna be's and he loves this spot. He loves how Bob Dylan got kicked out of here back in the day. He loves how its wedged between City Lights and Jack Kerouac Alley. He loves the whole ambiance of the Bar, every little thing from the hand painted tables to the photos of by-gone generation of Beats that populated North Beach in the 50's.

I love it 'cause it is a time hole that gives me a little peek in to the period of San Francisco that appeals to me most. A period of San Francisco that yelled out be different. A time that taught us to stand up for a cause or a way of life that one believes in. To this day, that theology is still embraced by the city and i hope it never lets go.
author: Tak H.

description: I love this place. Has become my standard stop after grabbing a couple books at City Lights. Their upstairs is a great place to look out at the SF streets, or people watch around the bar. The atmosphere is lively and friendly, and I dig the decor. Fun place.
author: Nick P.

description:
Before I discovered Kennedy's this was my regular watering hole. 

This is a real laid back spot. I love going next door to City Lights Books, getting a book to read, then coming next door to Vesuvio and reading over a couple pints of Anchor Steam in the upstairs area.

They also have showcase works from local artists that gets switched out every two weeks, giving you something new to check out every few weeks. 

Definitely not a place to go for a crazy "dude's night out" type bar experience. Vesuvio is more geared toward smaller groups who want to hang out in a chill setting and have a couple drinks.
author: Tommy P.

description:
I likey Vesuvio. A lot.

Historical and artistic significance? Check and check

Unpretentious staff? Check

Eclectic crowd? Check

Cheap drinks? Check 

Honest to goodness cool bar without obnoxious tourist/bridge & tunnel/sorority/frat presence despite being in a neighborhood known for attracting such types on the weekends? CHECK
author: Jenny K.

description:
I usually love this place. It's a true San Francisco jem of a saloon. Neat atmosphere, sweet ass upstairs seating, decently priced beverages... 
When friends and I are in North Beach and looking for a place to go, I suggest Vesuvio.
My last experience with Vesuvio though, a near train wreck. If it wasn't for my friends and I's extreme patience and willingness to deal with a crappy waitress, we would have made a scene. 
We got to Vesuvio early on a Saturday night. There were about 3 tables open upstairs, and we snatched one. We sat there about ten minutes. We saw the waitress come upstairs, go to a table, get their order, and go back downstairs to place the order. Is it really that hard to do a whole round of the floor, see what everyone wants, and get us all at the same time. Top capacity up here is like 20, lady!
Anyway, a booth cleared out and we, of course, snatched that in place of the small round table. It was another 10 minutes or so before the waitress finally made her way to the back side of the upstairs to get our drinks. 
1 rum and coke
1 Jameson straight
1 IPA
She takes our order, leaves, comes back about 5 minutes later with our beverages, we pay in cash, and we're happy.
Then, a group of about 8 older gentlemen walk in. Now let me tell you something about Vesuvio, if you've never been there, it's not a place for groups of more than 4..ever. But, in an attempt to make money, the waitress pushed together the 3 available tables, and sat the whole group together. What she didn't think about, is that she pushed the tables together right in front of our booth making it impossible for us to get in and our of our booth without requiring at least 4 people to stand up, move their chairs and tables, and let us squeeze through. 
Not only was it not effective when your bladder said "I'm full!!", but the waitress was now also unable to give us ANY decent customer service. She was now having to ask the men at the table to ask us if we needed a drink. We ordered with the old guy, he told the dumb waitress. This went on for about 30 more minutes until i finally said 'no more'.
As I attempted to squeeze out of my booth asking the large group to, once again, all move out of the way for one of us to get out, I kindly suggested that they move their table grouping about a foot off the ledge of the balcony. Not only would this open up a walk way to allow us in and out of our booth, it would allow the waitress a walkway, and wouldn't be blocking any other tables from leaving which is a HUGE fire hazard. I thought it was a fine solution. 
Understandably, at this point, the table was irritated with us. I'm sorry I'm a smoker dude, and I'm sorry that the idiot waitress has no brain, but don't get mad at me!
The one man, presumably head of the table, looked at me after making my suggestion and said "what are you, a high school graduate?". "Excuse me, sir", I replied, "Are you trying to insult me!?". 
As you can imagine, a few words were exchanged between me and this other irritated patron. It ended with me reminding him that insulting a young woman in front of his 7 fellow adult male friends was a sure fine way of making him look like a jackass. He apologized, I accepted it, and they moved their effing table, like I suggested. 
Finally, we could breath again.
About 15 minutes later, after our drinks had been empty for over 20, the pea-brained waitress comes back to see how we're doing. I kindly express to her the frustration we've had being locked into the booth by a group of older men who clearly were irritated every time one of us had to use the bathroom. I showed her that had it been thought out, there was room to sit the group without blocking any surrounding tables. I  advised her that due to fire safety standards, there are times in which a small bar may need to turn down a large group it does not have the capacity for, and lastly, i expressed to her my utter disappointment with her customer service (ordering beer thru another patron, REALLY!?).
The waitress was clear that she didn't give a crap about how she had made us feel. She said with a clear sarcastic 'I don't even care about you' voice, "I can see that you're not happy, is there anything I can do?". I told her I didn't want anything from her but our bill, and the hope that next time she has a group come in that she wouldn't block the patrons at the booth and ruin their experience at Vesuvio the way she ruined ours.
She looked at me, rolled her eyes, and said "I'll just cover your last round, is that good enough?"
I told her that was fine, and my friends and I left. 
Can I say I'll never go back? No. Vesuvio doesn't deserve to get a bad reputation from one crappy waitress...but I'll surely walk out, down Jack Kerouac Alley, and over to the Buddha Bar next time I see her coming toward my table.
author: Sarah J.

description:
