i hate peeing here.  That being said, I still come to Vesuvio for a quick (or long) night of drinking.  Why not?  This is still a cute hangout, and if you manage to score a table up at the top, you can almost peek into the venues across the street to catch an eyeful.
  ;-)

The gals upstairs took care of our table of 4, no 5, no 7... I think we finally gave up after much beer, cider and a couple rounds of Jack Kerouac's were consumed.  All aboard!!
author: Anonymouse C.

description:
There is really nothing more that can be said about this chill ass bar, that hasn't already been said. My favorite time to go is a Monday afternoon, so I can grab a seat by the front window with my beer. They play cool jazz on the hi-fi, that soothes my ears and allows me to relax.

Then I just watch the world around me move in all directions.
author: Eric B.

description:
This is absolutely my favorite bar. If I were to give you one place to go in San Fran, it would be here.
Very "hole in the wall" atmosphere. That's what I thought it was at first, it was very happenstance that I end up there on a Thursday night at 2 AM. Very fitting actually. I was just checking out the City Lights Bookstore right across the way, and had no clue of their connection. I love a historical bar. The lay out of the whole place is beautiful. The old staircase, all the pictures on the walls. Low, almost no lighting. Perfection in a dive bar. I wish I had been there in the 60s.
author: Alexandra L.

description:
Love this bar! Great atmosphere, perfect place to hangout and grab a drink with friends. Waitress was always there when we needed her. Drinks were strong and inexpensive. Sat upstairs near one of the open windows and watched as people walked by outside and took pictures of the alley. 
Will definitely be back.
author: Tia T.

description: One of the best bars around! I love this place from the top window seat upstairs to the dusty artifacts that have collected over time. I can feel the creative energy and the historic past as soon as walk in. I usually sit upstairs, but the banter at the bar of the North Beach locals always makes me smile. Good beer selection, great drinks and the bartender that works weekend morning shifts can make a hell of a Extra spicy Bloody Mary. I usually go in there for a drink and end up spending  a few hours longer than I planned-It's easy to get lost in the atmosphere. A true treasure of the neighborhood and of The City. Thanks Vesuvio! You RULE!!
author: Mel Z.

description:
Aside from the Saloon nearby, this is my 2nd favorite bar in all of the city.  Such history and ambiance here.  I'll never forget the first time my roommate and I visited the bar.

We were both in our Jack Kerouac "On the Road" mode, and just decided to soak in all the residual "Beat" energy in North Beach.  No sooner do we step in, after being carded and having to wait for a few people to step out of the bar, do we head to the bar and see Lawrence Ferlinghetti himself, sitting alone at the corner of the bar!  Incredible experience.  He was absolutely red-faced and didn't look like he was up for much socializing, so we placed our order, hung out downstairs for a bit, trying to look like we weren't staring;  

As soon as our fanaticism faded (it was a good hour or so), we headed upstairs and finally found a seat - we still had drinks in hand, but I guess one of the obligations of the privileged few who find a great seat overlooking the surrounding streets is that you can't not order anything from an eager server dying to get you another drink for a fabulous tip!  We just kept those drinks coming and the whole experience was more lucid.

Soon, there was a packed crowd, everywhere, with barely any walking room at all and a live band set up downstairs.  Ferlinghetti had disappeared so we did the only logical thing there was to do in that situation - we promptly headed over to neighboring City Lights bookstore to see if he was there!  He wasn't  - so we headed back to Vesuvio's...  Seeing him there was enough to make it a positively wonderful memorable experience.  We've visited Vesuvio's many times since.
author: Olma M.

description: Came here around 3:30 on a weekday. Sat on the second floor in a table next to a window. Definitely an interesting place to sit since you can watch everyone walking by on the street.
author: Pish P.

description: We got lucky - about two minutes after we walked in we found seats at the bar, which we proceeded to occupy for the next couple of hours, happily sipping pitchers and shots at totally reasonable prices (about $20 each for a great time).  The crowd was mellow, the bartenders friendly and the interior itself strangely fascinating, like the inside of a yacht/hobbit's den.  And of course, around the corner from the Broadway experience, and plenty of hotels to lay low in afterwards.  Great times, indeed.
author: Byung Ho B.

description:
Wow. If you want to have a drink in a cool place and are really craving some bitchy service, definitely go here. I was amazed by our waitress. The service wasn't slow or inaccurate, it was just really really bitchy.

The two stars are purely for the service - the drinks were fine and the place seemed cool. But those factors don't take precedence over the horrible service. Slender chick with short dark hair, I'm talking to you - and your manager.

I'd go here again, but I would order from the bar. I'd rather give feel compelled to tip the person who actually poured my drink, rather than to the bitch who lowered herself to bring it me.
author: Shal J.

description:
A friend once told me that everyone has a lounge/bar that they call theirs, and mine is the Vesuvio.

One day I walked in with my friends for Happy Hour, and it was as if we were there thousands of times.  Vesuvio has this charming vibe that allows you to just sit and relax, while still aware of all the rich history of SF around us.  

This almost 50 years old bar always provoked some deep soul searching on my part.  I wondered who was sitting at the same place I was 50 years ago, and what were they doing.  I also wondered what happened to all the poets and artists that hang around here drawing their inspiration from this place.  

Enough said.  I am definitely proud to say that this is my joint.
author: Gin H.

description:
historical: check
good drinks: check
good times: check
awesome people: check
a place where Jack Keroauc frequented: double check
view of sex shops/strip clubs: check (I'm a super classy chick ;-) )

This is the place to be.
author: Joan S.

description:
There are basically two types of bars:

1) bars where you go to pick up/get picked up and/or watch people pick up/get picked up (and drink, of course); and
2) bars where you go SIMPLY to drink.

Vesuvio falls squarely into the second category. The perfect spot for a completely low-key, raucous post-post happy hour.
author: Deb I.

description:
When you want a straight up drink with good friends, who may or may not be from out of town, Vesuvio's rarely fails.

The interior is very cute. Vintage posters are on the walls along with old newspaper articles, photographs and other little slices of history. Upstairs there are small tables in a small balcony. It's like a 2nd story run through the Xerox at 75% reduction. Applebee's would love to look like Vesuvio, but Vesuvio's doesn't have the canned atmosphere created by the right number of pieces of flair.

The clientele is usually a congenial mix of tourists and locals who dig eclectic locales. 

The drinks are decent and reasonably priced, but don't count on anything fancy. One of barmen is a serious pain, I tip him accordingly.
author: Claudius R.

description: Vesuvio is my absolute favorite bar in San Francisco. I love the vibe, the feeling you get thinking of the people that had drinks there before you. It's close to everything and its not overly pretentious. Great place to just relax and have a drink!
author: Danielle F.

description:
Great place to come, sit upstairs, have a late afternoon beer and watch the world go by.  In the arvo. it's pretty empty so seating is not an issue, but later it gets real busy. They have a great beer selection, and lots to look at, which will inevitably lead to you reminiscing with your drinking friends about that "On the Road" phase everyone went through in high school.
Yes, at night it gets packed with tourists, but that's what you get in North Beach. And what the hell is wrong with hanging out with people from other places and being exposed to new accents, ideas, and dress styles? 

Disclaimer: This review is written by a native Australian, who once was a tourist but now lives here.
author: MissSkip Z.

description:
Wow!  Nasty reviews from people who apparently take the Yelp in yelp quite literally! Vesuvio is not the kind of bar you go into for a diaper change or ego massage, and y'know, if there's not enough  salt on your glass rim, maybe the bartender is so low-key nurturing that he or she thinks you oughta cut down on the sodium, Mr. or Mrs. "They always treat me like royalty at the local TGI Friday's".

The problem with places that make everybody happy is that  Everybody keeps going there.

Give me an establishment that sneers in the collective face of those ignorant, egocentric patrons who seem to think the bar prototype should be based on the ability to satisfy the masses over the value of the patrons.  Not many of those left these days, but one of them is Vesuvio, and if it doesn't fit your standards of service (by the way, most of those who enjoy Vesuvio have worked in the service industry) then go where the other princes and princesses go, where the service is as flawless as those being served.
author: J B.

description:
Vesuvio reminds me of my favorite bar in Oxford, MS that was located next to an alley where Faulkner was said to take a cozy nap after polishing off an impressive amount of whiskey and Coke. His personal style was an inspiration to us all, and I'm not talking about his purported lack of punctuation.

Understandably, whiskey and literary greats have a special place in my heart, and the ghosts of the past really do color the mood of a building for decades to come. And for that reason alone, I love this bar. 
 
Tips for optimum Vesuvio drinking: Better to order from the bar. Come during off hours. Devote all of your concentration to the precarious stairs when you're climbing and descending them. Most importantly, be open to talking to complete strangers. You'll be glad you did. (Unless you don't like characters. Then you probably don't need to be going to Vesuvio.)
author: Jill C.

description: Always dig the Kerouac cocktail (Only have one or two, they're strong). Whenever I find myself in North Beach I always swing by City Lights and pick up a book and then head across the alley to here for a cocktail and some people watching out the second floor window. There's also plenty of stuff on the walls to just roam around and check out. If you're into the Beat Culture of Keroac and Ginsberg, this is a fun place to check out.
author: Justin P.

description:
Despite living here my entire life, I finally made it to Vesuvio with some folks from work on a recent Thursday afternoon and I have to say...better late than never!

I dig the exterior, feel and history of this bar. I dig the funky bathrooms, narrow staircases and strange odors in certain parts of this bar. I dig all the stuff that is in this bar, and wish I got to see the old-school projector at work. I dig the upstairs seating in this bar because it affords you great views of Columbus and Broadway Streets.

The bartender, Janet (who is also part owner), was way cool and hooked us up with a round of shots of Patron tequila. She said she did this to make up for the fact that the other bartender briefly ran off with my boss' corporate card when she went to grab lunch. He'll have to see if there are any "surprises" on his next bill but hey, free tequila.
author: Art D.

description:
The kind of bar I'd hang out in were it not a tourist mecca. That said, this is a need to go to. Go to City Lights next door, buy a book, and then come to Vesuvio to sit, drink, and read.

This afternoon while on my walkabout, I stopped in for a quick 7&7. $5.50, but well mixed, and the bar staff was friendly and funny. Sounds like they're going to have Secret Santas this year. One rule: You have to work there to participate!
author: Heath R.

description:
Hands down, an awesome bar.   Great for people watching, sitting back casually and enjoying a beer or two, and admiring a lot of fun stuff posted on the walls...

My friends and I came here the other night, a few days before Halloween and watched a dude in a Barrel of Monkeys costume grope and maul this woman in all camo attire.  It was the funniest thing I have seen in a long time.

Thank you, Vesuvio!!
author: Katie C.

description: The inside and outside of this place has no pretense.  WYSIWYG.  It's too chill for my taste, and feels a little stuffy.  I'd come here if it was one stop in a string of bars.
author: Erika C.

description:
Pretty cool place. Decent beer selection. (I was a weekday night, couldn't have my usuals, so sad.) Server lady with the short black hair: really nice and attentive. Thank you.
I used to come here a bit more over a decade ago. The place is much cleaner, and the clientele as well. (The late 80's early 90's artist types were not known for being clean.)
author: Kione E.

description:
Me likes.

We popped in for a quick beer, post North Beach Italian dinner. Luckily, it wasn't too crowded - and we didn't mind the small crowd of tourists that had gathered beside us. Especially since we got to coo over the throng of Irish accents.

2 floors and generous seating available. Great ambiance (dark yet authentic to the old world bars) and fascinating local history, a la Jack Kerouac.

-1 Star because it took forever to get the bartender's attention.
author: Ro D.

description:
A place with history! This place has been around for a long time. I live in San Francisco for 8 years now and I recommend this place to anyone who is here for a short stay or a long one, because it shows what SF is all about. 

It's a small place that has 2 floors and some amazing arts on the walls. They serve good beer and other alcohol there. I usually come there for beer :-) 

I always meet people from England, Germany and Ireland at Vesuvio...the crowd makes it even better! 

It's not trendy and honestly I get tired of trendy restaurants and bars. I want to be able to see the history behind the place, to hear stories, see some old pictures from 30 years ago. Vesuvio is the place!!! Their prices are great, good selection of beer and the setting is all worth being there.
author: Katja S.

description:
I invited a few out-of-towners to Vesuvio -- excitedly I said: "Jack Kerouac used to hang out there!"

I was greeted by blank stares.

"You know, the book 'On the Road'? Beat poets?" More blank stares.

Anyway, apparently not everyone appreciates the history of the place, but even with out that, Vesuvio is a great place to get your drink on. Get a pitcher or two and sit upstairs to watch the happenings on Columbus street.
author: Dan V.

description: Rad bar, great staff, and killer ambiance.
author: Gina G.

description: I've only been here once for a nice cold afternoon beer. Prices were average but the cool breezes flowing from the open upstairs windows and the view of the street made for a wonderful afternoon. I would most definately come back here.
author: AL S.

description: I and a friend went in after spending time in the bookstore hoping to grab an appetizer and a drink.  They do not serve food.  But that is not my problem...the waitress was HORRIBLE!!!!  Neither of us drink alcohol but had dinner plans in the area and just wanted to spend some down time before our meal.  My friend ordered a virgin bloody mary and I asked if the bar had any specialty non-alcohol drinks.  The waitress responded "We don't do that here"!  She never tried to help with a suggestion.  I was so shocked by her lack of service and her aggressive manner that I just ordered a glass of water.  When she brought my friends drink she said "that will be $4".  My friend tried to hand her a debit card and the waitress rudely stated "We do not accept those for less than $10".  Neither I nor my friend had cash.  We explained we did not have cash and were sort of expecting her to assist us with solving the issue.  Instead she states "I can add a $6 tip"!!!!!  What????!!!!  By this point we felt like we both had been bitchslapped one too many times by this rude excuse of person.  We looked at her and said "Fine, I think we will just leave now".  She kept coming at us....as we were leaving she follows us yelling "Are you trying to tell me you don't even have $4 cash??".   I was so disturbed by this employee's behavior that I called the manager/owner later.  I know EXACTLY why that employee behaved that way.  The manager/owner was just as rude and could have cared less!!!!  I will never ever ever return!  They would get a big fat zero if yelp allowed it.
author: T S.

description:
This place represents the real North Beach. Vesuvio's, Specs, Cafe Trieste, City Lights Book Store, and a few other establishments fall under this category. I love sitting on the second story, drinking bloody marys, or beer, and watching the people down one the street on a warm SF night. 

Plus, Joanna is a cocktail waitress extraordinaire.
author: Christina S.

description:
Delivers on the San Francisco vibe with local favorites. 
Very Bohemian, but a yuppie clientele. 

Disclaimer. I went on a Monday night. 

Clean Bathrooms.
author: Luke H.

description: Came here on a whim with a friend late at night. Downed a few henny's. I really liked the decor, but I did not stay long here. Seems like a nice place to hang out
author: Michael C.

description:
Vesuvio -- I know my parents preferred Speck's, but I got to say Vesuvio is a great place on a weekday afternoon.  

Beatniks, history and all that - really, so what at this point that was like 3 generations ago, and North beach is now a giant tourist trap.

Vesuvio though is a great place, fully worth going to simply to sip a Jameson rocks and look out from the balcony at the street mull over the passers by.
author: Gustie L.

description:
I had a blast at this place, especially as someone visiting San Francisco for the first time.  I think what made the experience even better was sitting on the upper floor at the extreme front of the place.  The view out the open window (past the street sign announcing "Jack Kerouac Alley") was terribly interesting people watching.  Really captured the San Francisco I had built up in my mind.

And a good time was had by all.
author: Mitchell M.

description: I love this place. It can be crowded at night, but during the day it's a great place to hang out. Last time I was there was between 1 and 3 on a Monday, and most of the clientele were old guys. One young guy stopped in at the bar and chatted with my cousin and I for a while. The bartender was really friendly, as well as another old guy customer. Totally one of those places where you can come and hang out, have a drink, chat with the bartender and feel good about life. We were watching the Olympic swimming trials on the TV. A younger woman came in with her lunch to have a drink while we were there too - they let you bring your own lunch in. I just love the atmosphere of the Beats and the 60s, all the old pictures and signs and stuff :) I got a drink called the Jack Kerouac, which was YUMMY - $7, which was a little more than I usually spend, but I'd get it again. My cousin then ordered a Dark & Stormy, which I tried and also was good. I'll get it next time. :)
author: Erin A.

description: A cozy bar that feels like your neighborhood watering hole.  Casual and relaxed.  Service is fairly attentive.
author: Niniane W.

description:
It's a neighborhood bar with neighborhood people.  Yes you have tourist coming in here, but what do you expect when it has so much history behind it.  When a place has a name you will have to deal with crowds.  Getting a table can be a chore, but good things come to those who wait.  It's a bit difficult with large groups, but you make due.

One of my favorites to hit up when the crew decides to stay in the area.  The drinks were good and it's a good place just to hang out and talk with your friends.
author: Po L.

description:
My 2nd favorite bar in North Beach!
This is a great place for locals and visitors to mix and mingle.
I do love this place, and the staff, lime and lagers, and fernet.
And usually the music is good, pending on who is bartending. :)
author: Jess L.

description:
Excellent place to grab a beer with a few friends.

The second floor has a lot of tables and the music is not too loud -- such that it's actually possible to have a decent conversation.

Bartenders are very friendly and drinks are rather strong and reasonably priced.
author: Bill T.

description: Great bar with a bartender that served Jack Kerouac. Good atmosphere with a nice selection of beers. Prices were a little lower than I expected.
author: Chad P.

description:
Vesuvio...  the only place in SF where I would want to be flash petrified by a volcano should one occasion My Fair City.  

Portland, OR does have its charms, but here in NOBEACH this is a highly suitable place to ring in happy hours any day (or any hour thereof) of the week.   Like an oases in the Sahara this first of several watering holes diligently points the way out of the Lego Land that Finance Built to the humbler but potent pubs of Barbary.  If beer be bought then to Vesuvio you must go.  Cheers.
author: Jim W.

description:
If I was an alcoholic...scratch that. If I was a closet alcoholic, I was be here all the time as I would have lost my job due to extreme hangovers and drunken rages over under-delivered impressions.

I could imagine myself sitting in the top floor, in the corner overlooking Columbus street. I would sip on hard liquor as I chain smoked while writing my manifesto on a yellow stenopad. I would have stacks of books written by Dickinson and Dylan. I would not own a cell phone or blackberry and besides my manifesto, I would have many half-written letters to Congress and heads of state regarding "Big Brother" and the deterioration of modern society.

I dont know if I would ever come here during peak hours. I prefer to be moody and annoyed with less people around. Yet I can imagine the cynical poetry I could write as I watched happy couples drinking and smiling. I think Ive found inspiration.
author: Erin F.

description:
Maybe my favorite bar in San Francisco?  I love sitting upstairs and looking out the windows at the craziness going on during a Friday night in North Beach.  The drinks are good, they've got a huge beer selection, and the place is always full and never crowded.  

If your conversation gets bored, there's always the beat memorabilia on the walls and an old-timey risque slideshow above the bar.
author: Cory G.

description: Like this place.. good selection of beers, good service and nice location. Only drawback is that there is no food service ..
author: Arun Kumar G.

description:
I love this place! My friends took me here after my birthday dinner at Mona Lisa. Their mission was to get me smashed, and they definitely succeeded, haha. Sean Penn was sitting at the table next to ours and bought my friends and I a round of drinks! AWESOME. He said he saw us having fun and wanted us to keep on having a good time so he thought he'd buy us drinks! Best birthday ever!

Anyways, the place has two floors, and its usually crowded, especially the upstairs, and sometimes its hard to find a table. Other than that, its just a really chill place and I love coming here. 

+ That mural is awesome!
author: Stephanie C.

description: I've been next door to City Lights several times over the last decade, but this is the first time I went to Vesuvios. I know the history, so I was interested in this bar. It didn't disappoint at all! The bar was wonderfully eclectic and the Beat ambiance was infused into the very history of the bar. We grabbed some mixed drinks and beers and immediately headed upstairs. The chairs/tables were under windows along one side that opened to Columbus Ave and the blinking lights of one of the coolest intersections in San Francisco. The drinks were good, the people were good, and this was definitely not some tourist trap like places around here. I will go back here every time I come to San Francisco from now on.
author: Devon A.

description: I really love this place.  Probably, I walked in the door because of its history (and also because my beautiful companion suggested it and I followed her brilliant lead).  But, more importantly, I have had some really great times here.  Upstairs, in a booth, is a great place for an intimate conversation with someone you love.  Downstairs the bartenders are friendly and knowledgeable.  Great location right by City Lights Bookstore.  Purple Onion is just down the street.  Such great memories . . . .
author: Telast T.

description:
Even though I am more of a lounge-slash-club kind of a guy, when I do go to a bar, I wish all of them were like Vesuvio - quirky, well-decorated and cozy. Even if you don't care about where Jack Kerouac used to sit while sipping his rye, this bar is as San Francisco as it gets. 

Drinks are good, too. Spiked coffees are a particular treat to try. Sit downstairs if it's not too crowded, or up if it it's a date. Just beware that while the bartenders are generally pleasant and efficient, waitresses tend to be on the dumber side of the spectrum. 

The truly best part about this place is location - steps from the Citylights bookstore and in the middle of the hodge-podge of North Beach.  Great if you're a tourist, too. Thumbs up.
author: Evg R.

description: Nice decor and some funky looking people outside and inside the bar. The bartender however-gave my friend a cosmo when she ordered a vodka red bull. Was very unsocial at the bar and only talked to the other waitress. My Jack and coke was okay. Only had one drink and went back to Union. By the way this place is full of tourists.
author: Patrick M.

description:
It's amazing how good the service is here when you're sitting upstairs. Especially considering that the server has to navigate one of the world's most rickety staircases in the process.

Always a good time.
author: Andrew L.

description:
we just happened to wander into this bar on a sunday night....didnt know that its a tourist location..anyways, aside from that...

company with a fantastic girlie - check
walking distance - check
awesome bartender - check
cheap drinks (washington apple shots $6.50) - check
not overly crowded - check

nice and cool neighborhood dive bar.

i love, love this bar!

i want to come back here soon!!
author: Thi Le L.

description:
I'm wavering between giving the place 3 and 4 stars. I've had a few really fun nights here but I don't know if they were just fun because of the company. It's got two levels and a relatively normal noise level for a cafe of its stature. You can tell when you walk in that it's got a lot of history to it, though, so it's got a lot of inviting character built into it right off the bat.

Average prices, average well-drink generosity. The staff is pretty nice, from what I can tell. It's in a really great location, though, by City Lights bookstore in the North Beach area, so it's pretty accessible. It's great for a low-key conversation with a few good friends. Wouldn't be surprised to hear a few conversations around me buzzing about Palahniuk. 

I wouldn't make it my final destination for a night of fun, but it's a great place to stop by for a drink or two, on your way to, say, a strip club down the block. =)
author: Christa M.

description:
very chill.  the history adds to an already ideal layout.

also, a good alleyway for live music.
author: L J.

description:
In the kitchen, a good line cook is someone who, even though he may hate his job, hate culinary arts, and hate the customers who devour his creations, he does the job, and he does it well.  Anthony Bourdain calls them 'mercenaries'; "they do it for cash and they do it well" (from KItchen Confidential).

this defined our bartender at this fine establishment.
which was great - I wasn't looking for the fluff that I had seen so far during my 2-day venture into the bay city.
the drinks were good and always full.  there was love when he constructed the bloody mary that my companion enjoyed.

Vesuvio is a beatnik bar, located in Northbeach, next to the infamous City Lights Bookstore, with, of course, Jack Kerouac Alley sliding between the two.  stained glass windows illuminate the local artists' scattered canvases, and the indoor balcony allows a great view of the barscene downstairs.

destiny brought me to this hipster asylum of the bohemian vibe of which I dig, like crazy.  I will never again resist the strings of the universe when they guide me, downhill, beyond my sight (or so I say...).

go here and hang.
author: Jaime D.

description:
Sometimes on perfect Sunday afternoons, you want to retreat from the tiring world and spend some quality time with the one you love.

Sometimes when you're a disturbed young woman whose ennui is swallowing her whole, "the one you love" happens to be Dee Dee Ramone.

You just want a nook away from your crappy apartment to be with your beloved and while away the hours.  So you curl up in the corner of Vesuvio, nursing pints and reading Mr. Colvin's own account of his end days, hearing his voice as you read because you've watched "The End of The Century" more times than could possibly be healthy.

Hours later you emerge into the still glowing sunlight and saunter dreamily home, wondering whatever happened to being awesome, and whether you'll ever encounter anything as soul shattering as the birth of punk rock.






Vesuvio.  It's filled with assholes like me, submerging themselves in various depths of wistfulness.  Someday you may find yourself to be an asshole like me.  You'll know where to come to be in good company.
author: Coco D.

description:
Bar itself is quite charming.
Location of the place - wish it wasn't in north beach. 
Dive bar type with it's own artistic style. 

Environment is kick back and chill. Lovely areas for small and big groups of people -- that's only if you can make it up stairs, but don't worry the bar does supply a nice sturdy rail. 

The drinks were a bit on the expensive side but the service was really friendly. I had a great time - good pitchers of beer, butterly nipple shots, and good company. 

Definitely coming back.
author: MJ T.

description: Fantasic place! Best place to start your evening of carousing the bars of san francisco. I used to come here early in the morning years ago and occasionally i'd see paul kantner stop in for a couple shots, cool!
author: Kevin B.

description:
I ordered a Manhattan at Vesuvio after reading the article in the Chronicle about the Manhattan in Friday's paper.  Reading the article made me want to drink one right away.  At Vesuvio they used my favorite bourbon, Maker's Mark, and they not only gave me the full martini glass full but in addition they gave me a side car of the extra.  That is RARE!  I order Manhattans all the time and I have never been given a side car.

The place was PACKED!  The bathroom line was thankfully only 2 people long.  Great experience.
author: Tracy A.

description:
I arrived at Vesuvio at 12:30 AM after an already long Friday night, at which point I was dressed in an overly revealing homemade toga and clutching a gold sparkly wig.   My friend Meghan K. (dressed in identical fashion) and I had departed in a hurry from a costumed charity event in order to chase our (even drunker) friend across the city.  This chick was in no position to be wandering by herself in a toga through the perilous late-night streets of North Beach, and so it was that Meghan and I ended up in a taxi headed to Columbus and Broadway in order to find her. However, when drunky drunk refused to answer her phone and then hung up on us (the nerve!!), we decided we had had fulfilled our good-friend obligations to the best of our abilities and certainly deserved a beer for all our efforts.

And that is how we found ourselves standing at the bar at Vesuvio clutching our ivory robes (er, sheets) to our bodices and trying to act like we fit right in.  And to be honest, I doubt I've ever received better treatment at a bar in my entire life. Within five minutes, we each had a long island in front of us, purchased by a  friendly (though not even sketchy) dude at the bar, and surrounded by thoroughly enjoyable company.

It turns out that few things break the ice as effortlessly as a tight toga in a crowded bar. It was almost enough to make us forget about our dear drunk friend, who at that very moment was sitting outside my doorstep in Russian Hill in a drunken stupor and awaiting our return. 

Four stars for great location, good vibe, and good service even to the oddballs.  I will be back for sure.
author: Chelsea R.

description:
Love this place.  Crowded, yes.  Blistering hot upstairs on the balcony, yes.  World's record for tiniest bathrooms, yes.  Strong drinks, decent service, eclectic people watching and just all around good times? Hell yes!  

Vesuvio has the history and laid back atmosphere that you can stay for a little while or all night.  We celebrated our engagement here with friends and make a point of visiting when we're in the neighborhood.
author: Kelly I.

description:
We came to Vesuvio on a Sat night for the boyfriend's b-day with a group of his friends. The place was packed, but we found a small table upstairs. This is a cool place with a very vintage pub feel to it, definitely not my scene...but I get why people like it. I'm the girl that comes to a place like this, orders a glass of wine and hopes that a drunkard doesn't spill a beer on my pretty new shoes. Feel free to judge....I even have to stop and judge myself sometimes....
Anyways, my prissy ways aren't the issue here....it was our racist waitress!!
I mean, I'm aware that we were the only dark-skinned folk in the place...but we came to celebrate my boyfriend's birthday and buy a shitload of drinks! I'm thinking, doesn't this bitch want to make some money?? Apparently not. 
We sat at a table upstairs and the waitress literally looked at all of us....and walks away. She failed to come back to our table for about 30 minutes while she took every other table's drink order around us. Finally, my guy and his friend walk downstairs to order drinks directly from the bar. Our waitress was standing next to the bar so they asked her if they could order the drinks from her instead....she completely ignored them and walked away. We got all of our drinks from the bar and a few minutes later some of our white friends joined us....only THEN did this bitch come over to our table and ask us if we needed anything when she had already seen that the non-white folk had gotten their own drinks from downstairs. A word comes to mind for this twat and it starts with a C and rhymes with Bunt. 
She can shove her head up her own ass and die.
author: Shani D.

description: This place is so cute, I wish I lived there. Cozy nooks for small groups of friends. Huge windows to people-watch. Adorable and other-era-ish decor. The waitresses are incredibly attentive and nice. On a packed Friday night, no less. The crowd seems mostly San Franciscan, not your usual annoying or too cool. Pretty good for the area. This place makes me happy. I eeeeven some saw Gen-Y beatniks. Win!
author: K S.

description: We pre gamed here before heading to Castro. Cool little bar! I had the sweet tea vodka special and it was deeeeeelish! I probably gained 5 lbs with that one drink, but it was good!
author: Erika A.

description: We tried caroling here and the long haired bartender told us to stop singing.  This was on a Sunday night.  Way too up tight for Sunday at 6:30pm.  Bah humbug Vesuvio.  Worst bar in Northbeach along with Adler Museum.
author: Ian M.

description:
Cool bar to go for an after work drink. It isn't the greatest bar in the world as some people will tell you.

Came here last night with a group of 7-8 happy hour friends. We got a table upstairs no problem, after pushing through a couple of girls downstairs making out - sweet!

The waitress was slow, took her time to come over and ask for our orders. The bar wasn't crowded, and she seemed to be bored with work. A pitcher for $14 is also a bit steep, there are no happy hour specials, and the glasses are kinda small, forcing you to have to keep refilling them :(

Unfortunately I have no idea who Kerouac is, so I'm not filled with nostalgia. However, the stained glass and pictures are pretty awesome.
author: Joseph T.

description:
I've always loved Vesuvio, ever since I moved here and first heard of the place. It's well-placed in the hustle and bustle of North Beach, right next door to the amazing City Lights Bookstore, and across the street from another favorite, Specs. But the other night something happened that solidified my Vesuvio love, perhaps forever.
I was at Vesuvio the other night meeting some friends, and when I got in the cab to go home I noticed a brooch I always wear on my coat was gone. I figured it had fallen off in the bar and that would be that, gone forever. I loved it for sentimental reasons, it's nothing special, just a piece of costume jewelery, but it was special to me. When I got home I called the bar and spoke with Jack, who said they would let me know if they found it.
Yesterday afternoon I called to see if they had had any luck. Talked with Mike who told me that yes, indeed, they had it and I could come get it whenever. Yes! Awesome! When I got home last night there was a message on my voice mail from Jack telling me that he had found it and letting me know I could get it at my leisure. 
Talk about nice bartenders. Talk about good follow-through. Talk about genuine going-out-of-the-way-for-a-patron.
I can't say enough.
Thanks, Vesuvio, for being so awesome.
author: Rachel M.

description:
To go along with the citylight posting, Jack, Allen, and Will used to hang out here.  Who are these mythical characters you may be asking your self, well they are the founders of the one of the greatest movements in American literature history, the beat movement.  And they used get f'ed up here.
So this may be all fine and dandy, but it also a cool spot oozing with character, and history.  The walls practically whisper in your ears as you walk by.  Oh yeah and it is not to expensive.
author: brian m.

description: This place is so cute, downstairs by the bar was crowded, but I went up stairs to use the restroom and found the upstairs sitting area...a great place to end the night.
author: Kelly N.

description: Thought the staff would be pretentious but was pleasantly surprised.  Great vibe, you must sit upstairs near an open window.  I once had a coworker confess her love to me here so nothings out of the question at this spot in North Beach.
author: Sean H.

description: Touristy, bad beer selection but $7 absinthe!  (2 1/2 stars)
author: Sarah G.

description: I LOVE Vesuvio!!!  As a hole in the wall, dive bar, this place has EVERYTHING...Relaxed atmosphere, awesome location, and the bartenders rock!  It's close to everything and has become my "go to" place when we can't decide what to do/where to go!
author: d h.

description: This is probably the most hipster place I like to go to.  A classic bar with great decor and a second story just a few steps away from strip clubs and North Beach, if I'm looking to hang in SF, this is my first choice.  Pricing is comparable with other bars and when busy service can be an effort, but the atmosphere is lively and enjoyable.
author: Michael H.

description: I love this bar, but I hate waiting for a table. It's great to catch a mid-afternoon pint with a buddy in this history rich watering hole. Just plan on getting there early if you're thinking about a Friday night pub crawl.
author: David H.

description: this was a PLAN B decision! we initially wanted to go to San Francisco Brewing Co, but I didn't do my research and the brewery closed down 2 years ago (BUMMER!) it's now a trendy, fancy italian restaurant. Went in the bar for a couple of drinks before heading down to Kyoto's Sushi restaurant! cool decor.. cool people! Happy Hour drinks were reasonable! I will probably go back!
author: Ooh Lal A.

description:
In college, in the mid-90's, I and my roommates  spent serious quality time here.  We lived up the street on Vallejo, and this was very much our neighborhood hangout, despite the tourist crowds.  

...So many memories I cannot even begin to try to recount them all, though my favorite is watching the view from the second story -- up Columbus toward Broadway, where the lights of the strip clubs were misty in the first rain of the season.  It was a "sick" day from school I took when a buddy came up to visit.  Ahhhh... cold Anchor never tasted better, and Coltrane on the jukebox made everything right in the world...
author: Jason B.

description: Love the interior and location; an awesome place to grab drinks before it is too late; accommodating to crowdfulls of hipsters. Cool bartenders, and fun atmosphere.
author: Y K.

description: An sf classic!  A diverse mix of people and lots of history made here.
author: Emm C.

description: very cool laid back bar in Northbeach, look for a seat on the second floor!
author: Phillip J F.

description: I loved the place, and the setting.  However, while sitting in the corner booth upstairs with my mid 20's aged friends, the waitress sat a table of 8 elderly males completely blocking us in from getting served, getting up to go out for a smoke or the bathroom.  Not only is this a fire hazard it was blatant disrespectful discriminatory gesture to us younger patrons.  Knowing if it was vice-versa I am sure she wouldn't have had a table of 8 younger patrons blocking off elderly ones.   We made it very clear to the waitress that we thought it was disrespectful, and I hope if this happens again to anyone they vocalize their feelings and made sure it doesn't happen again. I know this is a SF landmark, but people don't deserve to be treated disrespectfully when they are out to enjoy an evening.  Just wanted to put it out there.
author: Sonam G.

description: Vesuvio is rich in history and simply a great place!
author: Lisa R.

description: For the sheer novelty of sitting in that upstairs with the low ceiling that make me feel tall, this place is great.  Fun views out the window, and the prices are reasonable for all the ambiance.  My gin and tonics were also quite well-mixed.
author: Marc S.

description:
Normally love this place and go from time to time in the day.  I brought some out-of-towners here and they were super excited, loved the ambiance and old San Francisco charm.  At first everything was going well, then the waitress started to forget about us.  Didn't check in on our empty glasses, bring the right number of shots, etc.  Considering the friends I was with are or have been in the service industry they were very calm and understanding BUT when we asked to split the bill among cards we got chewed out.  I understand this a divey, old bar that doesn't appreciate needy patrons but the scene that was made was really embarrassing and left everyone uncomfortable. 

I will probably end up here again at some point, but will remember to bring cash and NOT visitors.
author: Melissa H.

description: Nice cozy bar with good vibes. Good place to chill when strolling through Chinatown or North beach.
author: Rocky S.

description:
The Cosmo sucked - might as well have ordered rubbing alcohol.

The ambiance was pretty enjoyable - esp. on the second flr. 

My girl friend and I met two guys here.  Two very strange, strange guys....

Perhaps I should give it another chance next time I visit SF.  I mean, there has to be a reason behind all y'all giving it 4-5 stars! :)
author: Claire Y.

description:
Vesuvio is a historic SF landmark.  The reason to go there and to City Light is to reach back in time and imagine Ginsberg, Kerouac, and the rest of the Beat artist sitting there with you.  Funky 2nd floor and the purple stained glass will never be reproduced.

Beyond the architectue and history though just rests a regular bar and typical slow bar service.  Nonetheless, it is a good scene and every so often when I get sick of the XYZ's of the world, I'll hit up a little slice of Old SF.
author: Laurence H.

description:
Went on a Sunday afternoon and accidentally stumbled into a poetry reading taking place in the upstairs loft area. I like poetry, I do and I'm fairly open minded but this poetry wasn't that great. Marks the first time I've ever had to whisper in a bar, though. 

Love the memorabilia on the walls...truly unique to this part of town. Wine and beer are good. We actually sampled the Jack Kerouac drink....wow....I guess it's good if you frequently like the taste of two totally different drinks mixed together. 

The bartender was nice until the poetry crowd hit the downstairs, at which point getting our check to us was the last thing on his mind...sadly, we had to insist so my brother could make it to the airport on time to catch his flight.

They don't serve food but have a small assortment of chips.
author: Angela N.

description: I used to hang out here a lot more before... years ago, but I have yet to write a review. I recently visited again and realize it really hasn't changed too much. I wish they had pear cider on tap so I can get it in a pitcher, but no luck there... all these years and I still have to stick to bottles. I believe they were $4.50 a pop... not too bad. The place is very informal, has a stuffy old attic feel that is very homey like. It is a great place for large groups if you manage to get there when it is not too packed. I see myself returning for more in the future.
author: Amelia M.

description:
there's something about Vesuvio's that draws you to the door. if you come here you will not be disappointed. it must be the colors and the lights that shine out the balcony windows with silhouettes floating on the second floor. 

i like this place. probably because of the beatnik history and spirit it has within it's walls. the ambiance is just right. although it might be crazy outside, walking in the this place changes everything. the bartenders are friendly and everyone here is super mellow. nothing crazy. not only did i enjoy my seat at the bar, but the music selection was pretty damn good. 

this is definitely a place i am coming back to when i'm in the city. it's also a place i would like to bring all my friends to. cheap drinks. great vibes all around. interesting people. yeah, this place is pretty beatific.

close to leaving i noticed a man sitting alone at a table upstairs observing the people downstairs. i was doing the same, observing the locals. then later on i noticed he was gone. i turned around to say something to my sister and was frightened by a figure standing next to me. there he was. it must have been the ghost of Jack Kerouac because he came down from upstairs and asked me to join him at his table for a drink. i declined and told him i was leaving. he must have been looking for Marilu... if you've read On the Road, then you'll know what i'm talking about.
author: Marilu R.

description: A fun spot and another home for the Beats. Right next to City Lights. Buy a book them come here and read while having a brew. Interesting characters. Many locals have given me some great tips while hanging out here.
author: Larry B.

description:
Even though this may be considered a tourist trap to most, its a landmark in my book. My uncle took me here for the first time when I was 22. Of course he told me all the history he had with the place, so I feel a connection with it now when I bring others here for the first time.
The drinks are stiff and the serve absynth from what I last remember? Guinness and most other popular beers are on tap here, so it satisfies most all alcoholics. Cheers!
author: Garrett B.

description: Anyone liking this bar probably liked the whole Beat thing, so ya, I read Kerouac, Ginsberg, Brautigan- so its pretty cool going drinking at the same place where these guys did. I always thought this bar had a great vibe- from the anti-social guy reading a newspaper in the bar (go figure), to the tourists who just walked from the City Lights to the surly waitresses (they are so much fun). Always a great time at this bar. I always make it a pt to have a few brews here while in SF. A great place to just sit back and watch the sidewalk traffic or good conversation.
author: Jimmy J.

description:
ive only been here once but it took me forever to get a drink. it was empty, the bartender knew i was waiting, but he just kinda twiddled his thumbs. 

i eat a lot of chinese food so im used to bad service, but this one was quite impressionable.
author: Michael N.

description:
Quaint little bar that somehow reminds me of riding a double-decker bus. It's long and narrow with an upstairs portion that overlooks the bar. I had a Jack Kerouac (I think it was vodka, tequila, OJ, pineapple) and that was mighty tasty. Tables are small; it's not ideal for large groups.

Times visited: 1
author: Amy L.

description:
Oh yeah.  I like this place.  This place makes me want to drink! No fancy attitude, no b.s. cocktail names, just good drinks.  

Vesuvio is one of our favorite places for happy hour! Usually we'd show like 15 of us and we would take up half of the mezzanine! I often wonder if the thing is going to collapse of all the happy people up there!
author: N. C.

description:
I secretly want to give 4 stars, but only because there is no food here.  I guess, fair enough, it IS a bar, and they don't have to have food.  So five stars it is and here is why:

1. David the bartender...you were an accomplice to a girlfriend of mine and I getting buzzed-up goofy after a wretched day at work.  You were sassy, you were fun, and really, who can ask for more?  Made our whole night (and even the puking the next day) so much more enjoyable!

2. One of the few bars downtown that has Red Bull.  Maybe there are others, but my favorite drink in the whole world- a Pat Swayze- requires the use of it.  And lots of folks in the FiDi lately have been tellin' me no- and not very nicely- they don't have the sweet nectar I need for my cirrhosis to keep churning.  Thanks Vesuvio, for keepin' it real.

3. The coolest alleyway mural around!  Sit upstairs overlooking it and you will find something new in the painting every time.  

4. Adjacent fabulous bookstore.  If drinking makes you want to read, you're in luck cause City Lights is right next door.

Plus, it's a great place to vent about your workday but private enough that you don't have to listen to the people next to you bitch about theirs.
Amen to that!
author: Lea N.

description:
I give this 4.5 stars, but only because I'm selfish and I can't find an upstairs window seat every time I'm there. 
Yes, this, for me, is really about the history and the people-watching.
author: K L.

description: This is simply a great bar.  One of my favorites in the city.
author: Neil A.

description: Stopped in to kill some time and get out of the cold rain. What a treat.  OK, some of the clientele were a bit scary and seemed to have just come off the streets, but the staff treated them all with respect and dignity. I could spend days just reading everything on the walls. Only regret was that I didn't know about the vending machine in the men's room. Cheers!
author: Paul S.

description: There are SO many bars to choose from in the city but when in North Beach, Vesuvio's is a decent choice if you don't want the super loud, over crowded drunkards to contend with.  Great place to meet for a date before dinner or with girlfriends.  I don't come here often because the drinks are just so-so, the bartenders are not very consistent and I find the cocktails are a bit watered down (the last time I was there I had a vodka gimlet and am still wondering if he put any vodka in it- yep, sometimes they are that bad).  But if you're looking for a cool place to hang out for an hour or so and do some great people watching, Vesuvio's will do.
author: Moto L.

description:
DISCLAIMER: I am a huge HUGE fan of Jack Kerouac, so I might be slightly biased towards Vesuvio. Just giving you a warning.

I'm not really big on modern clubs and "bars." I find I generally go to places that draw a good crowd, but also allow for sitting to enjoy drinks and have good conversation. That's the kind of atmosphere you'll find at Vesuvio. It's a popular destination, for both locals and tourists. The drinks are pretty good as well. Aside from beer and wine, I've tried the Kerouac drink (that probably surprises nobody). It's rum, tequila, cranberry and orange juice with a slice of lime. It is a fantastic drink- it doesn't taste too strong but it packs a punch. I would definitely recommend ordering it if you happen to be there. After my first time having it, I found myself saying "this is the best drink I've ever had" and my friend agreed.

But, aside from the good drinks and atmosphere, it's also a literary and historical landmark. You can drink in a bar that hosted some of the most famous and celebrated authors of the 20th Century. I don't think a lot of people realize that. This isn't just a bar, or a popular bar, but a piece of history. It's worth at least one visit, so you can say you did. Plus, you can pay a visit to City Lights either before or after and leave with an armful of books as well.
author: Tom B.

description: This place is not a lounge - it's a bar. All traces of literary heritage have been plastered over by generic noisy bar ambience. And the fact that all walks frequent here is not so unique to the area. A good place - an okay place. Chill though.  So how's that for an amazing review.
author: Andrew M.

description:
This place is ripe with history and the beer selection is fantastic.  Vesuvio is the original North Beach bar, the crowd authentic, the decor outstanding.

Come here with the expectation of having a beer or 2 and soaking in local culture, then move on to another venue for a better looking crowd, music, etc.
author: T D.

description:
Vesuvio has what is possibly the finest interior of any San Francisco bar. A pleasing spot to hang on a late, weekday afternoon and enjoy the North Beach street action from one of the upstairs tables or peer over the railing at the ornate decorations below. Vintage slide shows from an antique projector and an authentic above bar gas lamp are among the nice details. Quite crowded toward and on the weekend, but this is North Beach after all.

Not sure which bartender one of the reviewers was likening to a "good line cook" but if it was Jack the Hat, be forewarned that he is also one of the tightest barmen in the neighborhood. Expect to be five rounds in before he even considers buying you a drink. (Not that this is the worst characteristic a bartender could possess - he is fairly attentive, mixes a decent drink, isn't big on idle chit chat and even penned his own "how to treat your bartender" book.)

Ladies room is upstairs, guys downstairs. They won't take your order at the bar if you're sitting at a table, and the hostesses can be a bit slow on the uptake. Jack Kerouac saturation and phony ex Beat vibe aside, an excellent San Francisco establishment.
author: R M.

description:
Finally was able to get inside and get a table after several, previous failed attempts.  I dont know.  It's very crowded and hard to get a table.  But the bartender chick did get us our drinks really, really quickly.  

I think I have a thing against North Beach in general.  Why does everything close so fucking early????
author: brewgirl b.

description:
Great drinks, great prices, great patrons, great views from the second floor, I like this place...ALOT.

We had the best seat in the house I'm told for some romantic little drinky date chitchat.  The people watching is great from the upstairs windows and it was not crowded in the early evening, just comfortable.
author: Tanya C.

description:
Dirty, loud, packed. The essential SF "dive" bar. Great location, awesome locals, strong ass drinks. What more could you ask for?

Love the upstairs window seating, great place to people watch, down a beer (or 2!), & make new friends.  

The decor is funky, fun and lively. The waitstaff is friendly, sassy and if your nice to them, they'll be nice to you =) They have a great jukebox selection.  Bring your crew, grab some beer, and check your attitude at the door please!
author: Lulu C.

description: If you are in the area and you don't have anywhere to go, this place is always good for a, "let's just kick it at Vesuvios".  It's very mellow and the bartenders and waitresses are very cool.  The atmosphere is, well, the only way to describe it is chill.  Don't come if you're looking for a crazy time, but definitely come if you're in a chill mood.  Sit upstairs and have the drinks come to you :)
author: Tony N.

description: Not to be passed up, the bar friends are enjoyably friendly a writers world and the bar caretakers...(what will you be drinking?) are amazing. I definitely have to say each time when visiting my second home I always try to stop by.... cheap, easy and friendly...plus china town is close by to get a little shopping in.
author: Sera F.

description: Came here after 1am because we wanted  to get our drink on before we hit the sack. Walked in and it was totally dirty and smelly!  Floor was wet from spilled drinks.  The smell of this place remind me of the dumpsters in the streets of Chinatown in the wee hours of the morning.  Totally pukey but hey, I'm a nurse so I've smelled worse things.  Anyway, it didn't deter me from our goal and headed upstairs.  Only a few people were there so we picked a corner area.  We people watched from above and once in a while shouted on them.  We made funny noises and threw pennies.  They couldn't figure out where it was coming from.  Totally hilarious!  With all that said, their drinks are awesome.  Cosmo and Long Island is all I needed to have some fun.  Kudos to the bar tenders! And by the time I left, I forgot all about the smell!!!
author: Gem A.

description:
Classic Dive bar
This place looks like it has
been here forever
Stiff Drinks
Bohemian crowd
Two thumbs Up
author: Tommy T.

description:
What I like most about this place:

The fact that it's open at 6am daily.
The old school porn on display.
---
author: will h.

description:
Vesuvio, I think you're the only bar in North Beach I actually like. Thank you.

I've stopped in here a couple times with big groups and small groups and had decent bar service. It's a place where I'm actually able to have a conversation at a normal decibel level. 

My most recent trip was a Saturday night. I told my boyfriend when and where to meet me and headed out a little early to stake out a spot. I ordered my delicious vodka tonic and was lucky to stalk a table with a group departing. Sat down, got cozy and pulled out my book to wait for my date. No creeps tried to talk to me which is a big plus. Most of the time when I go into a place alone I've got creeps casing me out. Eh maybe I was looking ugly that night, I don't know but I did appreciate the lack of creeps. 

I love how the bartenders come around to the tables to take drink orders if need be.

My only gripe is taking the stairs up to the restroom in heels. Who the hell laid that out like that?
author: Jessica R.

description:
I love this place.

Yes, perhaps a bit touristy, but hey, I am a tourist and considering most tourist traps, this one is pretty and cool and is chock full of San Francisco history.

I came here with my sister and another friend (we're all New Yorkers) one late autumn night during a weekday, and it was not packed at all.  We were the only other party on the second floor aside from a couple.

Beautiful view (then again I think all views in San Francisco are breathtaking), good drinks and kitschy interior.
author: Regina J.

description:
Great historical bar hangout


Before the beat there was Rexroth, pay your dues. Read him

Kenneth Rexroth inspired all these cats in the 50's and 60's, but due to the unamerican committee he was blackballed.


Good bar, but I thank there are a lot of fakes showing up at this joint. Take your hipster attitude and stop conforming to an old ideal.

break the mold
author: Mike S.

description:
I dig this place.  It feels like history took place there, and certainly looks like it could have, as it's decor and architecture are old school SF.  

Why, specifically, I love it:
They have the most extensive dictionary I've ever seen outside of a library behind the bar.  It's being held together by duct tape.
If you're a remotely cute female, the bartender on Friday nights will talk to you.  Makes decent conversation, but probably won't comp you drinks unless you promise to put out.
One of the best book stores on the planet next door.
Italian food up the street served into the wee hours of the morning.
Nifty mezzanine for good people watching.
Takes credit cards.

Visit.  Do it.
author: Jessica R.

description: Such a great spot! The second floor is wonderful. Love to just read a book & have beer while watching Columbus Ave. while there, and great for large gatherings too. Perhaps the best bar in North Beach (though I love Tosca's and Specs too...)
author: Jim D.

description:
I like this place so much I am almost hesitant to write a review. 
The decor is cool, the people were nice, there were very few tourists when I was in there.  The beer list is ok, but they have cheap coffee and a lot of seating.
author: E P.

description: Vesuvio has a great atmosphere, and it instantly feels like your local bar, with what seems like a nice crowd of normal people. I love the low ceilings in the upper galley. It's a great place to meet a friend.
author: Chadwick M.

description: Still love the place and will always have a special place in my heart, but the jukebox is gone.  They'd removed it a couple of years ago.  I guess an iPod replaced it.
author: Kev M.

description: I love the atmosphere in this bar -- relaxed, great music, amazing decor/art, easy to find a quiet corner if you want. Drinks are reasonably priced.
author: Sarah B.

description: When you walk in, you will lose all sense of the proper passage of time.  When you walk out, you will forget that the floor was not actually made of hardwood.  If you have the words to spare, let the morning bartender, the one named Tony who is convinced all good things in the world come from Italian invention, know I say, "Hello."
author: Squid V.

description:
The Beat mystique is tangible at Vesuvio (and City Lights Books next door).  Sitting upstairs overlooking the bar, I spied several characters who could easily have been Neal Cassady's aging disciples.  History aside, you owe yourself a drink here whether you've ever read Kerouac and Ginsberg or not.  

As it happened, most everyone I met at the bar the one Saturday night I was there seemed to be from somewhere else, and Vesuvio seemed to crystallize all of the reasons we were already planning on coming back.  Perhaps the next time I knock (or, as I'm more prone, sip) one back at Vesuvio, the veil of romance will have parted and I'll be able to give a more objective assessment of Vesuvio as a bar alone, pure and simple, but I'm not counting on it.  So shuffle along to Vesuvio yourself to wallow in Beat nostalgia or to just get buzzed or hammered, as you wish, in a fabulous bar that's in an even more fabulous neighborhood.
author: Melissa W.

description: One of my favorite bars in The City. I've gotten pretty lucky and had the upstairs front window table several times, it's the best! Love the vibe, love the decor, and love bouncing across the street between here and Spec's.
author: Gina B.

description: I really adore the random assortment of people that collect here. The place feels a bit like a time warp, with its Victorian framed paintings, stained glass windows, and cigarette girls hawking their wares. It's great that they offer table service, and everyone is always really friendly. Five stars, for sure!
author: Kay B.

description: Very cool atmosphere, great place to stop by in the afternoon for a drink.  A dive bar, but with some serious character.  Very worthy of a visit.
author: M R.

description:
woo hoo! i love love love it! my boyfriend was here a couple months ago and knew i would love it.

1- TONS of stuff to look at. thats very important to me. i am a watcher so if theres not stuff on the walls, i stare at people. bf doesnt like that. lol

2- drink special- recession special is a beer and shot of old crow $4. ick, but i was drunk

3- you go up the stairs to more seating and you just feel like you are in a bar that has seen a old western-gun slinging- bar fight more than once. its awesome! like part of the gold rush or something. 

4- bartender girl was kinda rude, but why would she be nice? shes making bank doing very little, and you know shes busy. 

5- you can sit upstairs and see all the people on the street. i mean yeah, its a big window, but theres something about the glass and the position above the street that feels fun. and they have fun booths

i will be back next time!
author: Delaney P.

description: This was the first place to introduce me to seagrams sweet tea vodka and lemonade and for that I am thankful. It's also a cute little bar in San Francisco North Beach area with a pretty damn good jukebox playing the likes of The Kinks. If you're about definitely pop in
author: Charlotte H.

description: Being primarily a night worker I've only been to Vesuvio at hours normal for me but odd for most other people in the USA. I had the good fortune to live in North Beach for about 5 months & I used to stroll down here for a beer & bloody mary at the crack of 6 a.m. Even at that odd for most hour there was usually a motley bunch here reading books or morning papers with their drinks. Sitting in a bar at that hour is actually a preferred time in my opinion. More of a subdued quiet time for contemplation. Conversations carry on in lowered voices but occasionally the maniac would burst through the doors jolting everyone out of their quiet meditations and the place would burst to life. I really miss this place.
author: Chuck F.

description: Wonderful SF bar!  Its great as long as you can score a table upstairs.  Some of the best people watching in the city if you manage to sit by the huge windows.  Everytime I go I get to watch street performers in the alley adjacent to the bar, dramatic fights between quarreling couples, and slap stick comedy care of the drunks coming out of the strip clubs down the street.  This place is just dripping with ambience and charm that is hard to define.  Just go check it out!  And popin out City Lights bookstore next door if you have time.
author: BeeryMcGymrat X.

description: Cheap drinks, generous pours, friendly service, great location, and 2 floors of seating. What more can you ask for.
author: Jun W.

description: Even though this place is steeped in SF history I can't figure out exactly why it's considered one of the best pubs in the world.
author: Manny F.

description: This place is real chill. Like a LOT of other SF bars: nice atmosphere, cheap drinks and walking distance from a bunch of good eateries. good show.
author: Jaymes H.

description: Maybe it was the company, but there's nothing like a mandarin 7 in the "lady psychiatrists booth"...
author: Jaynel G.

description: Bonus:  You can go here dressed in full pirate regalia, and nobody will give you a second glance.  It might even get you faster service.  The occasional tourist will take your picture, but there's no harrrrm in that.
author: Andi T.

description: This place has a lot of character.  It's always fun to come here and chill out with a couple of pints.  I love it more though when it's not as crowded.  When it's real crowded on the weekends, it can be kind of hectic.
author: Mitch A.

description: Vesuvio is a fabulous little bar. I've never had snooty bartenders here but you can run into those just about anywhere. It's not excusable, but I'm just sayin I've had pleasant experiences here every time I've gone, and i adore the ambiance. As with just about ANY cool bar worth visiting, avoid the amateur drinkers by going at random times other than Fri & Sat nights... I mean, it's simple logic. Unless you are 21 being smooshed into a bar and not getting any service is just not fun. And Vesuvio is a popular place in the middle of North Beach where 90% of the tourists will be drinking on a weekend... so go on a Wednesday or something. The table in the front upstairs overlooking the street is a great place to chill.
author: margot b.

description:
they didn't kick me out. they kept the drinks coming. i could carry on a conversation with the people i was with. it comes with some history. that all makes me happy to drink here. 

sitting upstairs is a great people watching spot though a lot of stairs down to the restroom. this is a place we normally stop at when we do our mini pub crawl till we eat dinner. if the bartender gives me our drinks he can have his attitude. he has to go home with it. though it does bring the mood down if you have to deal with not getting my drinks.
author: roger b.

description:
A great space. A nice vibe. 

But too bad their beers all have to be crap. The usual bad beers easily supplied for cheap by one distributor I bet. One of their "micro brews" is Blue Moon, which is a total gimmick (in taste as well as image) and is really part of Coors. It has an unusual taste because it's flavored, not because of anything high quality about the beer making ingredients. But hey this is the story about beer at most bars.
author: Tom K.

description: I've wanted to go in here for quite some time, but for one reason or another, didn't until a few nights ago. It certainly was worth the wait. Got a table upstairs, sat right by the open window, which I'm thankful for because it was super warm in there. My gin gimlet was exceptional. The music and ambiance, top notch. I'll definitely be going back when I'm in Northbeach again.
author: Ravenna P.

description: Last Saturday afternoon, I sat down at the bar at Vesuvio to rest my weary feet for my commute into San Francisco had been an exhausting endeavor.  It was very busy so I when I was served, i was more than ready to be a part of this historic watering hole.  The staff was polite and helpful and I felt a real connection to the clientele, especially a particularly cool group that walked in. (Go Dallas Cowboys! Don't mess with Texas!)  Chatting with the barkeep about children and not taking our Aryan heritage for granted, I thought I had finally found my home.  Oh, how wrong I was.  As I handsomely sipped my Irish Coffee, I noticed several of my fellow douche nozzles unfairly thrown out because they brought alcohol into a bar!  How dare they enforce such a Draconian policy!  My local Red Lobster NEVER says anything when I bring in my own Shrimp Scampi!  Well, I was appalled by the intolerance but then came sublime vindication. I smiled and winked to myself in the bar mirror and thought, "Ha!  A bitingly witty Yelp review is sure to follow. That'll show them.  That'll show them."  And yes Matt L., I am mocking you.
author: James D.

description: Unless you are claustrophobic (small boxy rooms, very low ceilings, narrow staircases), I suggest checking out this famously quaint and character-rich beatnik hangout some night for a cappuccino or a well drink.  Its directly adjacent to City Lights Bookstore, which was founded by Lawrence Ferlinghetti.  A neat old place saturated with artsy bohemian atmosphere.
author: Rick H.

description: Ahh this place is fun! A great location, friendly people, generally a younger crowd. The only reason I won't put up 5 stars is because drinks here are typically a dollar more than the drinks across the street at Spec's, and it does get a little crowded, but they offer a huge variety--they even do Absinthe, or at least, they did the last time I was there. An all-around great time, cool atmosphere with lots of windows on the second story. Cool bathrooms too! Add a magazine clipping to the wall for fun.
author: Macey B.

description: You have to dig this place for its literary history alone, but talk about ambiance. If I decide to play hooky from work you just might find me upstairs attempting some prose, pretending to work on a script or just making up stories about the "dancers" having a smoke across the way.  Vesuvio's is a great staging area for almost any North Beach or Chinatown adventure.
author: Mingus R.

description: Oh I like the feel of this place.  It's warm and has some great perching spots on the second floor.  I hardly ever remember that I like this place unless someone's in from out of town, in which case I remember that San Francisco has a captivating history.  Vesuvio is truly unique.
author: Jennifer B.

description: My mom likes to come here because it reminds her of when she was a freewheelin' twentysomething in the Big City.  On that basis alone, I avoid Vesuvio.
author: Pumpkin K.

description: Always interesting haunt.  Quirky decor.  Funny bartender.  Nicely made drinks.  But no food.  (pout.) (then shrugs.)  Next time I'll bring my own.
author: Poet D.

description: The one place in North Beach that I would agree to go to -- it's what this area of SF should be and not the ghetto clubs that line that street.  Back when I used to live in SF this place had a great juke, strong and cheap drinks, and a cool hanging rattan chair that was ultra fun when buzzing.  Love that it's not a tourist spot, too.
author: Helen C.

description: This might be my favorite bar in San Francisco. It's old school and very cozy. Chances of you running into a lot of tourists here are very slim. I've had many many good times here, always on the second floor. The view is great up there.
author: Josh H.

description: I agree with the previous review, The guy bartender sucks.  This place is a staple of old school and you feel like a part of history.  Too bad the bartender tried to rip me off.  I laid my money on the bar and he picked up my my tab money AND my change.  then he wanted to charge me again when i was leaving, what a con artist. When i confronted him he just shrugged it off and said  "OH".  Watch this dude.
author: D D.

description:
One of my favorite bars in the SF.  Right next to commie haven, City Lights bookstore (check out the mural in Jack Kerouac Alley of noble gun toting, mask-wearing guerrillas protecting a peaceful and vibrant socialist society, replete with playing children).

The bar is quite nice, though entirely unpretentious. Plenty of seating both upstairs and downstairs.  Last time I was there they did not serve food, but feel free to bring your lunch and have a pint.   At night (at least on the weekends) the crowd generally consists of young professionals and a smattering of students and older professionals.  Depending on the night, you can also catch a number of artist types--always a good conversation to be had.

Another major selling point for Vesuvio--besides itsbeatnik tradition and lore--is its 6am opening time 7 days a week.  Dave is usually the man who will be handling your drinking needs.  He is always up for  a good chat and more than accommodating.  You get all kinds at that hour (google "90 Proof Breakfast"  for more info), but it is generally peaceful and laid back .  

If you are looking to escape the madness of the Broadway/Columbus scene when in North beach, check out Vesuvio (and Specs across the street).
author: Socrates M.

description:
Jackpot~~!! After our horrendous experience at the plastic cup drink serving ghetto fab Zebra Lounge, we came here. It was recommended by a lady we met on the plane ride to SF who was really cool and helpful. Anyway, we walked in...the place had a lot of character and charm. It had a Cheers-like feel to it. (Sometimes you wanna go where everybody knows your name). It was pretty full with all sorts of people. Surprising on a Thursday night. The bartender was really cool. My friend wasn't feeling well so he even gave her green tea. Dude...green tea at a bar?? Who does that?? Haha. He was really nice. After the whole green tea thing...I spilled my Henney and coke all over the bar...NICE~! He made me a new one with a smile. We sat at the bar for about an hour and a half...had many many Henney and cokes, Vodka tonics and Pear ciders. The bartender came by with complimentary shots of Jager. Not the best mix in my tummy but thank you Mr. Bartender man for welcoming us to SF~!! 

***Oh, oh , oh~!! I realized that the drinks are dirt cheap here!!***
author: Caroline Y.

description: A great bar starts with great ambience- stained glass windows, backlit whiskeys, an antique slide projector.  They mix the classics well, have some decent microbrews, and interesting specialty drinks (bohemian coffee and the jack kerouac).  This place is too good for it's own good but while this place draws a trendier crowd on weekend nights, this is still a great place to go off-peak (as early as 6 am).  The second floor is a perfect spot for a date if you can get a table, while the bar area draws a very mixed crowd eager for conversation- an "I'm from Texas!" type sitting next to a bohemian reading a book and casting dirty looks anytime anyone talks too loud.
author: Rob R.

description: A legend...and for good reason...the history alone warrants 5stars...the atmosphere, staff, and cheap drinks confirm it...a MUST...
author: d v.

description: Vesuvio is a San Francisco institution and, when you're drinking there, you can feel the history seeping through its walls.  Jack Kerouac, Allen Ginsberg and the like raised many a glass here -- and you will, too 'cos it's awful tough to peel your butt from the seat when the pitchers keep coming and coming. Vesuvio is best on a rainy weeknight with a good friend or lover. Make your way to one of the upstairs window tables, talk close, drink whiskey and watch the world go by through a veneer of raindrops.
author: Katie B.

description: I have a fondness for it.  The jukebox has some great tunes and the bartenders pour a good drink.  Plus the whole beat generation vibe comes through 50 years later.
author: T-Bone L.

description:
why have i been to north beach more times in the last two months than in the past ten years? i don't know. but i enjoyed my absinthe upstairs.

i've been thinking about getting a boat- a sailboat, probably. i don't know how to sail, so i'll have to take lessons, i guess.
author: vincent m.

description: The corner of this world on which Vesuvio and City Lights is situated is truly blessed. The list of house drinks alone is awesome. What other place has drinks like "Bohemian Coffee," "And Only for the Devout," or "The Jack Kerouac"? My favorite thing to do during an evening in San Francisco is pay a little visit to the bar in this place with my friends and read the quotes about drinking while carrying on a lively group discussion.
author: Daniel R.
